question_text:
A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy and headache for the past 6 hours. Three days ago, she was started on dapsone and rifampin for the treatment of tuberculoid leprosy. Her pulse is 115/min and respirations are 12/min. Physical examination shows bluish discoloration of the lips and nail beds. A venous blood sample appears chocolate-colored and does not change color when exposed to oxygen. Compared to a healthy child, arterial blood gas analysis in this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

%O_2 saturation
O_2 partial pressure
O_2 content
Hb concentration

A
Normal
normal
increased
increased

B
Normal
normal
decreased
decreased

C
Decreased
normal
decreased
normal

D
Decreased
decreased
decreased
normal

E
Decreased
normal
decreased
increased
content_preview: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy and headache for the past 6 hours. Three days ago, she was started on dapsone and rifampin for the treatment of tuberculoid leprosy. Her pulse is 115/min and respirations are 12/min. Physical examination shows bluish discoloration of the lips and nail beds. A venous blood sample appears chocolate-colored and does not change color when exposed to oxygen. Compared to a healthy child, arterial blood gas analysis in this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings? %O2 saturation O2 partial pressure O2 content Hb concentration A Normal normal increased increased B Normal normal decreased decreased C Decreased normal decreased normal D Decreased decreased decreased normal E Decreased normal decreased increased
hint: In a patient undergoing treatment with dapsone, tachycardia, respiratory depression, cyanosis, and chocolate-colored blood on venous sampling should raise suspicion for acute methemoglobinemia.
learning_objective: Recognize methemoglobinemia, and recall its arterial blood gas findings.

answers.explanation_why: These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with polycythemia vera (PV), a condition characterized by an increase in erythrocyte count and thus hemoglobin (Hb) concentration. While this results in an increased arterial O_2 content, O_2 partial pressure and O_2 saturation remain normal because these parameters mainly depend on the inhaled oxygen concentration, atmospheric pressure, and gas exchange in the lungs, none of which is affected by increased Hb concentration. Classical manifestations of PV include facial flushing and pruritus, neither of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, respiratory depression, which is seen here, would not be expected.

These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with anemia, which is characterized by low serum concentrations of hemoglobin (Hb) and, as a consequence, reduced arterial O_2 content. O_2 partial pressure and O_2 saturation remain normal because these parameters mainly depend on the inhaled oxygen concentration, atmospheric pressure, and gas exchange in the lungs, none of which is affected by low Hb concentration. Anemia can cause tachycardia, which is seen in this patient, but pallor rather than cyanosis would be expected. Moreover, chocolate-colored blood that does not change color when exposed to oxygen is not seen in anemia.

Methemoglobinemia is caused by an abundance of methemoglobin, an altered form of hemoglobin in which ferrous iron (Fe^2+) is oxidized to the ferric form (Fe^3+). Since Fe^3+ cannot bind oxygen, arterial O_2 saturation and total O_2 content decrease. This leads to functional anemia, despite normal hemoglobin concentrations. Patients with methemoglobinemia show clinical signs of cyanosis due to poor tissue oxygenation. O_2 partial pressure (PaO_2), which reflects the concentration of dissolved oxygen in plasma, is not affected. In patients prone to developing methemoglobinemia (e.g., patients with G6PD deficiency), oxidant drugs such as dapsone and topical anesthetic drugs should be avoided. Treatment consists of converting methemoglobin to hemoglobin by using reducing agents such as methylene blue and vitamin C.

Although prolonged or chronic methemoglobinemia may lead to erythrocytosis or polycythemia, this patient has only been taking her medication for three days.

See “Overview of factors that affect oxygenation” table.

These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with hypoxemia (e.g., due to impaired gas exchange in the lungs). Impaired oxygenation of the blood decreases both the amount of oxygen dissolved in the plasma (↓ PaO_2) and the amount of oxygen bound to hemoglobin (↓ SaO_2). As a result, the total amount of oxygen transported by arterial blood (i.e., O_2 content) will also be reduced. In states of hypoxemia, the hemoglobin concentration is initially unaffected, but may eventually increase due to stimulation of erythropoietin secretion. Hypoxemia can cause signs of cyanosis, which are seen here. However, unlike this patient's blood sample, deoxygenated blood changes color to bright red upon exposure to oxygen.

These arterial blood gas findings are consistent with chronic carbon monoxide poisoning (e.g., from cigarette smoke). Since carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin (Hb) with much higher affinity than oxygen (producing carboxyhemoglobin), it cannot easily be displaced. This results in a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, which impairs oxygen delivery to the tissues. The amount of oxygen bound to Hb (SaO_2) as well as the total arterial O_2 content are reduced, while the amount of dissolved oxygen in the plasma (PaO_2) remains unaffected. Elevated erythropoietin production secondary to chronic hypoxia induces an increase in Hb. Clinical findings of chronic carbon monoxide include dizziness and seizures, neither of which is seen here. Moreover, based on this patient's history, there is no reason to expect prolonged exposure to CO.

question_text: A 65-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He takes no medications. Physical examination and laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Compared to a healthy adolescent, this patient is most likely to have which of the following changes in immune function?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He takes no medications. Physical examination and laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Compared to a healthy adolescent, this patient is most likely to have which of the following changes in immune function?
hint: Age is associated with physiologic changes in certain immune functions, including a decrease in CD4+ T-cell numbers.
learning_objective: Recall the effect of aging on immune response to vaccines.

answers.explanation_why: With increasing age, autoimmunity is increased rather than decreased because the synthesis of T_reg cells decreases and the synthesis of autoantibodies increases.
The phagocytic ability of neutrophils is decreased in older individuals, but the number of circulating neutrophils or neutrophil precursors are not affected by aging.

With advancing age, the ability of the body to mount antibody and cell-mediated immune responses to a new antigen decreases. This is caused by a decline in the counts of most subsets of B cells and T cells. The decreased immune response is also caused by impaired affinity maturation and V(D)J recombination, an increase in the proportion of monoclonal cell lines, and decreased affinity of antibodies for new antigens due to a decrease in the variety of B-cell receptors for antigens. These changes lead to an increased need for booster vaccinations in older adults.

answers.content: Increased number of circulating B cells
answers.explanation_why: The number of circulating B cells as well as the number of B-cell precursors decreases with advanced age because of senescence-related alterations in the microenvironment of the bone marrow and impaired responsiveness to growth-stimulating cytokines.

answers.content: Increased antibody affinity for foreign antigens
answers.explanation_why: The affinity of antibodies for antigens decreases rather than increases with age. This is primarily because of impaired affinity maturation, impaired V(D)J recombination, a decrease in the variety of B-cell receptors, and an increase in the proportion of monoclonal cell lines.
In older individuals, the amount of complement protein produced by the liver is less when compared to younger individuals.

question_text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of painful swelling in his right knee that started after he collided with another player during a soccer game. He has no history of serious illness except for an episode of prolonged bleeding following a tooth extraction a few months ago. Physical examination shows marked tenderness and swelling of the right knee joint. There are multiple bruises on the lower extremities in various stages of healing. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 235,000/mm^3, partial thromboplastin time of 78 seconds, prothrombin time of 14 seconds, and bleeding time of 4 minutes (N = 2–7). Which of the following steps in coagulation is most likely directly affected by this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of painful swelling in his right knee that started after he collided with another player during a soccer game. He has no history of serious illness except for an episode of prolonged bleeding following a tooth extraction a few months ago. Physical examination shows marked tenderness and swelling of the right knee joint. There are multiple bruises on the lower extremities in various stages of healing. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 235,000/mm3, partial thromboplastin time of 78 seconds, prothrombin time of 14 seconds, and bleeding time of 4 minutes (N = 2–7). Which of the following steps in coagulation is most likely directly affected by this patient's condition?
hint: Combined with a history of abnormal bleeding and prolonged PTT, acute hemarthrosis following trauma likely indicates underlying hemophilia.
learning_objective: Recognize hemophilia, and recall the affected coagulation pathway.

answers.explanation_why: Formation of thrombin occurs as a part of the combined pathway as factor Xa and factor Va form a complex that cleaves prothrombin to thrombin. Hemophilia impairs a different part of the coagulation cascade, and once the combined pathway is activated the cascade functions normally. Therefore, the formation of thrombin is not directly affected in this patient.

The degradation of fibrin (i.e., fibrinolysis) is primarily carried out by plasmin. Plasma concentrations of plasmin can be influenced by the administration of thrombolytics (e.g., alteplase, tenecteplase) or antifibrinolytics (e.g., aminocaproic acid, tranexamic acid). A prolonged PTT, as seen in this patient, indicates a defect in coagulation rather than fibrinolysis. Hemophilia does not directly affect the degradation of fibrin.

The conversion of factor X to factor Xa can occur via two mechanisms: a complex formed of factor VIIa and tissue factor (extrinsic pathway), or a complex formed of factor VIIIa and IXa (intrinsic pathway). The extrinsic pathway is unaffected in this patient, as evidenced by the normal PT. However, hemophilia is characterized by a deficiency of factor VIII (hemophilia A) or a deficiency of factor IX (hemophilia B), both of which affect the intrinsic pathway, causing the prolonged PTT seen in this patient. While the conversion of factor X can still occur via the extrinsic pathway, the conversion of factor X by the intrinsic pathway will be impaired. A prolonged PTT with normal PT, bleeding time, and platelet count is typical of hemophilia.

Hemophilia C is due to a deficiency of factor XI but is exceedingly rare.

Von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds to free collagen, factor VIII, and the GP1b surface receptor of platelets to mediate adhesion between platelets and the exposed collagen fibrils of damaged blood vessels during primary hemostasis following injury. Patients with von Willebrand disease have a deficiency of vWF and classically have abnormal bleeding, a prolonged PTT (due to a decreased half-life of unbound factor VIII), and a normal PT and platelet count, as seen in this patient. However, bleeding time would typically also be prolonged, which is not seen here. Furthermore, hemarthrosis is not typical of von Willebrand disease, which usually manifests with epistaxis, gingival bleeding, and/or menorrhagia.

images.title: Congenital disorders affecting primary hemostasis
images.description: Red indicators link syndromes with their associated defective or absent molecules, according to which phase of primary hemostasis is affected (i.e., adhesion or aggregation)

answers.explanation_why: Factor VII is activated by tissue factor via the extrinsic coagulation pathway. Isolated impairment of the extrinsic pathway would manifest with a normal platelet count and bleeding time and could account for hemarthrosis following trauma. However, an increased PT and a normal PTT would also be expected.

question_text: A 30-year-old man with Down syndrome is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of fatigue. Physical examination shows bluish-colored lips and digital clubbing that were not present at his most recent examination. Right heart catheterization shows a right atrial pressure of 32 mmHg. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 30-year-old man with Down syndrome is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of fatigue. Physical examination shows bluish-colored lips and digital clubbing that were not present at his most recent examination. Right heart catheterization shows a right atrial pressure of 32 mmHg. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's current condition?
hint: Congenital heart defects associated with Down syndrome include atrioventricular, ventricular, and atrial septal defects.
learning_objective: Recognize Eisenmenger syndrome, and recall its cardiac complications.

answers.explanation_why: Aortic valve regurgitation is most commonly seen in connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome. Backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle would result in left ventricular hypertrophy and increased left atrial pressure rather than increased right atrial pressure. In addition, aortic valve regurgitation presents with fatigue but not with clubbing and cyanosis. This patient's history of Down syndrome makes a different mechanism more likely.

Pulmonary hypertension is a manifestation of acyanotic heart defects, which are the result of a left-to-right shunt. The increased volume of the shunted blood causes a remodeling of the pulmonary vasculature, leading to pulmonary hypertension. This patient most likely has pulmonary hypertension but this is an irreversible process, not reversible.

Intrapulmonary shunting occurs in situations where parts of the lungs are perfused but not ventilated, resulting in a ventilation-perfusion mismatch. Some common conditions that can cause intrapulmonary shunt include pulmonary AVM, hepatopulmonary syndrome, severe cases of pulmonary edema, and lobar atelectasis. This patient's history of Down syndrome makes an underlying congenital heart defect a more likely cause of his condition, rather than a pulmonary condition.

Central cyanosis, weakness, and clubbing in a patient with a history of Down syndrome are highly suggestive of Eisenmenger syndrome due to a congenital heart defect, most likely an endocardial or atrioventricular cushion defect. Both of these defects initially cause a left-to-right blood shunt (i.e., acyanotic heart defect) due to higher pressures within the left heart. Over time, the increased blood flow within the right heart and the pulmonary vasculature results in permanent remodeling of pulmonary vessels and right ventricular hypertrophy. The right ventricular pressure eventually becomes higher (normal 5–10 mmHg) than the left ventricular pressure, causing a reversal of the shunt and cyanosis.

Asymmetric septal hypertrophy is seen in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), a hereditary condition that can manifest with fatigue and an increased atrial pressure. However, HOCM would not manifest with central cyanosis, digital clubbing, and increased right atrial pressure (the left side is more commonly involved). This patient's history of Down syndrome makes a different etiology more likely.

question_text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion in addition to a 1-month history of ankle swelling. She has a history of sleep apnea. Examination of the lower extremities shows bilateral pitting pedal and ankle edema. Cardiac examination shows a widely split S_2 that varies with respiration. An ECG shows right bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of the patient's lower extremity edema?
content_preview: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion in addition to a 1-month history of ankle swelling. She has a history of sleep apnea. Examination of the lower extremities shows bilateral pitting pedal and ankle edema. Cardiac examination shows a widely split S2 that varies with respiration. An ECG shows right bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of the patient's lower extremity edema?
hint: The patient's symptoms of exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema, and physical exam findings of a widely split S2 and right bundle branch block are consistent with right heart failure caused by pulmonary hypertension (cor pulmonale). Sleep apnea can lead to pulmonary hypertension.
learning_objective: Recognize right heart failure, and recall the pathophysiology of edema formation.

answers.explanation_why: Patients who have undergone lymph node removal, radiation therapy, or have a history of cancer are at risk for edema caused by lymphatic obstruction (i.e., lymphedema). However, lymphedema would not explain the shortness of breath seen in this patient. Her edema, shortness of breath, and physical examination findings are instead related to heart failure.

Myxedema, a specific type of edema that manifests in a small portion of patients with Graves disease or severe hypothyroidism, is caused by the dermal accumulation of glycosaminoglycans. Although this patient's edema is in the lower extremities, which is similar to myxedema, she has no signs of thyroid dysfunction (e.g., temperature intolerance, weight changes, constipation/diarrhea).

answers.content: Thrombus formation in a deep vein
answers.explanation_why: Deep venous thrombosis can cause decreased venous drainage and edema in the affected extremity. However, this woman's bilateral lower extremity edema would have to be caused by bilateral thromboses, which is very rare.
answers.explanation_but: The formation of a pulmonary embolism from a DVT could also cause shortness of breath, although the presentation is typically acuter than seen in this patient.

answers.explanation_why: Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure occurs in right-sided heart failure in which reduced right ventricular output leads to systemic venous congestion. Venous congestion increases the capillary hydrostatic pressure, altering the physiological Starling forces to cause fluid leakage into the interstitium and edema. Reduced cardiac output also activates RAAS, leading to a second mechanism for edema formation in patients with congestive heart failure: renal sodium and water retention.

Decreased plasma oncotic pressure is seen in patients with conditions that cause low levels of plasma proteins, especially albumin (e.g., liver failure, nephrotic syndrome). Low levels of protein in the blood alter the physiological Starling forces to cause fluid leakage out of capillaries, resulting in generalized peripheral edema. This patient's right heart failure has no effect on total protein levels in the bloodstream and therefore has no effect on oncotic pressure.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, lower extremity swelling, and a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain. Crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched early diastolic sound at the 5^th left intercostal space that becomes louder in the left lateral decubitus position at end-expiration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these auscultation findings?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, lower extremity swelling, and a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain. Crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. Cardiac examination shows a dull, low-pitched early diastolic sound at the 5th left intercostal space that becomes louder in the left lateral decubitus position at end-expiration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these auscultation findings?
hint: The patient presents with clinical features of heart failure (shortness of breath, crackles, lower extremity swelling, weight gain); the early diastolic heart sound is S_3, a strong predictor for heart failure.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features of heart failure, and recall the cause of a third heart sound (S3).

answers.explanation_why: Decreased myocardial compliance is the cause of the S_4 gallop, which is an important sign of heart failure with diastolic dysfunction or other conditions with reduced myocardial compliance (e.g., active ischemia, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy). However, in contrast to the auscultation findings in this patient, S_4 gallop is a late diastolic sound.

Heart failure due to systolic dysfunction is due to decreased, not increased, ventricular contractility. Increased ventricular contractility can be seen after myocardial hypertrophy and is a sign of a well-functioning heart.

Increased left ventricular end-systolic volume is the most likely cause of this patient's third heart sound (S_3). In heart failure with systolic dysfunction, the myocardium cannot effectively contract to empty during systole, resulting in ventricular volume overload. During the rapid ventricular filling phase, a sudden deceleration of blood occurs when the ventricle reaches its elastic limit, producing a third heart sound.

images.title: Anatomical locations and auscultatory sites for heart valves
images.description:
I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves1. Aortic area: 2^nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).2. Pulmonary area: 2^nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs3. Tricuspid area: 4^th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs4. Mitral area: 5^th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

answers.explanation_why: The left ventricular filling pressure would be decreased in a patient with hypovolemia. In this patient with features of heart failure, LV filling pressure would be increased.

answers.content: Increased capacity of the pulmonary circulation
answers.explanation_why: An increase in the capacity of the pulmonary circulation occurs during inspiration as a result of a decrease in intrathoracic pressure. This results in a split S_2 due to early closure of the aortic valve (A_2) and delayed closure of the pulmonary valve (P_2). However, it does not result in an S_3_, nor is it related to heart failure.

question_text: A 38-year-old woman undergoes hemithyroidectomy for treatment of localized, well-differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma. The lesion is removed with clear margins. However, during the surgery, a structure lying directly adjacent to the superior thyroid artery at the upper pole of the thyroid lobe is damaged. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following symptoms?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman undergoes hemithyroidectomy for treatment of localized, well-differentiated papillary thyroid carcinoma. The lesion is removed with clear margins. However, during the surgery, a structure lying directly adjacent to the superior thyroid artery at the upper pole of the thyroid lobe is damaged. This patient is most likely to experience which of the following symptoms?
hint: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve lies directly adjacent to the superior thyroid artery at the upper pole of the thyroid lobe. If the artery is ligated during surgery, it may be damaged.
learning_objective: Recall the anatomy and function of the superior laryngeal nerve.

answers.explanation_why: Voice pitch limitation is caused by damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN), which occurs in up to 30% of thyroid dissections. The external branch of the SLN innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for lengthening, thinning, and stiffening the vocal cords and increases the pitch of phonation. The cricothyroid muscle is the only tensor of the vocal cord, and its denervation results in an inability to increase the pitch of the voice or produce explosive sounds as well as easy voice fatigability.

images.title: Thyroid gland and surrounding structures
images.description: The thyroid gland is located in front of the trachea in the lower neck and consists of two lobes connected by an isthmus. A third pyramidal lobe extending from the isthmus is present in 50% of patients. This third lobe is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.The parathyroid glands are located posterior to the thyroid gland; they may vary in number and location. The recurrent laryngeal nerves (RLN) branch off from the vagus nerve; the left RLN loops under the aortic arch, and the right RLN passes beneath the subclavian artery. Both RLNs are vulnerable to injury during thyroid surgery as they ascend to the larynx behind the thyroid gland. Unilateral RLN injury may result in hoarseness, and bilateral RLN injury may cause dyspnea and stridor.

answers.explanation_why: Perioral paresthesia after thyroid surgery is a result of hypocalcemia secondary to hypoparathyroidism, usually due to unintentional removal of one or several of the parathyroid glands. Hypoparathyroidism is the most frequent complication of total or near-total thyroidectomy. However, the superior parathyroid glands are most commonly found inferior to the superior thyroid artery and the external branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve and are thus less likely to be injured in this patient.

Ineffective cough could result from unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury. This causes the affected vocal fold to rest in the paramedian or lateralized position. Coughing, which requires transient tight glottic closure, may then become ineffective. While unilateral RLN injury can occur during thyroid surgery, the nerve is unlikely to be damaged during ligation of the superior thyroid artery. Instead, the RLN is at risk during preparation of the inferior pole of the thyroid gland, as it runs close to the inferior thyroid artery.

Weakness of shoulder shrug can occur due to spinal accessory nerve injury (cranial nerve XI). The spinal accessory nerve runs through the posterior triangle of the neck and supplies the trapezius muscle, which is responsible for shoulder shrugging. However, injury to the spinal accessory nerve would not be expected during a hemithyroidectomy. The most common causes of spinal accessory nerve injury include biopsy of the cervical lymph nodes in the posterior triangle and radical neck dissection.

Difficulty swallowing and increased risk of aspiration can occur in bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle. It also carries sensory input from the larynx below the vocal cords. The RLN can be injured during thyroid surgery because it passes close to the inferior thyroid artery on its ascent to the larynx. Unilateral damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is unlikely to cause difficulty swallowing.

Shortness of breath may be caused by bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which can be injured during thyroid surgery because it passes lateral to the thyroid gland, adjacent to the inferior thyroid artery, on its ascent to the larynx. The RLN innervates the posterior cricoarytenoids, which are responsible for vocal cord abduction. In cases of bilateral RLN injury, the vocal cords are unable to abduct, which restricts air entry into the trachea and can lead to shortness of breath. Unilateral damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is unlikely to cause shortness of breath.

question_text:
A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, recurrent diarrhea, and an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has a 4-month history of recurrent blistering rashes on different parts of his body that grow and develop into pruritic, crusty lesions before resolving spontaneously. Physical examination shows scaly lesions in different phases of healing with central, bronze-colored induration around the mouth, perineum, and lower extremities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
10.1 g/dL

Mean corpuscular volume
85 μm^3

Mean corpuscular hemoglobin
30.0 pg/cell

Serum

Glucose
236 mg/dL

Abdominal ultrasonography shows a 3-cm, solid mass located in the upper abdomen. This patient's mass is most likely derived from which of the following types of cells?
content_preview: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, recurrent diarrhea, and an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. He has a 4-month history of recurrent blistering rashes on different parts of his body that grow and develop into pruritic, crusty lesions before resolving spontaneously. Physical examination shows scaly lesions in different phases of healing with central, bronze-colored induration around the mouth, perineum, and lower extremities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume 85 μm3 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin 30.0 pg/cell Serum Glucose 236 mg/dL Abdominal ultrasonography shows a 3-cm, solid mass located in the upper abdomen. This patient's mass is most likely derived from which of the following types of cells?
hint: This patient's rash, known as necrolytic migratory erythema, is strongly associated with his underlying tumor.
learning_objective: Recognize a glucagonoma, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: Carcinoid tumors, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from enterochromaffin cells, produce serotonin and can manifest with weight loss and recurrent diarrhea. These tumors are associated with skin lesions caused by niacin deficiency (e.g., casal necklace), but they are not associated with necrolytic migratory erythema. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of a carcinoid tumor, including flushing and wheezing.

images.title: Pellagra
images.description: There are symmetrical, hyperpigmented, hyperkeratotic plaques on sun-exposed areas of the chest (Casal necklace), shoulders, face, hands, and arms.This is the typical dermatological manifestation of pellagra. Dermatitis is one of the “4 D's of pellagra” alongside diarrhea, dementia, and death.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient has a glucagonoma, a functional neuroendocrine tumor derived from pancreatic α-cells. These tumors secrete glucagon, which increases gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis and thus results in hyperglycemia. Other features of glucagonoma include chronic diarrhea, weight loss, neuropsychiatric symptoms (e.g., depression, dementia, ataxia), deep vein thrombosis, normocytic anemia (due to anemia of chronic disease and the inhibitory effect of glucagon on erythropoiesis), and necrolytic migratory erythema. The pathophysiology that underlies the development of necrolytic migratory erythema is not well understood, but it may be related to direct action of glucagon on the skin, protein deficiency (because glucagon causes proteolysis), and/or a deficiency of zinc and fatty acids due to chronic diarrhea.

See “Overview of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors” table.

images.title: Necrolytic migratory erythema
images.description: Feet of a patient with pancreatic glucagonomaAn annular erythema consisting of ring-shaped, linear, bronze-colored areas as well as red patches is visible. The surface of the erythema crusts and has formed macules and erosions.These lesions are suggestive of necrolytic migratory erythema associated with pancreatic glucagonoma. They can be differentiated from acrodermatitis enteropathica by the measurement of plasma zinc levels.

answers.explanation_why: Insulinomas, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from pancreatic β-cells, produce insulin and manifest with weight gain (not weight loss) and hypoglycemia (not hyperglycemia). Moreover, they are not associated with necrolytic migratory erythema.

Somatostatinomas, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from pancreatic δ-cells, secrete somatostatin and can manifest with weight loss and glucose intolerance. However, these tumors are not associated with necrolytic migratory erythema. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of a somatostatinoma, including abdominal pain, steatorrhea, and cholelithiasis.

Gastrinomas, which are functional neuroendocrine tumors derived from gastric G-cells, secrete gastrin and can manifest with weight loss and recurrent diarrhea. However, these tumors are not associated with hyperglycemia or necrolytic migratory erythema. In addition, this patient lacks other typical manifestations of a gastrinoma, including abdominal pain and dyspepsia.

question_text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, difficulty falling asleep, and night sweats for the past 6 months. Over the past year, her menstrual cycle has become irregular and her last menstrual period was 2 months ago. She quit smoking 2 years ago. Pelvic exam shows vulvovaginal atrophy. A pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following changes is most likely to occur in this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, difficulty falling asleep, and night sweats for the past 6 months. Over the past year, her menstrual cycle has become irregular and her last menstrual period was 2 months ago. She quit smoking 2 years ago. Pelvic exam shows vulvovaginal atrophy. A pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following changes is most likely to occur in this patient's condition?
hint: This 47-year-old patient presents with irregular menses, night sweats, insomnia, and vulvovaginal atrophy, which are all signs and symptoms of menopause. The median age at onset of menopause in the United States is 51, but smoking is associated with earlier onset of symptoms.
learning_objective: Recognize the signs and symptoms of menopause, and recall the hormonal changes associated with it.

answers.explanation_why: An increase in luteinizing hormone (LH) would be seen during menopause rather than a decrease. Ovarian failure leads to a decrease in the circulating levels of estrogen and progesterone, resulting in a decrease in negative feedback to the hypothalamus, and a subsequent increase in LH.

Estrogen levels often fluctuate during perimenopause but are more likely to be decreased, not increased, due to declining ovarian function. At menopause, ovarian production of estrogen ceases completely due to ovarian failure. After menopause, the majority of estrogen is derived from the peripheral conversion of testosterone via aromatase. Obese patients may have milder symptoms, as adipose tissue contains higher concentrations of aromatase.

Inhibin B is secreted by ovarian granulosa cells. Levels of Inhibin B decrease during perimenopause, reflecting a decline in ovarian function, disappearing altogether shortly before menopause. Therefore, decreased, not increased, levels of inhibin B would be expected in this patient.

Testosterone levels during menopause are typically normal not increased. Increased testosterone can be a cause of anovulation and amenorrhea in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), but this patient has no signs of hirsutism or an adnexal mass on pelvic exam, making PCOS an unlikely diagnosis.

An increase rather than a decrease in gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) would be seen during menopause because menopause disrupts the pituitary-hypothalamic feedback mechanism. Low GnRH levels are seen, e.g., in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, which may be congenital (Kallmann syndrome) or seen in secondary amenorrhea (excessive exercise, stress, reduced caloric intake etc.).

Increased levels of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) are most likely to be seen in this patient. Menopause is usually preceded by the climacteric period, in which the menstrual cycles become increasingly irregular before amenorrhea begins. Ovarian failure leads to a decrease in the circulating levels of estrogen and progesterone, resulting in a decrease in negative feedback to the hypothalamus. This results in an increase in GnRH levels and subsequent increase in FSH.

Due to the wide variability of FSH levels in women, it is no longer routinely tested to diagnose menopause, which is instead determined on a clinical basis.

question_text:
A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after being found unconscious on the street. On arrival, he is unresponsive to painful stimuli. His respirations are 5/min and shallow. Physical examination shows pinpoint pupils. Which of the following sets of findings would be expected on arterial blood analysis?

pH
PCO_2 (mm Hg)
HCO_3^- (mEq/L)

A
7.29
71
33

B
7.52
51
40

C
7.21
64
25

D
7.53
31
25

E
7.26
36
16
content_preview: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after being found unconscious on the street. On arrival, he is unresponsive to painful stimuli. His respirations are 5/min and shallow. Physical examination shows pinpoint pupils. Which of the following sets of findings would be expected on arterial blood analysis? pH PCO2 (mm Hg) HCO3- (mEq/L) A 7.29 71 33 B 7.52 51 40 C 7.21 64 25 D 7.53 31 25 E 7.26 36 16
hint: This patient's presentation of decreased respiratory effort, constricted pupils, and unresponsiveness is consistent with opioid overdose.
learning_objective: Recognize opioid overdose, and recall its arterial blood gas findings.

answers.explanation_why:
Decreased pH and increased pCO_2 suggest a primary respiratory acidosis. The measured HCO_3^- (33 mEq/L) is consistent with a secondary metabolic alkalosis in the setting of primary acute respiratory acidosis because the measured HCO_3^- is more than what would be expected for acute respiratory acidosis (24 + [0.1 x (pCO_2  in mm Hg - 40)] +/- 3 = 24–30 mEq/L). Although this patient's presentation is consistent with acute respiratory acidosis due to an opioid overdose, there is, however, no history to suggest an additional metabolic alkalosis (e.g., diuretic use, severe vomiting).

The measured HCO_3^- is within the range of the expected HCO_3^- for a single chronic respiratory acidosis (24 + [0.4 x (pCO_2  in mm Hg - 40)] +/- 3 = 33–39 mEq/L) but the acute nature of an opioid overdose makes chronic respiratory acidosis unlikely.

This ABG analysis is consistent with primary metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation. Increased pH indicates alkalosis, while the increased bicarbonate (HCO_3^-) suggests a metabolic source (e.g., vomiting, nasogastric suction, diuretic use). Appropriate respiratory compensation via hypoventilation results in an elevated pCO_2. Although this patient presents with hypoventilation, there is no history to suggest a primary metabolic derangement.

This ABG analysis suggests acute respiratory acidosis, which is seen in an opioid overdose as a result of hypoventilation. Decreased pH indicates acidosis, increased pCO_2 suggests a respiratory source and, due to the acute nature of an opioid overdose, only minimal metabolic compensation from the rapid action of buffers in blood would be expected. In acute respiratory acidosis, for every 10 mm Hg increase in pCO_2 above 40 mm Hg, the HCO_3^- concentration increases by 1 mEq/L from 24 mEq/L with an expected variability of +/- 3 mEq/L. A slow-onset but more substantial compensation occurs as a result of renal acid-base handling in chronic respiratory acid-base disorders.

Differential diagnoses for acute respiratory acidosis in the emergency department setting include airway obstruction (e.g., foreign body aspiration, acute exacerbations of obstructive lung diseases), neuromuscular etiologies (e.g., Guillain-Barré syndrome, myasthenic crisis, botulism), and overdoses with other drugs that can cause CNS depression (e.g., benzodiazepines).

images.title: Acid-base nomogram
images.description: This nomogram can be used for the interpretation of an arterial blood gas analysis in the context of acid-base disorders.PCO_2 is on the x-axis and the concentration of HCO_3^- (cHCO_3^-) is on the y-axis; both are displayed logarithmically, allowing the pH to be displayed on parallel straight lines. The important areas for acid-base disorders are highlighted and labeled. The oval area in the middle around PCO_2 = 40 mm Hg and cHCO_3^- = 24 mEq/L represents the reference range.

answers.explanation_why: This ABG analysis is consistent with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis. Increased pH indicates alkalosis, while the decreased pCO_2 suggests a respiratory source (e.g., hyperventilation during a panic attack or in early salicylate overdose). Normal bicarbonate (HCO_3^-) indicates an acute scenario with negligent metabolic compensation. Although this patient does present with respiratory abnormality, his shallow respirations at 5/min indicate hypoventilation, as opposed to hyperventilation.

This ABG analysis suggests a combined metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis, which can occur in cardiopulmonary arrest. Decreased pH indicates acidosis, while reduced bicarbonate (HCO_3^-) suggests a metabolic source. This pCO_2 is higher than would be expected with respiratory compensation (by Winter formula), and therefore a primary respiratory acidosis is also expected. Although respiratory derangements would be expected as a result of this patient's opioid overdose, metabolic acid-base changes would be unlikely.

question_text:
A 54-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sharp chest pain and shortness of breath for 1 day. She has been coughing intermittently, which worsens the pain. She has osteoporosis, for which she takes raloxifene. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.52

PCO_2

25 mm Hg

PO_2

65 mm Hg

O_2 saturation
92%

Physical examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 54-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of sharp chest pain and shortness of breath for 1 day. She has been coughing intermittently, which worsens the pain. She has osteoporosis, for which she takes raloxifene. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.52 PCO2 25 mm Hg PO2 65 mm Hg O2 saturation 92% Physical examination is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Arterial blood gas analysis shows hypoxemia and respiratory alkalosis, probably due to hyperventilation in the setting of hypoxemia.
learning_objective: Recognize the presentation of pulmonary embolism, and recall its common cause and associated risk factors.

answers.explanation_why: Physical examination is most likely to show unilateral leg swelling, indicating deep vein thrombosis (DVT). DVT is the most common cause of pulmonary embolism (PE), which typically presents with sharp chest pain and shortness of breath, as seen here. In PE, occlusion of one or more of the pulmonary arteries leads to a ventilation-perfusion mismatch, which results in an increased A-a gradient and hypoxemia. In turn, hypoxemia leads to hyperventilation and subsequent respiratory alkalosis (due to low PCO_2 levels). Certain medications including raloxifene increase the risk of DVT and PE.

images.title: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
images.description: There is diffuse edema and erythema of the right leg and foot. The diameter of the right calf is visibly greater than that of the left.These features are typical of DVT. Clinical history and investigations (e.g., Doppler ultrasonography, D-dimer levels) help distinguish between DVT and cellulitis, which also manifests with a painful, warm, erythematous, and edematous leg.

answers.content: Increased anteroposterior diameter of the thorax
answers.explanation_why: Increased anteroposterior diameter of the thorax (i.e., barrel chest) is typically seen in advanced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to air trapping and emphysema. COPD causes respiratory acidosis due to CO_2 retention, not respiratory alkalosis.

images.title: Emphysema with barrel chest
images.description: X-ray chest (lateral view)The retrosternal air space is enlarged (green overlay), with widening of the anterior-posterior diameter of the thorax (barrel chest). The hemidiaphragms are flattened (indicated by yellow lines) in contrast to a normally arched configuration (example indicated by white dashed line).The findings indicate marked hyperinflation of the lungs from air trapping.AA: aortic arch; CS: cardiac silhouette; LPA: left pulmonary artery

answers.content: Grouped vesicles on the right hemithorax
answers.explanation_why: Grouped vesicles on the right hemithorax can be seen in patients with herpes zoster, which typically presents with sharp chest pain. However, herpes zoster would not explain this patient's shortness of breath, intermittent cough, and arterial blood gas changes.
Pericardial friction rub is a sign of pericarditis, which can present with sharp chest pain. However, pericarditis is unlikely to cause arterial blood gas changes.

An absent left radial pulse can be seen in cases of aortic dissection proximal to the subclavian artery. Aortic dissection classically presents with sudden, severe chest or back pain. This condition can lead to hypoperfusion and, subsequently, tissue hypoxia. Tissue hypoxia results in lactic acidosis, which causes metabolic acidosis (pH < 7.35), not respiratory alkalosis.

Increased tactile fremitus indicates consolidation (e.g., due to lobar pneumonia), which can cause hypoxemia, as seen in this patient. However, pneumonia is more likely to cause respiratory acidosis (rather than alkalosis) due to inadequate alveolar ventilation, as alveoli are filled with inflammatory exudate.

question_text: A 57-year-old man has worsening suprapubic discomfort 36 hours after undergoing a hemorrhoidectomy under spinal anesthesia. He reports that he has not urinated since the procedure. Examination shows a palpable bladder 4 cm above the symphysis pubis. He is treated with a drug that directly increases detrusor muscle tone. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following adverse effects of his treatment?
content_preview: A 57-year-old man has worsening suprapubic discomfort 36 hours after undergoing a hemorrhoidectomy under spinal anesthesia. He reports that he has not urinated since the procedure. Examination shows a palpable bladder 4 cm above the symphysis pubis. He is treated with a drug that directly increases detrusor muscle tone. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following adverse effects of his treatment?
hint: This patient likely received bethanechol, a direct muscarinic agonist commonly given for postoperative or postpartum urinary retention.
learning_objective: Recall the adverse effects of direct muscarinic agonists.

answers.explanation_why:
Bethanechol is a direct parasympathomimetic that binds to muscarinic receptors, increasing detrusor muscle tone to cause contractions that initiate urination. Although sweat glands are primarily innervated by the sympathetic nervous system, they have muscarinic receptors and are therefore activated by acetylcholine, unlike all other sympathetic pathways. Due to the cholinergic activity of bethanechol, diaphoresis is the most likely adverse effect in this patient.

Postoperative urinary retention commonly occurs after surgeries (especially anorectal surgeries involving spinal anesthesia).

Dry mouth is caused by administration of anticholinergic agents, which decrease the activity of salivary glands. Since the cholinergic activity of bethanechol stimulates the salivary glands, increased salivation would be expected.

Muscle spasms can be caused by cholinergic drugs that activate nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the skeletal neuromuscular junction (e.g., transient fasciculations after administration of succinylcholine). Although bethanechol is a cholinergic agent, it acts only on muscarinic receptors and will not cause muscle spasms.

Tachycardia can be caused by administration of anticholinergic agents, which increase the contractility of the atria and the conduction velocity of the AV node. However, bethanechol increases cholinergic activity, more likely causing bradycardia.

Constipation can be caused by anticholinergic agents, which slow down the gastrointestinal tract. Bethanechol stimulates muscarinic receptors in the GI tract and restores peristalsis, potentially causing diarrhea due to the sudden increase in motility.
answers.explanation_but: Bethanechol is commonly administered in patients with postoperative ileus for increasing bowel movements.

answers.explanation_why: Mydriasis can be caused by anticholinergic agents such as atropine, which inhibit contraction of the pupillary sphincter muscles. The parasympathetic action of bethanechol on the eye causes miosis.

question_text:
A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of nausea, abdominal pain, and confusion. She has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease treated with over-the-counter calcium carbonate antacids. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is metformin. Her pulse is 86/min and blood pressure is 142/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft abdomen. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: 

pH
7.46

PCO_2

44 mm Hg

PO_2

94 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

30 mEq/L

An ECG shows a QT interval corrected for heart rate (QTc) of 0.36 seconds (N = 0.40–0.44). The serum concentration of which of the following substances is most likely to be increased in this patient?
content_preview: A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of nausea, abdominal pain, and confusion. She has a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease treated with over-the-counter calcium carbonate antacids. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her only medication is metformin. Her pulse is 86/min and blood pressure is 142/85 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft abdomen. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.46 PCO2 44 mm Hg PO2 94 mm Hg HCO3- 30 mEq/L An ECG shows a QT interval corrected for heart rate (QTc) of 0.36 seconds (N = 0.40–0.44). The serum concentration of which of the following substances is most likely to be increased in this patient?
hint: The constellation of nausea, abdominal pain, confusion, and shortened QT interval suggests hypercalcemia. Hypercalcemia with metabolic alkalosis on arterial blood gas analysis indicates milk-alkali syndrome, which is typically caused by the prolonged intake of calcium carbonate antacids.
learning_objective: Recognize milk-alkali syndrome, and recall the associated serum substance change.

answers.explanation_why: Parathyroid hormone (PTH), which is secreted by the parathyroid glands in response to a drop in serum calcium levels, increases serum calcium by stimulating the reabsorption of calcium from the renal distal tubules, the production of calcitriol in the kidneys, and the release of calcium from bone. Hypercalcemia (e.g., due to milk-alkali syndrome) inhibits PTH secretion, which is why PTH levels would most likely be decreased (not increased) in this patient. Hypercalcemia in combination with increased PTH levels is seen in primary hyperparathyroidism (e.g., due to parathyroid gland adenomas).

Thyroid-stimulating hormone levels are decreased in hyperthyroidism. Hyperthyroidism can cause hypercalcemia through the activation of osteoclasts, which results in the release of calcium from the bones. Confusion and elevated blood pressure can also be seen in hyperthyroidism. However, this patient lacks typical features of hyperthyroidism, including tachycardia, palpitations, heat intolerance, fine tremor, and weight loss.

β-hydroxybutyrate is a ketone body produced by the liver and used by peripheral tissues (e.g., heart, brain, skeletal muscle) as an energy source when glucose is not readily available (states of ketogenesis, e.g., during prolonged starvation, in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), or chronic heavy drinking). There is no history of starvation or alcohol use in this patient. DKA is seen primarily in patients with type I diabetes mellitus, as opposed to type II diabetes mellitus. Although clinical findings of DKA include nausea, abdominal pain, and confusion, which are present here, it typically results in metabolic acidosis rather than metabolic alkalosis.

Phosphate homeostasis is a complex process that is regulated by various hormones (e.g., parathyroid hormone, vitamin D). Hypercalcemia due to milk-alkali syndrome is typically associated with decreased, not increased levels of phosphate. The decreased phosphate levels result from prolonged ingestion of calcium carbonate without the simultaneous ingestion of phosphate. Calcium carbonate binds to phosphate, lowering phosphate serum levels.

Calcium homeostasis is a complex process that is regulated by various hormones (e.g., parathyroid hormone, vitamin D, calcitonin). A mechanism that occurs in response to hypercalcemia (e.g., due to milk-alkali syndrome) is increased renal conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 24,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, an inactive intermediate in vitamin D metabolism; in addition, there is decreased conversion of 25-hydroxycholecalciferol to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol (calcitriol), the most active form of vitamin D. Since calcitriol normally increases serum calcium concentrations (via effects on the gastrointestinal tract and the kidneys), decreased formation of calcitriol results in a reduction in serum calcium concentrations.

question_text: A 25-year old man comes to the physician because of fatigue over the past 6 months. He has been to the emergency room several times over the past 3 years for recurrent shoulder and patella dislocations. Physical examination shows abnormal joint hypermobility and skin hyperextensibility. A high-frequency mid-systolic click is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is most likely to result in an earlier onset of this patient’s auscultation finding?
content_preview: A 25-year old man comes to the physician because of fatigue over the past 6 months. He has been to the emergency room several times over the past 3 years for recurrent shoulder and patella dislocations. Physical examination shows abnormal joint hypermobility and skin hyperextensibility. A high-frequency mid-systolic click is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is most likely to result in an earlier onset of this patient’s auscultation finding?
hint: This patient most likely has Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which can manifest with joint hypermobility (predisposing to joint dislocations) and hyperextensible skin. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is associated with mitral valve prolapse (MVP), a structural defect of the mitral valves due to myxomatous degeneration that leads to the bulging of the leaflets into the left atrium during systole.
learning_objective: Recognize mitral valve prolapse, and recall its auscultatory findings.

answers.explanation_why: The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased afterload and subsequent increased left ventricular end-systolic volume during hand grip (hand clenching) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

The characteristic auscultatory finding of MVP is a high-frequency mid-systolic click, which is caused by sudden tensing of the chordae tendineae as the valve leaflets prolapse. The click may be followed by a mid-to-late systolic murmur indicating mitral regurgitation. Since the prolapse occurs when the contracting ventricle reaches a critical volume, the timing of the click varies according to the left ventricular end-diastolic volume (EDV). Decreased EDV, e.g., due to decreased venous return to the heart during abrupt standing (i.e., decreased preload) causes the leaflets to prolapse sooner, resulting in an earlier onset (i.e., closer to S1) and increased intensity of auscultatory findings. Conversely, maneuvers that increase the volume (e.g., squatting) result in a later onset and decreased intensity.

images.title: Heart murmur in mitral valve prolapse
images.description: High-frequency, mid-systolic click with a late systolic crescendo murmur.

answers.explanation_why: The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased venous return to the heart during rapid squatting (i.e., increased preload) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

The characteristic click heard on auscultation in patients with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) results from the bulging of the valve leaflets into the atrium, which begins when the contracting left ventricle reaches a critical volume during systole. An increased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, e.g., due to increased venous return to the heart during the release phase of the Valsalva maneuver (i.e., increased preload) delays the point when that volume is reached and results in a later onset of the auscultatory findings.

Leaning forward brings the heart closer to the chest, but it has no significant impact on preload or afterload, so it does not affect the timing of the murmur of mitral valve prolapse. However, a pericardial friction rub and the murmur of aortic regurgitation are best heard with the patient leaning forward.

question_text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 12-hour history of severe shortness of breath and worsening of her chronic cough. The cough is productive of large quantities of sputum. She has hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years. Current medications include tiotropium, albuterol, and hydrochlorothiazide. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 146/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Examination shows perioral cyanosis and subcostal retractions. Expiratory wheezes are heard over both lung fields. The patient is given albuterol and intravenous methylprednisolone and receives 100% oxygen at 10 L/min via face mask. Eight hours later, she becomes somnolent and nonresponsive. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's somnolence?
content_preview: A 68-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 12-hour history of severe shortness of breath and worsening of her chronic cough. The cough is productive of large quantities of sputum. She has hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years. Current medications include tiotropium, albuterol, and hydrochlorothiazide. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 146/95 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Examination shows perioral cyanosis and subcostal retractions. Expiratory wheezes are heard over both lung fields. The patient is given albuterol and intravenous methylprednisolone and receives 100% oxygen at 10 L/min via face mask. Eight hours later, she becomes somnolent and nonresponsive. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's somnolence?
hint: In a patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), worsening of chronic cough, increased sputum volume, and wheezing on lung examination indicate an acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD). Excessive supplemental oxygen can worsen ventilation-perfusion mismatch in COPD.
learning_objective: Recognize acute exacerbation of COPD, and recall the effects of excessive supplemental oxygen.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased cerebral blood flow is seen in patients with hypocapnia (e.g., in hyperventilation) due to cerebral vasoconstriction. Hypocapnia can manifest with neurological impairment (e.g., dizziness, confusion, visual disturbances), but somnolence is not typical. By contrast, hypercapnia is likely to occur in COPD, which would cause increased rather than decreased cerebral blood flow as a result of cerebral vasodilation.

Increased pulmonary vasoconstriction occurs as a result of hypoxemia (hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction) to improve an existing ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch and would, therefore, also improve symptoms of AECOPD. This patient, however, has hyperoxemia from excessive supplemental oxygen, which has caused vasodilation of capillaries in poorly ventilated alveoli and worsened both the V/Q mismatch and clinical presentation.

Decreased serum HCO_3^- concentration is seen in metabolic acidosis (e.g., due to renal insufficiency, lactic acidosis, or gastrointestinal loss of HCO_3^‑) and as a compensatory change in respiratory alkalosis (e.g., pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, pain, anxiety). However, patients with AECOPD typically present with respiratory acidosis secondary to retained CO_2. A compensatory rise in serum HCO_3^-  rather than a decrease would, therefore, be expected.

Increased arterial pCO_2 due to excessive supplemental oxygen is the most likely explanation for this patient's somnolence. Oxygen therapy in patients with chronically impaired oxygenation from COPD should be titrated to a saturation of 88–92% to avoid oxygen-induced hypercapnia and CO_2 narcosis, which is seen here. Alveolar hyperoxia inhibits hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction, leading to increased perfusion of poorly ventilated alveoli (i.e., worsening ventilation-perfusion mismatch). The resulting increased dead space ventilation is thought to be the major contributor to acute hypercapnia. In addition, accumulating oxyhemoglobin facilitates CO_2 release from RBCs (Haldane effect). Contrary to prior belief, reduced hypoxic respiratory drive is only responsible for a small increase of pCO_2.

The affinity of hemoglobin for CO_2 is increased in the peripheral tissue, where hemoglobin is deoxygenated. This effect facilitates the uptake and transport of CO_2 from the periphery to the lungs. However, this patient is receiving 100% oxygen at 10 L/min via face mask, which results in a high PaO_2 and a high fraction of oxygenated blood. As the CO_2 affinity to hemoglobin is inversely proportional to the oxygenation of hemoglobin (i.e., Haldane effect), a decrease in CO_2 affinity of hemoglobin would be expected in this patient.

question_text: A previously healthy 36-year-old man comes to the physician for a yellow discoloration of his skin and dark-colored urine for 2 weeks. He does not drink any alcohol. Physical examination shows jaundice. Abdominal and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. Serum studies show increased levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). A liver biopsy is performed and a photomicrograph after periodic acid-Schiff-staining is shown. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
content_preview: A previously healthy 36-year-old man comes to the physician for a yellow discoloration of his skin and dark-colored urine for 2 weeks. He does not drink any alcohol. Physical examination shows jaundice. Abdominal and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. Serum studies show increased levels of alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST). A liver biopsy is performed and a photomicrograph after periodic acid-Schiff-staining is shown. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
hint: This patient's elevated transaminases and signs of hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice, darkened urine) indicate liver damage. His biopsy findings of PAS-positive, spherical, inclusion bodies in hepatocytes confirm α1-antitrypsin deficiency (AAT deficiency) as the most likely underlying cause.
learning_objective: Recognize α1-antitrypsin deficiency, and recall its pulmonary complications.

answers.explanation_why: Tropheryma whipplei-specific RNA on PCR is diagnostic for Whipple disease, an intestinal disorder caused by infection with the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. Whipple disease typically manifests as a malabsorptive syndrome with abdominal pain, extraintestinal symptoms (e.g., arthritis, fever, polyserositis), and PAS-positive macrophages on intestinal biopsy. However, signs of hepatic damage and PAS-positive inclusion bodies as seen in this patient would not be expected.

images.title: Whipple disease
images.description: Photomicrograph of duodenal tissue (H&E stain)There are goblet cells (colorless cells; examples indicated by green overlays) within the columnar epithelial cells and immune cells (examples indicated by black arrowheads) within the lamina propria. There are numerous macrophages (single and in loose aggregates) within the lamina propria, causing blunting of the villi.These findings are characteristic of Whipple disease.

answers.content: Bullous changes of the lung bases on chest CT
answers.explanation_why: Bullous changes of the lung bases on chest CT scan is a typical finding of emphysema, a sequela of AAT deficiency. AAT deficiency is an autosomal codominant disorder associated with liver damage and panacinar emphysema secondary to the proteolytic destruction of alveolar architecture by the enzyme elastase. Hepatic accumulation of AAT presents as PAS-positive, spherical, inclusion bodies on liver biopsy.

answers.content: Beading of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts on ERCP
answers.explanation_why: Beading of intra- and extrahepatic bile ducts on ERCP is a diagnostic feature of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC typically presents in middle-aged men with early signs of cholestasis (e.g., jaundice, pruritus, fatigue) and liver damage as seen in this patient. However, "onion skin" scarring and fibrosis of bile ducts on liver biopsy, rather than PAS-positive inclusion bodies, would be expected. In addition, PSC is usually associated with other autoimmune diseases, especially ulcerative colitis (UC). This patient shows no signs of UC such as bloody stool or abdominal pain.

answers.content: Myocardial iron deposition on cardiovascular MRI
answers.explanation_why: Myocardial iron deposition on cardiovascular MRI is found in hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis is mostly asymptomatic but usually becomes symptomatic between the third and fifth decades of life, with a classic triad of cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, and skin pigmentation. Although hemochromatosis presents with liver damage, the biopsy findings are characterized by positive Prussian blue staining and pronounced iron deposits in hepatocytes rather than PAS-positive inclusion bodies as seen in this patient. In addition, other symptoms such as arthritis, pituitary infiltration, and cardiomyopathy would be expected.

answers.content: Dark corneal ring on slit-lamp examination
answers.explanation_why: Dark corneal ring on slit-lamp examination (Kayser-Fleischer ring) results from the accumulation of copper in the Descemet membrane of the cornea and is found in ∼ 98% of patients affected by Wilson disease. Although Wilson disease causes hepatic damage, a liver biopsy would show positive copper staining and hepatic copper concentration > 250 μg/g instead of PAS-positive inclusion bodies as seen in this patient. In addition to hepatic and ocular involvement, a broad spectrum of neurologic and psychiatric manifestations would also be expected in Wilson disease.

images.title: Kayser-Fleischer ring
images.description: Slit-lamp photography of a left eyeA brown ring is visible in the periphery of the cornea (Kayser-Fleischer ring; green overlay).Kayser-Fleischer rings are typically seen in Wilson disease.

images.title: Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency (liver)
images.description: Photomicrograph of a liver biopsy specimen (PAS diastase stain; approx. 450x magnification)PAS-positive and diastase-resistant globular cytoplasmic inclusions (green overlay) can be seen within periportal hepatocytes. The periportal fibrous tissue has been highlighted for orientation (white overlay).These are the characteristic histopathological findings in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. Additional immunohistochemical staining should be performed to confirm that the inclusions contain alpha-1 antitrypsin.

question_text: A previously healthy 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a lump beneath his right nipple that he discovered 1 week ago while showering. He has allergic rhinitis treated with cetirizine. He is at the 65^th percentile for height and 80^th percentile for weight. Examination shows a mildly tender, firm, 2-cm subareolar mass in the right breast; there are no nipple or skin changes. The left breast shows no abnormalities. Sexual development is Tanner stage 3. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's breast lump?
content_preview: A previously healthy 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a lump beneath his right nipple that he discovered 1 week ago while showering. He has allergic rhinitis treated with cetirizine. He is at the 65th percentile for height and 80th percentile for weight. Examination shows a mildly tender, firm, 2-cm subareolar mass in the right breast; there are no nipple or skin changes. The left breast shows no abnormalities. Sexual development is Tanner stage 3. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's breast lump?
hint: This patient's condition is likely the result of a transient imbalance between estrogens and androgens.
learning_objective: Recognize normal pubertal gynecomastia.

answers.explanation_why: A Leydig cell tumor can affect pre-pubertal and pubertal children by causing overproduction of either testosterone or estrogen. Although estrogen overproduction can cause gynecomastia, an estrogen-secreting Leydig cell tumor would result in bilateral gynecomastia rather than the unilateral gynecomastia seen here. Additionally, testicular examination of this patient showed no abnormalities; a testicular tumor would typically present as a palpable testicular mass.

Several drugs are associated with gynecomastia, including ketoconazole, spironolactone, digoxin, flutamide, leuprolide, and H_2 antagonists (e.g., cimetidine). This patient's only medication is cetirizine, an H_1 antagonist that is not known to cause gynecomastia. Moreover, drug-induced gynecomastia most often manifests as bilateral, diffuse enlargement of the breast tissue rather than the small, unilateral, limited mass seen here.

Invasive ductal carcinoma is a neoplastic process that occasionally appears in male breasts. It most commonly manifests in older males (> 40 years), who present with a unilateral breast mass, nipple discharge (often bloody), and in some cases overlying skin or nipple changes. This patient is very young and does not have skin changes or discharge, making ductal carcinoma very unlikely.

Kallmann syndrome is a very rare cause of gynecomastia in adolescent males. Affected males typically have negligible facial or body hair. Moreover, one of the classic hallmarks of this syndrome is anosmia, and the absence of this feature makes this diagnosis very unlikely.

Klinefelter syndrome can also present with gynecomastia in an adolescent male. However, in patients with Klinefelter syndrome, bilateral, generalized enlargement of the breasts is much more common than the unilateral development of a localized mass seen here. Additionally, adolescents suffering from this syndrome are classically very tall and thin and present with lack of body and facial hair as well as testicular atrophy; this patient's height and weight are average for his age and he has normal testes.

images.title: Klinefelter syndrome
images.description: Testicular hypoplasia and bilateral gynecomastia are characteristic features of Klinefelter syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Puberty is associated with a variety of physical changes. Normal pubertal changes in males include growth spurts, increased testicular volume, penile enlargement, development of breast tissue (e.g., gynecomastia), the appearance of genital and axillary hair, and deepening of the voice. Pubertal gynecomastia is common (affecting up to 50% of adolescent boys) and typically occurs in patients aged 10–14 years. Manifestations of gynecomastia include small, mobile, soft, nontender or minimally tender masses that may be unilateral or bilateral and typically recede within 18 months.

images.title: Gynecomastia
images.description: Male patient with bilateral gynecomastia

answers.explanation_why: Hyperprolactinemia is usually caused by a pituitary adenoma. Although it can cause breast enlargement, gynecomastia would be bilateral and it would typically be associated with galactorrhea, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, a pituitary adenoma would likely inhibit secretion of gonadotropins, causing a delay in puberty. This patient's unilateral breast enlargement, absence of any signs of pituitary adenoma (bitemporal hemianopsia, headache), and normal pubertal development make this diagnosis unlikely.
