question_text: A 57-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the emergency department because of leg swelling for 2 weeks. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, hepatomegaly, and pitting edema of both lower extremities. Cardiac examination shows a regular heart rate and normal heart sounds. Auscultation of the lungs shows scattered wheezing without crackles. Left ventricular ejection fraction is 60%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 57-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the emergency department because of leg swelling for 2 weeks. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention, hepatomegaly, and pitting edema of both lower extremities. Cardiac examination shows a regular heart rate and normal heart sounds. Auscultation of the lungs shows scattered wheezing without crackles. Left ventricular ejection fraction is 60%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: Hepatomegaly, bilateral pitting edema, and JVD are consistent with right-sided heart failure.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic hypoxic vasoconstriction as a cause of cor pulmonale.

answers.explanation_why: Excessive collagen deposition in the pulmonary tissue and arteries is characteristic of connective tissue disorders such as systemic sclerosis. This process can cause inflammation, interstitial thickening, and vascular dysfunction, which can result in pulmonary arterial hypertension and subsequent right-sided heart failure. However, right heart failure secondary to connective tissue disorders is commonly a late complication that is preceded by a long history of systemic symptoms (skin manifestations, Raynaud phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility). Furthermore, this patient' s history of COPD makes a different cause much more likely.

answers.content: Left-sided heart failure with systolic dysfunction
answers.explanation_why: Left-sided heart failure (LHF) with systolic dysfunction (i.e., reduced left ventricular ejection fraction) can lead to pulmonary vascular congestion with increased pulmonary venous pressure and subsequent pulmonary hypertension. Over time, this can result in right ventricular strain, hypertrophy, and, ultimately, right-sided heart failure. Although LHF with systolic dysfunction is the most common cause of right-sided heart failure, it is unlikely to be the underlying cause of this patient's condition, since he has a normal ejection fraction (∼ 60%) and shows no signs of left-sided heart failure (e.g., pulmonary edema with dyspnea, bilateral basilar rales).

Ventricular septal defect (VSD) arises from the incomplete closure of the ventricular septum during fetal development. Initially, VSDs cause a left to right shunt that increases blood flow through the pulmonary circulation. The resulting pulmonary hypertension can then, over time, cause right ventricular hypertrophy and subsequent right-sided heart failure. A VSD is unlikely in this patient given absence of a holosystolic murmur and his age.

answers.content: Chronic occlusion of the pulmonary vessels
answers.explanation_why: Chronic occlusion of the pulmonary vessels (e.g., chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension) is a form of pulmonary hypertension that can also lead to right-sided heart failure. However, this patient has no history of major risk factors (e.g., immobilization, hypercoagulability, malignancy) and a different etiology is much more likely given his underlying COPD.

This patient's right-sided heart failure is most likely related to chronic hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction due to his COPD (e.g., cor pulmonale). COPD is characterized by pulmonary inflammation resulting in fibrosis, airway obstruction, and capillary loss. Subsequent hypoxia and hypercapnia cause compensatory pulmonary vasoconstriction. The combination of hypoxic vasoconstriction and chronic inflammation triggers vascular remodeling, which, in turn, causes elevated pulmonary capillary pressure and pulmonary hypertension. Chronic, untreated pulmonary hypertension puts a strain on the right ventricle, causing concentric hypertrophy and progressive decline in right cardiac function, eventually leading to symptoms of decompensated right heart failure, as seen in this patient.

question_text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, and swelling and pruritus of the lips, tongue, and throat for 1 hour. The symptoms began minutes after he started eating a lobster dinner. It is determined that his symptoms are due to surface crosslinking of IgE. This immunologic event most likely caused the release of which of the following?
content_preview: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of abdominal pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, and swelling and pruritus of the lips, tongue, and throat for 1 hour. The symptoms began minutes after he started eating a lobster dinner. It is determined that his symptoms are due to surface crosslinking of IgE. This immunologic event most likely caused the release of which of the following?
hint: The patient's acute-onset abdominal pain, dizziness, shortness of breath, swelling, and pruritus after eating shellfish (a common allergen) are characteristic of an anaphylactic reaction. Anaphylaxis is a type I hypersensitivity reaction mediated by surface crosslinking of IgE on mast cells.
learning_objective: Recognize anaphylaxis, and recall the mediators released from mast cells.

answers.explanation_why:
In the immediate phase of anaphylactic reactions, surface crosslinking of IgE causes mast cell degranulation, which releases tryptase, histamine, heparin, and eosinophil chemotactic factors. Of these compounds, tryptase is a relatively specific marker of mast cell activation.

In the late phase of anaphylactic reactions, inflammatory cells (e.g., eosinophils) and cytokines mediate inflammation and tissue damage.

images.title: Mast cells
images.description: Photomicrograph of a blood smearMast cells are visible as multiple large purple cells containing copious amounts of cytoplasmic granules.

answers.explanation_why: Cathepsin is a lysosomal enzyme released by neutrophils during type III hypersensitivity reactions, as seen in vasculitides and serum sickness. Although serum sickness (or a serum-sickness like reaction) may present with urticaria, this patient lacks other characteristic findings such as fever, arthralgia, proteinuria, and lymphadenopathy. Moreover, serum sickness typically occurs 1–2 weeks after antigen exposure (unlike this patient's acute-onset symptoms). Cathepsin is not released by surface crosslinking of IgE.

Serotonin is released in high levels in carcinoid syndrome, which may present with abdominal pain and shortness of breath. However, carcinoid syndrome usually presents with additional symptoms, such as recurrent diarrhea and flushing. It does not cause facial swelling, and it is not mediated by surface crosslinking of IgE.

Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator responsible for facial swelling in patients with hereditary angioedema. In addition to facial swelling, some patients with hereditary angioedema also have gastrointestinal attacks that manifest with abdominal pain, similar to this patient. However, this condition does not cause urticaria or pruritus, and it is not mediated by surface crosslinking of IgE.
answers.explanation_but: Acquired causes of C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency and ACE inhibitor therapy (which decreases levels of ACE responsible for the breakdown of bradykinin) can also cause bradykinin-mediated angioedema.

answers.explanation_why: Interferon-gamma is secreted by natural killer cells and T cells and stimulates macrophages. This response occurs during type II hypersensitivity reactions and type IV hypersensitivity reactions. However, neither of these reactions play a role in anaphylaxis. Interferon-gamma is not released by surface crosslinking of IgE.

question_text: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following drugs would most likely have prevented this patient's condition?
content_preview: Four weeks after starting hydrochlorothiazide, a 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine. His blood pressure today is 176/87 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The precordial leads of a 12-lead ECG are shown. The addition of which of the following drugs would most likely have prevented this patient's condition?
hint: This patient has manifestations of hypokalemia (e.g., muscle cramps, weakness, and U waves on ECG). Thiazide diuretics inhibit Na^+ reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, which increases K^+ excretion and can lead to hypokalemia.
learning_objective: Recognize hypokalemia due to diuretic therapy, and choose a potassium-sparing antihypertensive.

answers.explanation_why: Torsemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the resorption of potassium in the thick ascending loop of Henle. It can also cause hypokalemia and would exacerbate the thiazide-induced hypokalemia seen in this patient.

Nifedipine, like amlodipine, is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It does not affect serum potassium concentrations and would not prevent this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia. Moreover, the combination of drugs from the same class is not recommended for the treatment of hypertension.

Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist that acts centrally to decrease peripheral vascular resistance. Clonidine has no effect on potassium excretion and would not have prevented this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia.

Eplerenone is an effective adjunct antihypertensive medication in patients with treatment-resistant hypertension. In addition, the drug's potassium-sparing properties are useful in patients who develop hypokalemia due to the use of potassium-wasting diuretics (e.g., loop and thiazide diuretics). Eplerenone inhibits the effect of aldosterone and, therefore, decreases K^+ excretion in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

images.title: Overview of diuretics
images.description: A. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: inhibit carbonic anhydrase and increase elimination of bicarbonate.B. Osmotic diuretics: predominantly act on the proximal tubule and the descending loop of Henle.C. Loop diuretics: inhibit Na^+-K^+-2Cl^- cotransporters in the ascending loop of Henle.D. Thiazide diuretics: inhibit Na^+-Cl^- cotransporters in the early distal convoluted tubule.E. Potassium-sparing diuretics: inhibit sodium resorption and potassium secretion in the distal convoluted tubule and proximal collecting duct.

answers.explanation_why: Hydralazine is a direct peripheral vasodilator that is used to decrease peripheral vascular resistance in patients with severe and/or treatment-resistant hypertension. It does not affect serum potassium concentrations and would not prevent this patient's iatrogenic hypokalemia.

images.title: ECG features of hypokalemia
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Sinus rhythm with a heart rate of approx. 77/min
– Normal cardiac axis
– Prolonged PR interval (~220 ms)
– ST-segment depression in I, II, and V2 to V6 (example indicated by red overlay in V2 zoom box)
– T-wave flattening in the limb leads
– Prominent U waves in the precordial leads, with fusion of the T and U waves (examples indicated by purple and green overlays respectively). The P waves in these leads (example indicated by blue overlay) are also mostly buried in the U waves.These findings are characteristic of severe hypokalemia.

question_text:
Two days after undergoing left hemicolectomy for a colonic mass, a 60-year-old man develops shortness of breath. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds and decreased fremitus at both lung bases. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.35

PaO_2

70 mm Hg 

PCO_2

40 mm Hg

An x-ray of the chest shows collapse of the bases of both lungs. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's hypoxemia?
content_preview: Two days after undergoing left hemicolectomy for a colonic mass, a 60-year-old man develops shortness of breath. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds and decreased fremitus at both lung bases. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.35 PaO2 70 mm Hg PCO2 40 mm Hg An x-ray of the chest shows collapse of the bases of both lungs. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's hypoxemia?
hint: This patient's dyspnea and decreased bilateral fremitus in the early postoperative period (1–3 days after surgery) are concerning for bibasilar atelectasis, which is confirmed with a chest x-ray showing collapsed lung.
learning_objective: Recall the pathophysiology of hypoxemia due to atelectasis.

answers.explanation_why: Anatomic dead space refers to the proportion of the airway that does not participate in gas exchange (e.g., nasopharynx, trachea). Anatomic dead space is not affected by atelectasis and would not explain this patient's hypoxemia.

A decreased hemoglobin oxygen-binding capacity (e.g., due to carbon monoxide poisoning or methemoglobinemia) can cause hypoxemia. However, atelectasis does not affect hemoglobin oxygen-binding capacity.

An increased tidal volume would result in increased ventilation and improved oxygenation, rather than hypoxemia, as seen in this patient. Exercises to increase tidal volume (e.g., using an incentive spirometer) are commonly used to prevent and correct atelectasis.

In patients with bibasilar atelectasis, collapsed alveoli are unable to participate in gas exchange, allowing venous blood to pass into the arterial circulation without becoming oxygenated, which results in a right-to-left pulmonary shunt and ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch.

A right-to-left pulmonary shunt or a V/Q mismatch increases the A-a gradient, which is ≈ 150 - (1.25 × P_aCO_2  in mm Hg) - P_aO_2 in mm Hg on room air (i.e., F_iO_2 of 0.21) and at sea level. The normal A-a gradient for age should be < (age in years / 4) + 4. This patient's A-a gradient should be < 19 mm Hg but is 30 mm Hg.

images.title: Hypoxemia workup
images.description: A-a gradient: alveolar-arterial gradientABG: arterial blood gas analysisALS: amyotrophic lateral sclerosisARDS: acute respiratory distress syndromeAVM: arteriovenous malformationCNS: central nervous systemDLCO: diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxideFiO_2: fraction of inspired oxygenGBS: Guillain-Barré syndromeMG: myasthenia gravisOHS: obesity hypoventilation syndromeOSA: obstructive sleep apneaPaCO_2: partial pressure of carbon dioxide in arterial bloodPaO_2: partial pressure of oxygen in arterial bloodRF: respiratory failureV/Q mismatch: ventilation-perfusion mismatchV/Q ratio: ventilation-perfusion ratio

answers.explanation_why: The rate of oxygen consumption is increased in states of high-energy expenditure (e.g., exercise, severe illness, sepsis) and usually leads to a compensatory increase in ventilation (e.g., increase in respiratory rate and/or tidal volume) to prevent hypoxemia. This patient does not have any history to suggest increased oxygen consumption.

Decreased chest wall compliance (e.g., due to scoliosis, trauma, or frailty) can lead to hypoxemia as a result of impaired ventilation and may occur parallel to atelectasis. However, hypercapnia would also be expected.

question_text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe epigastric pain and vomiting that started 30 minutes ago while gardening. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis and jugular venous distention. An ECG shows P waves independent of QRS complexes and ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Coronary angiography is most likely to show narrowing of which of the following vessels?
content_preview: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe epigastric pain and vomiting that started 30 minutes ago while gardening. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diaphoresis and jugular venous distention. An ECG shows P waves independent of QRS complexes and ST segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF. Coronary angiography is most likely to show narrowing of which of the following vessels?
hint: Epigastric pain and vomiting, combined with ST segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF are consistent with an inferior wall myocardial infarction. Dissociated P waves and QRS complexes are indicative of third-degree atrioventricular block.
learning_objective: Recognize inferior wall myocardial infarction and its associated ECG changes, and recall the coronary artery anatomy.

answers.explanation_why: The left coronary artery (LCA) branches to the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and the left circumflex artery (LCX). Occlusion of the LCA can lead to a massive myocardial infarction involving a combination of the anterior (ECG changes in leads I, aVL, and V1– V6), anteroseptal (leads I, aVL, and V1– V4), anterolateral (leads I, aVL, and V5– V6/V7), apical (leads I, aVL, V3– V5), and posterolateral (leads II, III, aVF, and V5– V7, and sometimes lead I and aVL) walls. This patient's ECG is consistent with infarction of the inferior wall, which can be supplied by the distal LCX but is more commonly supplied by a different artery.

Occlusion of the proximal right coronary artery (RCA) can cause an inferior wall myocardial infarction, which in turn can present atypically with epigastric pain. High-degree atrioventricular block can occur in this setting because the sinoatrial node (SA node) and atrioventricular node (AV node) are usually supplied by the RCA (the SA node directly, and the AV node via the AV nodal branch). Right-sided leads (V4R, V5R, and V6R) should also be obtained to evaluate for right ventricular (RV) infarction (especially given the patient's jugular venous distention), as the RCA supplies the RV via its right marginal branch.

images.title: Illustration of the coronary arteries
images.description: This image shows the anatomical location of the coronary arteries from a ventral and dorsal view. The left and right coronary arteries arise from the aortic sinus and run along the corresponding coronary sinuses on the caudal side of the heart. The majority of the population has right-dominant coronary artery circulation.

answers.explanation_why: The left circumflex artery (LCX) supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle. Occlusion of the LCX causes ECG changes in the lateral (V5, V6, I, aVL) leads. In patients with left-dominant coronary circulation, occlusion of the LCX causes distal infarction of the posterior descending artery, leading to an inferior wall myocardial infarction and ECG changes in the posterior/posterolateral (V7–V9) and inferior (II, III, aVF) leads. However, the LCX is not the most likely source of this patient's inferior wall myocardial infarction because only approx. 10% of the population is left-dominant.

Occlusion of the left anterior descending artery (LAD) causes infarction of the anterior (ECG changes in leads I, aVL, and V1– V6), anteroseptal (leads I, aVL, and V1– V4), anterolateral (leads I, aVL, and V5– V6/V7), and/or apical wall (leads I, aVL, and V3– V5). The inferior wall is not typically supplied by the LAD. Moreover, although an anteroseptal myocardial infarction can sometimes cause serious arrhythmias, such as a high-degree atrioventricular block (the LAD supplies the left and right bundle branches and partially supplies the left anterior and posterior fascicles), conduction abnormalities are more common following an inferior myocardial infarction.

Occlusion of the posterior interventricular artery would cause a posterior wall myocardial infarction, which would manifest as ST segment depression in leads V1 and V2, sometimes with prominent R waves. Posterior leads (V7– V9) would show ST segment elevation. Epigastric pain is not common in posterior wall myocardial infarctions, nor are conduction abnormalities, since the posterior interventricular artery does not supply the conduction system.

images.title: Posterior myocardial infarction
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Heart rate: ~ 83/min
– Sinus rhythm
– Normal axis (R > S in I and II)
– Downsloping ST depression in leads V_2 and V_3 and horizontal ST depression in V_4 (examples indicated by red overlay) is accompanied by positive T waves (examples indicated by blue overlay). This appearance is reciprocal to posterior ST elevations with T-wave inversions.
– Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V_2 (example indicated by green overlay): reciprocal to posterior Q waves
– Right bundle branch block (RBBB): rSR′ complex in V_1 and QRS duration of 0.12 sThese findings suggest a posterior myocardial infarction. To confirm, an additional ECG including the posterior leads V7–V9 can be obtained to look for ST elevation, T-wave inversion, and Q waves. Note that ST depression ≥ 0.5 mm in leads V1–V4 is a STEMI-equivalent ECG finding (i.e., management is the same as that for STEMI).

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-month history of episodic chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion. He is at the 99^th percentile for height and 40^th percentile for weight. Examination shows a high-arched palate, long and slender upper extremities, and elbows and knees that can be hyperextended. Cardiac examination shows a grade 2/6 late systolic, crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click. The murmur is most likely to be heard best over which of the following labeled areas?
content_preview: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 3-month history of episodic chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion. He is at the 99th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows a high-arched palate, long and slender upper extremities, and elbows and knees that can be hyperextended. Cardiac examination shows a grade 2/6 late systolic, crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click. The murmur is most likely to be heard best over which of the following labeled areas?
hint: This boy's tall stature, long and slender arms, joint hypermobility (as evidenced by his hyperextensible elbows and knees), and high-arched palate are consistent with Marfan syndrome, an inherited connective tissue disorder associated with ocular, musculoskeletal, and cardiovascular abnormalities.
learning_objective: Recognize Marfan syndrome, and recall the auscultation location for mitral valve prolapse.

answers.explanation_why: Area A corresponds to the carotid area. Aortic stenosis causes a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur that can radiate to this area. Severe carotid artery stenosis can also cause a carotid bruit heard over this area. The murmur most commonly associated with Marfan syndrome is best heard over a different area.

Area B corresponds to the aortic area, which is located in the right 2^nd intercostal space in the parasternal line. Aortic stenosis causes a midsystolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard over this area. Marfan syndrome, which this patient has, commonly causes aortic root dilation and, consequently, aortic regurgitation. In aortic regurgitation due to aortic root disease, an early diastolic murmur is heard over the aortic area during diastole. The systolic murmur in this patient, however, is best heard over a different area.

Area C corresponds to the pulmonic area, located in the left 2^nd parasternal intercostal space. Pulmonary stenosis causes a systolic, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard over this area. Pulmonary stenosis is not associated with Marfan syndrome.

Area D corresponds to the left sternal border. Aortic regurgitation (AR) due to valvular disease can cause a murmur that is best heard over this area. AR in Marfan disease, although a common manifestation, is due to aortic root dilation, which causes a murmur best heard at the right rather than the left sternal border. Moreover, the murmur in AR is early diastolic. The systolic murmur in this patient is best heard over a different area.

Area E corresponds to the tricuspid area located in the left 4^th parasternal intercostal space. Ventricular septal defects (the most common congenital cardiac defect) can cause a holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmur best heard over this area. Tricuspid stenosis causes a diastolic, low-pitched, decrescendo murmur and tricuspid regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur, both of which can also be heard over this area. The murmur most commonly associated with Marfan syndrome is best heard over a different area.

Patients with Marfan syndrome can have mitral valve prolapse (MVP), which causes a late systolic, crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click. This murmur is best heard at the heart apex (mitral area, located at the left 5^th intercostal space in the midclavicular line) when the patient is in the left lateral recumbent position. Other cardiovascular abnormalities associated with Marfan syndrome include aortic disease (e.g., aortic root dilation, aortic regurgitation, aortic aneurysm, aortic dissection) and berry aneurysms.

Marfan syndrome can lead to other musculoskeletal abnormalities, including arachnodactyly and spinal abnormalities (scoliosis and sternal kyphosis). Ocular manifestations can include ectopia lentis (superiorly and temporally), myopia, retinal detachment, and glaucoma.

images.title: Anatomical locations and auscultatory sites for heart valves
images.description:
I–IV: anatomical locations of heart valves1. Aortic area: 2^nd right parasternal intercostal space (ICS)
- Ideal site for auscultation of aortic valve murmurs (1a). The murmur of aortic stenosis also radiates to the carotid arteries (1b).2. Pulmonary area: 2^nd left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of pulmonary valve murmurs3. Tricuspid area: 4^th left parasternal ICS
- Ideal site for auscultation of tricuspid valve murmurs4. Mitral area: 5^th left ICS in the midclavicular line (over the cardiac apex)
- Ideal site for auscultation of mitral valve murmurs (4a). The murmur of mitral regurgitation also radiates to the left axilla (4b).

answers.explanation_why: Area G corresponds to the left midaxillary line. Mitral regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur that can radiate to this area, particularly if the patient is in the left lateral recumbent position. The murmur most commonly found in patients with Marfan syndrome is best heard over a different area.

images.title: Auscultatory sites of the heart valves
images.description:
(A) Carotid area
(B) Aortic area
(C) Pulmonic area
(D) Left sternal border
(E) Tricuspid area
(F) Mitral area
(G) Axilla

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S_2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The patient presents with lower extremity cyanosis and clubbing with preserved upper extremity oxygenation (a finding known as differential cyanosis) and symptoms of heart failure.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features of a large patent ductus arteriosus, and recall the expected echocardiographic finding.

answers.content: Single overriding great vessel arising from the heart
answers.explanation_why: A single overriding great vessel is called a persistent truncus arteriosus. This single arterial trunk arising from the heart provides mixed blood to the pulmonary arteries and the systemic circulation. Pulses may be accentuated and bounding; however, oxygen saturation would be decreased in all extremities. Furthermore, if it is not diagnosed prenatally, it will typically present perinatally with symptoms of global cyanosis and heart failure, while this adolescent patient only has differential cyanosis.

answers.content: Anomalous shunting of blood through a defect in atrial septum
answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASD) are often asymptomatic. In adults, larger defects may lead to a distinct left-to-right shunt, which can result in right heart failure, supraventricular arrhythmias, and pulmonary hypertension, and ultimately lead to an Eisenmenger reaction and global cyanosis. Differential cyanosis would not be seen.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Persistent blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta
answers.explanation_why:
Failure of the ductus arteriosus to completely close postnatally allows blood to flow from the descending aorta back to the pulmonary artery (left-to-right shunt). In a large patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), this leads to volume overload of the right ventricle and the lung circuit. This increased blood flow causes pulmonary hypertension and irreversible remodeling of small pulmonary vessels, which may eventually lead to an Eisenmenger reaction (shunt reversal). This patient's palpable right parasternal heave and pronounced S_2 are evidence of increased right heart strain. In patients with a large PDA, the features of differential cyanosis occur once shunt reversal develops. Because the ductus is located on the descending aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery, reversal of the shunt results in deoxygenated blood reaching only the lower body. Due to the rise in pulmonary pressure, the characteristic continuous machine-like murmur heard in patients with PDA eventually disappears.

Infants with PDA usually receive an infusion of indomethacin to induce closure of the duct, while in older children symptomatic PDAs are typically closed surgically or via percutaneous catheter occlusion. The presence of an Eisenmenger reaction is, however, a contraindication to a PDA closure.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect
answers.explanation_why: Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect is seen in tetralogy of Fallot. The other features of this cardiac abnormality are pulmonary stenosis and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is typically symptomatic in infancy and presents with tet spells and mild cyanosis in all extremities.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Abnormal narrowing of the aorta at the aortic isthmus
answers.explanation_why: Abnormal narrowing at the aortic isthmus is consistent with coarctation of the aorta (CoA), which would cause differential cyanosis if the CoA is severe (i.e., a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect) but this differential cyanosis would be evident from the neonatal period. In addition, patients with CoA have a brachio-femoral pulse delay rather than synchronous pulses. The symptoms of a mild CoA can begin later in life but in such a scenario, differential cyanosis would not be expected. Instead, patients present with features of brachiocephalic hypertension (e.g., headaches, epistaxis), lower extremity arterial insufficiency (manifesting with claudication and cool skin with faint or unpalpable pulses, but no cyanosis), and evidence of compensatory collateral arteries (e.g., continuous murmur over the back).

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

question_text: Two weeks after undergoing allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma, a 55-year-old man develops a severely pruritic rash, abdominal cramps, and profuse diarrhea. He appears lethargic. Physical examination shows yellow sclerae. There is a generalized maculopapular rash on his face, trunk, and lower extremities, and desquamation of both soles. His serum alanine aminotransferase is 115 U/L, serum aspartate aminotransferase is 97 U/L, and serum total bilirubin is 2.7 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: Two weeks after undergoing allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma, a 55-year-old man develops a severely pruritic rash, abdominal cramps, and profuse diarrhea. He appears lethargic. Physical examination shows yellow sclerae. There is a generalized maculopapular rash on his face, trunk, and lower extremities, and desquamation of both soles. His serum alanine aminotransferase is 115 U/L, serum aspartate aminotransferase is 97 U/L, and serum total bilirubin is 2.7 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient developed a desquamating pruritic rash, diarrhea with abdominal cramping, and evidence of liver damage (scleral jaundice, elevated transaminases) shortly after a stem cell transplantation, which is concerning for graft-versus-host disease (GvHD).
learning_objective: Recognize graft-versus-host disease, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.content: Donor T cells in the graft
answers.explanation_why: During allogeneic stem cell transplantation, donor T cells can perceive host tissue as a foreign antigen and mount an immune response, resulting in acute GvHD within 100 days of transplantation. It commonly affects the skin, mucosa, liver, and intestine; thus, patients present with maculopapular rash, diarrhea, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly, as observed in this patient.

Newly formed anti-HLA antibodies mediate a humoral immune response in acute graft rejection. Antigen-antibody complexes activate the complement cascade, which mediates tissue injury; hence, complement fragments (C4d) can be observed upon graft tissue staining. Patients with acute graft rejection present with fever, pain in the graft region, and graft vessel vasculitis within 6 months of transplantation. Although this patient presented within 2 weeks of transplantation, he has involvement of intestine, liver, and skin, making acute graft rejection unlikely.

Although proliferating transplanted B cells have been shown to have a role in chronic GvHD in studies with animal models, its role in patients with allogeneic stem cell transplantation is not well defined. Chronic GvHD is observed 100 days after transplantation and presents with clinical features of chronic enteritis, chronic sicca syndrome, bronchiolitis obliterans, liver dysfunction, and polymyositis.

Exposure to graft MHC alloantigen can activate recipient T cells, which orchestrates a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction (cell-mediated immune response), that develops into acute graft rejection within weeks to months. Patients present with fever, graft tissue swelling, generalized deterioration, and lymphocytic infiltration of graft vessels; although this patient presented within 2 weeks of transplantation, his symptoms are not confined to the transplanted tissue.

Preformed cytotoxic anti-HLA antibodies react to graft class 1 HLA antigen and mediate hyperacute graft rejection, which is commonly seen in cases with donor recipient ABO incompatibility. Antigen-antibody complexes activate the complement system (type 2 hypersensitivity reaction), leading to thrombus formation and graft ischemia. Patients present with intraoperative graft swelling and can develop systemic inflammatory response syndrome within minutes to hours, unlike this patient who presented 2 weeks after transplantation with maculopapular rash, diarrhea, and features of liver injury.

question_text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 36 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department after an episode of dizziness and vomiting followed by loss of consciousness lasting 1 minute. She reports that her symptoms started after lying down on her back to rest, as she felt tired during yoga class. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. On arrival, she is diaphoretic and pale. Her pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 90/58 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is lying in the supine position with a fundal height of 36 cm. There is a prolonged fetal heart rate deceleration to 80/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate action to reverse this patient's symptoms in the future?
content_preview: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 36 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department after an episode of dizziness and vomiting followed by loss of consciousness lasting 1 minute. She reports that her symptoms started after lying down on her back to rest, as she felt tired during yoga class. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. On arrival, she is diaphoretic and pale. Her pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 90/58 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is lying in the supine position with a fundal height of 36 cm. There is a prolonged fetal heart rate deceleration to 80/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate action to reverse this patient's symptoms in the future?
hint: This patient's symptoms are consistent with supine hypotensive syndrome, which frequently occurs due to compression of the inferior vena cava associated with the anatomical changes involved in pregnancy.
learning_objective: Recognize supine hypotensive syndrome in pregnancy, and choose the position to alleviate symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: Muller maneuver causes intrathoracic pressure to become more negative, thereby improving venous return to the heart. Although it could be beneficial for this patient, this maneuver would not resolve the cause of her symptoms.

answers.content: Lying in the supine position and elevating legs
answers.explanation_why: Elevating the legs while lying in the supine position increases venous return to the heart. Although it could be beneficial for this patient, this maneuver would not resolve the cause of her symptoms.

answers.content: Gentle compression with an abdominal binder
answers.explanation_why: Gentle compression with an abdominal binder can be used in pregnant patients with back problems. However, abdominal compression can decrease venous return to the heart, which could worsen this patient's symptoms.

answers.content: Lying in the left lateral decubitus position
answers.explanation_why: The left lateral decubitus position is generally recommended for pregnant women when lying down, especially in the third trimester, because this position shifts the uterus away from and thus avoids compression of the inferior vena cava. Compression of the inferior vena cava is the cause of supine hypotensive syndrome, which results in compromised venous return and leads to decreased cardiac output, fetal hypoxia, and prolonged decelerations on cardiotocography, as seen here.

Hand grip maneuver increases systemic vascular resistance and afterload. This maneuver is used for better evaluation of heart murmurs (e.g., mitral regurgitation, aortic regurgitation, VSD). It would not, however, resolve the cause of this patient's symptoms.
Valsalva maneuver increases intrathoracic pressure, thereby decreasing venous return to the heart. This maneuver could worsen this patient's symptoms.

question_text:
A 76-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a sudden loss of vision in her right eye for 10 minutes that morning, which subsided spontaneously. Over the past 2 months, she has had multiple episodes of left-sided headaches and pain in her jaw while chewing. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Range of motion of the shoulders and hips is slightly limited by pain. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 69 mm/h. Treatment with the appropriate medication for this patient's condition is initiated. Which of the following sets of laboratory findings is most likely as a consequence of treatment?

Lymphocytes
Neutrophils
Eosinophils
Fibroblasts

A
↓
↓
↓
↓

B
↑
↑
↓
↑

C
↓
↑
↑
↑

D
↓
↓

↓

E
↓

F

Over the past 2 months, she has had multiple episodes of left-sided headaches and pain in her jaw while chewing. Examination shows conjunctival pallor. Range of motion of the shoulders and hips is slightly limited by pain. Her erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 69 mm/h. Treatment with the appropriate medication for this patient's condition is initiated. Which of the following sets of laboratory findings is most likely as a consequence of treatment? Lymphocytes Neutrophils Eosinophils Fibroblasts A ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ B ↑ ↑ ↓ ↑ C ↓ ↑ ↑ ↑ D ↓ ↓ ↑ ↓ E ↓ ↑ ↓ ↓ F ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓
hint: Sudden, transient loss of vision (amaurosis fugax) in an elderly female with a history of unilateral headaches and jaw claudication suggests giant cell arteritis (GCA). Proximal muscle pain and stiffness should raise suspicion for concurrent polymyalgia rheumatica. The presence of anemia (conjunctival pallor) and a significantly elevated ESR further support the diagnosis of GCA. High-dose glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment for GCA.
learning_objective: Recognize giant cell arteritis, and recall the hematological effects of glucocorticoids.

answers.explanation_why: A decrease in the circulating levels of lymphocytes, eosinophils, and fibroblasts is seen after initiation of glucocorticoids. However, glucocorticoids would also cause neutrophilic leukocytosis.
Glucocorticoids would cause neutrophilic leukocytosis and eosinopenia. However, they do not result in increased lymphocytes and fibroblasts.

Isolated lymphocytopenia can be seen in certain viral infections, e.g., HIV. Other causes of lymphocytopenia include parasitic infections (malaria), fungal infections (histoplasmosis), and autoimmune disorders (SLE and rheumatoid arthritis). While glucocorticoids also cause lymphocytopenia and neutrophilia, they do not lead to an increase in eosinophils and fibroblasts.

Eosinophilia is seen in parasitic and fungal infections, allergic reactions, atopic disorders such as asthma, certain neoplasms (e.g., leukemia and lymphoma), and hypoadrenalism. Glucocorticoids, however, are associated with a marked decrease in circulating levels of eosinophils due to promotion of eosinophil apoptosis. Glucocorticoid use would also lead to neutrophilic leukocytosis, not neutropenia.

The laboratory findings expected in response to the initiation of glucocorticoids include neutrophilic leukocytosis within hours of the initial dose. This is secondary to demargination of neutrophils. Glucocorticoids promote apoptosis and lead to a decrease in the circulating levels of eosinophils, lymphocytes, and monocytes. They also inhibit the proliferation and activity of fibroblasts, decrease collagen synthesis, and can lead to skin thinning, striae distensae, purpura, and poor wound healing.

images.title: Adverse effects of glucocorticoids
images.description: Features not specifically highlighted as being caused by inhaled glucocorticoids or by both systemic and topical glucocorticoids are caused primarily by systemic glucocorticoid use.

answers.explanation_why: Lymphocytosis can be seen secondary to viral infections, hypersensitivity reactions, stress, autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, and lymphocytic malignancies. Glucocorticoids, however, cause lymphocytopenia due to the promotion of lymphocyte apoptosis. Moreover, glucocorticoids cause neutrophilic leukocytosis, not neutropenia.

question_text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of crampy abdominal pain, recurrent watery diarrhea, and a 2.5-kg (5.5-lb) weight loss. Her husband has noticed that after meals, her face and neck sometimes become red, and she develops shortness of breath and starts wheezing. Examination shows a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of crampy abdominal pain, recurrent watery diarrhea, and a 2.5-kg (5.5-lb) weight loss. Her husband has noticed that after meals, her face and neck sometimes become red, and she develops shortness of breath and starts wheezing. Examination shows a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
hint: Watery diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, episodic cutaneous flushing triggered by eating or emotional events, asthma-like attacks, and a murmur indicative of tricuspid regurgitation are highly suggestive of carcinoid syndrome. Neuroendocrine neoplasms are highly metabolically active and can secrete excess amounts of serotonin.
learning_objective: Recognize carcinoid syndrome, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Increased gastric pH levels are not associated with carcinoid syndrome but are seen in achlorhydria, which is a key feature of WDHA syndrome (watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria) seen in VIPomas. The unregulated production of VIP leads to excessive secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Cutaneous flushing is seen in about 20% of patients with VIPoma. However, abdominal pain is usually mild or absent. Furthermore, this etiology does not explain why the patient also presents with a tricuspid murmur and asthma, neither of which are typical findings of VIPomas.

Laryngeal edema is not associated with carcinoid syndrome but commonly occurs in hereditary angioedema, a bradykinin-mediated reaction that can also cause colicky abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, episodic cutaneous flushing and a tricuspid regurgitation murmur would not be expected. Although mast cell-mediated angioedema can cause flushing, it does not present with abdominal pain or diarrhea.

Dermatitis is a characteristic feature of pellagra, or niacin deficiency; other key findings include dementia and diarrhea (i.e., the “three Ds”). Dermatitis in patients with pellagra is characterized by a symmetrical, pigmented, scaly thickening of the skin in sun-exposed areas, such as the limbs and around the neck (casal necklace). The increased metabolism of serotonin in neuroendocrine neoplasms depletes the amount of tryptophan precursors available for other organic compounds, including niacin. A lack of niacin leads to decreased production of the coenzymes NAD+ and NADP+, which are essential in redox reactions throughout cellular metabolism. Diagnosis is confirmed via 24-hour urine testing for 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), the end product of serotonin metabolism.

In developed countries, pellagra is most commonly seen in patients with alcohol use disorder or as a complication of malabsorption. It can also occur in Hartnup disease (due to renal and intestinal loss of tryptophan) or after prolonged use of isoniazid (due to decreased levels of vitamin B6, which is essential for the production of niacin).

images.title: Vitamin B₃ deficiency
images.description: Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

answers.explanation_why: Megaloblastic anemia is not caused by carcinoid syndrome but is usually due to folate deficiency or vitamin B12 deficiency and is commonly associated with malnutrition or malabsorption. Specific causes for folate deficiency include the use of folate antagonists, whereas vitamin B12 deficiency is seen in pernicious anemia or after gastrectomy. Although malabsorption can occur in carcinoid syndrome, it is usually not severe enough to cause folate or vitamin B12 deficiency. Another complication is more likely to affect this patient.

Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma is not associated with carcinoid syndrome but is a complication of celiac disease. Although this patient has had weight loss and diarrhea, she lacks other typical manifestations of celiac disease, such as steatorrhea, malabsorption symptoms (e.g., anemia), and dermatitis herpetiformis. Furthermore, celiac disease does not explain this patient's tricuspid murmur, asthma, and flushing.

question_text: A 59-year-old man with angina pectoris comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of shortness of breath on exertion that improves with rest. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, and nitroglycerine. Echocardiography shows left ventricular septal and apical hypokinesis. Cardiac catheterization shows 96% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. The patient undergoes angioplasty and placement of a stent. The patient's shortness of breath subsequently resolves and follow-up echocardiography one week later shows normal regional contractile function. Which of the following is the most accurate explanation for the changes in echocardiography?
content_preview: A 59-year-old man with angina pectoris comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of shortness of breath on exertion that improves with rest. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, and nitroglycerine. Echocardiography shows left ventricular septal and apical hypokinesis. Cardiac catheterization shows 96% occlusion of the left anterior descending artery. The patient undergoes angioplasty and placement of a stent. The patient's shortness of breath subsequently resolves and follow-up echocardiography one week later shows normal regional contractile function. Which of the following is the most accurate explanation for the changes in echocardiography?
hint: The patient had signs and symptoms of chronic left ventricular dysfunction that were reversed by revascularization.
learning_objective: Recall the concept of hibernating myocardium.

answers.explanation_why: Unstable angina pectoris is characterized by the sudden new onset of symptoms of acute coronary syndrome at rest or on minimal exertion, or rapidly worsening symptoms (crescendo angina). However, this patient has long-standing dyspnea, which likely occurs on exertion and improves with rest and would therefore be most consistent with stable angina pectoris.

Stress cardiomyopathy (Takotsubo cardiomyopathy) describes an acute decline in left-ventricular function following an emotionally or physically stressful event (e.g., unexpected death of a relative, natural disaster, or respiratory failure, infection). Although dyspnea can be present, it would not be limited to exertion, as in this patient. A hallmark finding on echocardiography is apical ballooning of the left ventricle, which is not seen here. In contrast to this patient who experienced rapid symptom relief and functional improvement after revascularization, patients with stress cardiomyopathy recover spontaneously and only require symptomatic treatment with beta blockers or ACE inhibitors.

Hibernating myocardium is characterized by persistently impaired myocardial contractility at rest (on echocardiography or radionuclide myocardial perfusion imaging) that is partially or completely reversible when adequate oxygen supply is restored (e.g., after angioplasty or coronary artery bypass surgery). In response to decreased perfusion, hibernating myocardial cells enter a state of decreased metabolic activity. In contrast, myocardial stunning occurs after an episode of acute ischemia and is characterized by transiently impaired myocardial contractility.

Myocardial scar tissue indicates myocardial necrosis, most often induced by irreversible myocardial ischemia due to myocardial infarction (MI). The patient could have undergone a silent MI, but, since myocardial scars are marked by complete replacement with fibrous, non-contractile tissue, there would be permanent dyskinesia on echocardiography even after revascularization. Scar tissue can also lead to a true ventricular aneurysm, which would then manifest as an outward bulge of the affected segment during myocardial contraction.

Cardiac remodeling is a chronic process in which the myocardium undergoes permanent changes in structure (i.e., mass, shape, dimensions) and/or function to compensate for cardiac injury or an increased hemodynamic load that does not rapidly improve after treatment (here within one week). Reduced contractile function would likely persist even after successful revascularization.

In myocardial stunning, affected segments undergo short but significant acute ischemia ("stunning"), but regain their baseline contractile functionality because of the short-term nature of the event. This patient's myocardial dysfunction is similar in that function is regained after revascularization. However, this patient's symptoms suggest a prolonged, chronic history of myocardial flow reduction and ischemia.

question_text: A 42-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), and pulse is 105/min. When the blood pressure cuff is inflated to 140 mm Hg, the patient's pulse is audible and regular. However, upon inspiration, the pulse disappears and does not reappear until expiration. The pulse becomes audible throughout the entire respiratory cycle when the blood pressure cuff is deflated to 125 mm Hg. Which of the following underlying conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's physical examination findings?
content_preview: A 42-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of shortness of breath. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), and pulse is 105/min. When the blood pressure cuff is inflated to 140 mm Hg, the patient's pulse is audible and regular. However, upon inspiration, the pulse disappears and does not reappear until expiration. The pulse becomes audible throughout the entire respiratory cycle when the blood pressure cuff is deflated to 125 mm Hg. Which of the following underlying conditions is most likely responsible for this patient's physical examination findings?
hint: Arterial systolic pressure normally falls during inspiration, although the magnitude of decrease usually does not exceed 10 mm Hg. A pathological decrease in arterial systolic pressure > 10 mm Hg during inspiration (in this case, the difference is 15 mm Hg) is characteristic of pulsus paradoxus.
learning_objective: Recognize pulsus paradoxus in asthma.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) can manifest as dyspnea due to pulmonary venous congestion. Physical examination findings associated with MR include holosystolic high-pitched murmur heard best at the apex and crackles on lung auscultation. Pulsus paradoxus is not associated with mitral regurgitation.

Pulmonary fibrosis is characterized by progressive scarring of the lung parenchyma, resulting in reduced lung compliance and a restrictive pulmonary physiology. Patients often present with progressive dyspnea, a dry cough, and fine inspiratory crackles on auscultation. Restrictive lung disease does not cause the marked decrease in intrathoracic pressure that leads to pulsus paradoxus.

Physical examination findings associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) include the presence of an S4, harsh systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur heard at the apex, and a brisk carotid upstroke. Rarely, it is also associated with reverse pulsus paradoxus, which refers to an inspiratory increase rather than a decrease in systolic and diastolic pressures. Pulsus paradoxus, as seen in this patient, is not associated with HOCM.

Heart failure does not commonly cause pulsus paradoxus but can cause pulsus alternans (alternating strong and weak pulses) on physical examination due to alterations in cardiac output. Additional manifestations of heart failure include dyspnea, peripheral edema, crackles on lung auscultation, a 3rd heart sound, and distended jugular veins.

Pulsus paradoxus is most commonly caused by severe obstructive lung disease (e.g., COPD, asthma) or constrictive cardiac disease (e.g., cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis, tension pneumothorax). Increased airway resistance in obstructive lung disease leads to a significant decrease in intrathoracic pressure during inhalation, which increases venous return to the right atrium and ventricle. The enlarged right ventricle then exerts pressure on the left ventricle, resulting in a decrease in stroke volume and a drop in inspiratory blood pressure.

In constrictive cardiac disease, the pericardial space is unable to compensate for inspiratory venous return, leading to pulsus paradoxus. In a pathologically constricted heart, the increase in right ventricular volume causes bowing of the right ventricle into the left ventricle, resulting in decreased left ventricular filling and cardiac output, and a subsequent drop in systolic blood pressure.

question_text: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of anxiety, difficulty focusing on tasks, and a 4.6-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 4 weeks. He is diaphoretic. His pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm, moist skin, goiter, and a resting tremor of both hands. Laboratory studies show a thyroxine (T4) concentration of 30 μg/dL and a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 0.1 μU/mL. The patient is started on methimazole and atenolol. The latter agent predominantly affects which of the following?
content_preview: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of anxiety, difficulty focusing on tasks, and a 4.6-kg (10-lb) weight loss over the past 4 weeks. He is diaphoretic. His pulse is 100/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 150/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows warm, moist skin, goiter, and a resting tremor of both hands. Laboratory studies show a thyroxine (T4) concentration of 30 μg/dL and a thyroid-stimulating hormone concentration of 0.1 μU/mL. The patient is started on methimazole and atenolol. The latter agent predominantly affects which of the following?
hint: Atenolol is a cardioselective beta blocker, which competitively antagonizes the positive chronotropic, inotropic, and dromotropic effect of catecholamines.
learning_objective: Recall the effects of beta blockers on the heart.

answers.explanation_why: β_1 adrenergic receptor antagonists lower concentrations of cAMP and calcium in the cells of the atrioventricular (AV) node. This decreases conduction and automaticity at the AV node by decreasing the slope of phase 4 depolarization of the nodal (pacemaker) action potential. On ECG this effect would appear as a prolonged PR interval. Beta blockers also have a negative chronotropic (↓ risk of heart failure) and a negative inotropic (↓ contractility) effect.

images.title: Class II Antiarrhythmics
images.description: Illustration of membrane potential of the atrioventricular node over time for class II antiarrhythmic drugs.Normal action potential is shown faded. Class II antiarrhythmic drugs extend the time until the threshold potential is reached and prolong depolarization and are therefore negative dromotropic (slow down conduction speed).

answers.explanation_why: Atenolol acts on β_1 receptors to decrease sympathetic tone. It has no effect on vagal (parasympathetic) tone. Digoxin is an antiarrhythmic that can increase vagal tone.

answers.content: Effective refractory period of the cardiac action potential
answers.explanation_why: Prolongation of the effective refractory period of the cardiac action potential is caused by Class IA, IC, III, and IV antiarrhythmic drugs. Beta-blockers (class II antiarrhythmics), however, do not significantly alter the refractory period.
Class I antiarrhythmics can decrease conduction in extranodal tissue (e.g., His-Purkinje system). Beta blockers do not act on the His-Purkinje system.

answers.content: Phase 0 depolarization slope of the cardiac action potential
answers.explanation_why: Phase 0 depolarization slope of the cardiac action potential is caused by the opening of fast voltage-gated Na^+ channels. Class I antiarrhythmics, which block these channels, would, therefore, affect phase 0. Beta-blockers (class II antiarrhythmics) do not affect Na^+ channel activity and do not have any effect on phase 0. They instead decrease the slope of phase 4 depolarization.

question_text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-week history of shortness of breath and dull chest pain. She has a history of antiphospholipid syndrome. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. Right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 30 mm Hg and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-week history of shortness of breath and dull chest pain. She has a history of antiphospholipid syndrome. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention. Right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary arterial pressure of 30 mm Hg and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 10 mm Hg. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The presence of jugular venous distention suggests right heart failure, which can manifest with findings such as exertional shortness of breath and chest pain, as seen here. Antiphospholipid syndrome can cause pulmonary embolism, resulting in pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. A mean pulmonary artery pressure ≥ 25 mm Hg at rest confirms the diagnosis of pulmonary hypertension, and a normal PCWP (4–12 mm Hg) excludes left heart failure as the cause.
learning_objective: Recognize right heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension, and recall the expected echocardiographic finding.

answers.content: Constriction of the renal afferent arteriole
answers.explanation_why: In cases of systemic hypoperfusion, reduced renal perfusion results in dilatation of the afferent arteriole via myogenic autoregulation and the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism, as well as constriction of the efferent arteriole via an increase in angiotensin II synthesis. Afferent arteriole dilation and efferent arteriole constriction then work in combination to maintain a constant GFR despite decreased cardiac output. Right heart failure is a condition that can cause systemic hypoperfusion. For this reason dilatation (not constriction) of the renal afferent arteriole would rather be expected in this patient.

Right heart failure due to pulmonary hypertension involves increased afterload of the right ventricle, resulting in reduced right ventricular output. Reduced right-sided cardiac output leads to venous congestion in the vessels that drain into the right heart, including the coronary sinus, which can become dilated as a result.

images.title: Coronary veins
images.description:
The coronary sinus is the largest vein of the heart. It lies in the left posterior atrioventricular groove and opens into the right atrium.

Main tributaries of the coronary sinus:
- Great cardiac vein: lies in the left anterior atrioventricular groove; receives the anterior interventricular vein that begins at the cardiac apex
- Small cardiac vein: lies in the right posterior atrioventricular groove; receives the right marginal vein and the anterior veins of the right ventricle
- Middle cardiac vein: lies in the posterior interventricular groove
- Posterior vein(s) of the left ventricle: lies to the left of the middle cardiac vein

answers.explanation_why: Decreased left ventricular contractility is the hallmark of systolic left heart failure. Although left heart failure can lead to right heart failure, PCWP is typically elevated in left heart failure (> 18 mm Hg). This patient's normal PCWP makes left heart failure unlikely.

Mitral valve leaflet thickening can occur in mitral valve diseases such as mitral stenosis (e.g., due to rheumatic fever). Mitral valve disease usually results in increased left atrial pressure and therefore increased PCWP, whereas PCWP is normal in this patient.

Hemosiderin-laden macrophages (heart failure cells) are typically seen in the alveoli of patients with chronic pulmonary congestion due to blood leakage into the alveolar spaces. Conditions that cause chronic pulmonary venous congestion include left heart failure and mitral stenosis. PCWP is typically elevated in left heart failure and mitral stenosis, whereas it is normal in this patient.

images.title: Heart failure cells in decompensated heart failure
images.description: Photomicrograph of lung tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)Accumulations of hemosiderin-laden macrophages, known as siderophages (examples indicated by blue overlay), are visible within alveoli. Additionally, alveoli filled with erythrocytes (examples indicated by yellow overlay) can be seen.Siderophages in pulmonary alveoli (heart failure cells) suggest decompensated heart failure.

question_text: A 52-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of substernal chest pain on exertion that is relieved with rest. His pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 145/82 mm Hg. He is prescribed a drug that acts by forming free radical nitric oxide. The patient is most likely to experience which of the following adverse effects as a result of this drug?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of substernal chest pain on exertion that is relieved with rest. His pulse is 82/min and blood pressure is 145/82 mm Hg. He is prescribed a drug that acts by forming free radical nitric oxide. The patient is most likely to experience which of the following adverse effects as a result of this drug?
hint: Nitrates work by forming free radical nitric oxide, which leads to smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation.
learning_objective: Recall the common adverse effects of nitrates.

answers.explanation_why:
Headaches are a common side effect of nitrates and affect approx. 10% of patients. These headaches are either mild-to-moderate and occur immediately after drug administration (due to nitric oxide-induced vasodilation) or migraine-like, occurring several hours after drug intake (due to nitric oxide-mediated release of neurotransmitters such as calcitonin gene-related peptide and glutamate, and/or altered ion channel function). Nitrate-induced vasodilation decreases both preload and afterload and improves myocardial perfusion, but may also result in cutaneous flushing and hypotension.

Other adverse effects include gastroesophageal reflux and reflex tachycardia, the latter of which can be treated with beta blockers.

Digital vasospasm (secondary Raynaud phenomenon) is a potential side effect of beta blockers. This side effect is mediated by the blockade of β_2-receptors, which causes vasoconstriction. Nitrates do not cause digital vasospasm.

Nitrates can cause hypotension, rather than hypertensive urgency. Nitrates are used to treat hypertensive crisis for short-term reduction of blood pressure and are contraindicated in hypotensive patients.

Nonproductive cough is a side effect of ACE inhibitors. This side effect is due to decreased breakdown of bradykinin, which increases production of arachidonic acid metabolites (e.g., prostaglandins). The accumulation of prostaglandins in the upper respiratory tract and the lungs results in nonproductive cough. Nitrates do not cause cough.

Lupus-like syndrome (drug-induced lupus erythematosus; DILE) is a side effect of antihypertensives, such as hydralazine and methyldopa. Other drugs that can lead to DILE include monoclonal TNF-α inhibitors, such as infliximab or etanercept, procainamide, penicillamine, isoniazid, minocycline, and phenytoin. Nitrates do not cause DILE.

Lower extremity edema is a common side effect of dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCBs), particularly amlodipine. CCBs cause vasodilation, which increases the hydrostatic pressure within the blood vessels, causing extravasation of plasma into the interstitial space. Although nitrates can rarely cause lower extremity edema, it is not the most common side effect associated with this drug class.

Erectile dysfunction is a known side effect of beta blockers, which inhibit β_2-receptors in the vasculature and thereby cause vasoconstriction. Patients taking PDE-5 inhibitors for erectile dysfunction have an increased risk of life-threatening hypotension if nitrates are taken within 24 hours of a PDE-5 inhibitor. Nitrates do not cause erectile dysfunction.

question_text:
An otherwise healthy 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of mild persistent bleeding from the site of a tooth extraction. He has no prior history of medical procedures or surgeries and no history of easy bruising. He appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
12.4 g/dL

Platelets
200,000/mm^3

Serum

Prothrombin time
25 seconds

Partial thromboplastin time (activated)
35 seconds

Deficiency of which of the following coagulation factors is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
content_preview: An otherwise healthy 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of mild persistent bleeding from the site of a tooth extraction. He has no prior history of medical procedures or surgeries and no history of easy bruising. He appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 12.4 g/dL Platelets 200,000/mm3 Serum Prothrombin time 25 seconds Partial thromboplastin time (activated) 35 seconds Deficiency of which of the following coagulation factors is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
hint: The patient's elevated prothrombin time and normal partial thromboplastin time (activated) indicate a coagulation defect in the extrinsic pathway.
learning_objective: Recall the coagulation pathways, and recognize the laboratory findings associated with factor VII deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Factor VII is the only coagulation factor listed here that is part of the extrinsic hemostatic pathway. The extrinsic pathway is activated by traumatic tissue injury, such as this patient's tooth extraction, which exposes tissue factor (factor III) located beneath the endothelium. Factor III then activates factor VII, forming a complex to trigger the common pathway by activating factor X. Hereditary factor VII deficiency is rare and is caused by a mutation of the F7 gene on chromosome 13. Factor VII deficiency presents with features similar to those of hemophilia (factor VIII or factor IX deficiency), such as bleeding following dental extraction and hemarthrosis. However, in patients with factor VII deficiency, the PT would be prolonged (due to an extrinsic pathway defect) and the aPTT would be normal. Conversely, in patients with hemophilia, the aPTT is prolonged (due to an intrinsic pathway defect) and the PT is normal.

Factor V is a coagulation factor of the common pathway. A defect in the common pathway would result in prolongation of both prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). However, only prothrombin time is prolonged in this patient.

Factor II is a coagulation factor of the common pathway. A defect in the common pathway would result in prolongation of both prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). However, only prothrombin time is prolonged in this patient.

Factor XIII is a coagulation factor of the common pathway. Most defects in the common pathway result in prolongation of both prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). However, PT and aPTT only test for the formation of fibrin polymers (i.e., unstable clots) via these pathways – not stable clots. Since factor XIII is involved in covalently crosslinking fibrin to form stable clots, its activity is not reflected in either the PT or aPTT. Therefore, in most cases of factor XIII deficiency, both the PT and aPTT are normal. This patient, however, has a prolonged PT.

Factor X is a coagulation factor of the common pathway. A defect in the common pathway would result in prolongation of both prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). However, only prothrombin time is prolonged in this patient.
