question_text: A 64-year-old man with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of urinary incontinence. The urge to urinate occurs suddenly, and he often is unable to make it to the bathroom before leaking urine. He has no incontinence with coughing or laughing. Digital rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a normal post-void residual volume. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's incontinence?
content_preview: A 64-year-old man with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of urinary incontinence. The urge to urinate occurs suddenly, and he often is unable to make it to the bathroom before leaking urine. He has no incontinence with coughing or laughing. Digital rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a normal post-void residual volume. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's incontinence?
hint: In a patient with multiple sclerosis, a sudden urge to urinate that is not related to increased intra-abdominal pressure is consistent with urge incontinence due to detrusor hyperreflexia (upper motor neuron dysfunction!).
learning_objective: Recognize urge incontinence in multiple sclerosis, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Doxazosin, an alpha-1 antagonist that causes relaxation of the bladder sphincter muscle, is used in the treatment of urinary retention and concomitant overflow incontinence due to an overactive sphincter or BPH. A normal post-void residual volume makes urinary retention unlikely in this patient. This patient with urge incontinence has an overactive bladder with heightened detrusor tone; relaxation of the urinary sphincter could worsen his symptoms.

Bethanechol, a parasympathomimetic agent, is used in the treatment of urinary retention and concomitant overflow incontinence due to an underactive detrusor, which can occasionally occur in patients with multiple sclerosis due to lesions below S1 spinal level. A normal post-void residual volume makes urinary retention unlikely in this patient. This patient with urge incontinence has an overactive bladder with heightened detrusor tone; increasing it further would likely worsen his symptoms.

Midodrine, an alpha-1 agonist that causes contraction of the urinary sphincter and detrusor, is used in the treatment of underactive bladder sphincter (stress incontinence), which can occur in patients with multiple sclerosis due to demyelinating lesions below S1 spinal level. However, stress incontinence presents with dribbling of urine during laughing or coughing, which is not reported in this patient. This patient with urge incontinence already has a heightened detrusor tone; increasing it further would likely worsen his symptoms.
Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that affects the central nervous system (CNS) and is used in the treatment of dementia. Rivastigmine is not used to treat urinary incontinence.

Mirtazapine, an alpha-2 antagonist, is used to treat depression, which often occurs in patients with multiple sclerosis. However, mirtazapine is not used to treat urinary incontinence because alpha-2 adrenergic receptors do not play a role in maintaining urinary continence. An alpha-1 antagonist can be used to treat certain forms of urinary incontinence.

In a healthy individual, bladder wall relaxation due to stimulation of β3 receptors in the detrusor muscle allows storage of urine. During the storage phase, contraction of the trigone and sphincter muscles due to stimulation of α1 receptors at these sites maintains continence. Bladder wall contraction due to stimulation of M3 receptors in the detrusor muscle, and reflex inhibition of the trigone and sphincter allows for micturition to occur during the voiding phase. Muscarinic antagonists (e.g. tolterodine, oxybutynin, solifenacin, dicyclomine) and the newly developed β3 agonists (e.g., mirabegron) relax detrusor muscles, and can therefore be used to treat urge incontinence caused by an overactive detrusor muscle.

question_text: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of episodes of shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and palpitations. During the examination, he reports the onset of one such episode. His pulse is 170/min and regular, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. An ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia; no P waves are visible. A common clinical maneuver to diagnose and/or relieve the patient's symptoms involves stimulation of which of the following nerves?
content_preview: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of episodes of shortness of breath, lightheadedness, and palpitations. During the examination, he reports the onset of one such episode. His pulse is 170/min and regular, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. An ECG shows a regular narrow complex tachycardia; no P waves are visible. A common clinical maneuver to diagnose and/or relieve the patient's symptoms involves stimulation of which of the following nerves?
hint: Intermittent palpitations, lightheadedness, dyspnea, and ECG findings that show a narrow complex tachycardia without P waves are all features of atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia, a type of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Several maneuvers that elicit an autonomic response can be used to diagnose and terminate this cardiac arrhythmia.
learning_objective: Recognize atrioventricular nodal re-entrant tachycardia, and recall the nerve involved in vagal maneuvers.

answers.explanation_why: The parasympathetic fibers of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) supply the salivary glands, the lacrimal glands, and the nasal mucosa. They do not supply the myocardium and will therefore not help to diagnose or relieve this patient's PSVT. In addition, the trigeminal nerve does not lie in close proximity to the carotid sinus.

Although the recurrent laryngeal nerves lie in close proximity to the carotid sinus and branch out from the vagus nerve, they do not participate in the autonomic response that would terminate this patient's PSVT.

The parasympathetic fibers of the facial nerve (CN VII) supply the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands and the lacrimal glands. They do not supply the myocardium and will therefore not help to diagnose or relieve this patient's PSVT. In addition, the facial nerve does not lie in close proximity to the carotid sinus.

Although the phrenic nerves lie in close proximity to the heart and provide sensory supply to the pericardium, they do not provide autonomic supply to the myocardium. Therefore, they will not help to diagnose or relieve this patient's PSVT.

The nerve of the carotid sinus (nerve of Hering) is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) that terminates in the vasomotor center of the medulla oblongata (nucleus tractus solitarius). Carotid sinus massage stimulates baroreceptors, which transmits a signal to the medulla oblongata via CN IX. The efferent signals from the medulla to the myocardium are conducted via the vagus nerve (parasympathetic supply), which results in ↓ AV nodal conduction, ↓ heart rate, ↓ contractility, and vasodilation (↓ blood pressure). This patient's symptoms are caused by AV nodal re-entry; slowing AV nodal conduction terminates the arrhythmia.

Other vagal maneuvers include the Valsalva maneuver and breath holding.

images.title: Baroreceptor and chemoreceptor pathways
images.description: Baroreceptors are stretch receptors that are located in the carotid sinuses and in the aortic arch of the aorta. Baroreceptors sense minute blood pressure (BP) changes and send afferent signals to the brain stem (nucleus tractus solitarius) via the vagus nerve from the aortic arch and the glossopharyngeal nerve from the carotid sinus. The brainstem modulates autonomic outflow to alter the heart rate and peripheral vascular resistance to normalize BP (i.e., ↓ BP → sympathetic stimulation → ↑ HR, ↑ peripheral vascular resistance → ↑ BP; ↑ BP → parasympathetic stimulation → ↓ HR and ↓ peripheral vascular resistance → ↓BP). This pathway is known as the baroreflex.A prolonged decrease in BP also stimulates long-term homeostatic mechanisms of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone pathway (RAAS) and ADH secretion (↑ ADH release → ↓ water excretion by the kidneys → ↑ intravascular volume → ↑ BP).Chemoreceptors detect minute changes in pH and partial pressures of respiratory gases. Peripheral chemoreceptors, located in the carotid body and aortic body, are stimulated by a fall in pH and pO_2 or a rise in pCO_2, which occurs in hypoxia. Chemoreceptors send afferent signals to the brain stem (dorsal respiratory group) via the vagus and glossopharyngeal nerves, which stimulates the respiratory centers of the brain, resulting in an increase in the rate and depth of breathing. Chemoreceptor stimulation also increases the sympathetic outflow to the heart.

question_text: A 75-year-old man with a seizure disorder is brought to the emergency department by a friend because of progressive confusion over the past two weeks. He is unable to provide any history. His vital signs are within normal limits. He appears lethargic and is only oriented to person. Oral mucosa is moist. There is no jugular venous distention. A basic metabolic panel shows a serum sodium concentration of 115 mEq/L but is otherwise normal. Serum osmolality is low and antidiuretic hormone level is elevated. X-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hyponatremia?
content_preview: A 75-year-old man with a seizure disorder is brought to the emergency department by a friend because of progressive confusion over the past two weeks. He is unable to provide any history. His vital signs are within normal limits. He appears lethargic and is only oriented to person. Oral mucosa is moist. There is no jugular venous distention. A basic metabolic panel shows a serum sodium concentration of 115 mEq/L but is otherwise normal. Serum osmolality is low and antidiuretic hormone level is elevated. X-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hyponatremia?
hint: This patient is euvolemic and has a low serum sodium level with high ADH levels, suggesting a diagnosis of SIADH.
learning_objective: Recognize medication effect as a cause of SIADH-related hyponatremia.

answers.explanation_why: Low cardiac output (e.g., due to congestive heart failure) results in hypervolemic hyponatremia due to low renal perfusion and subsequent activation of RAAS and ADH secretion, which in turn stimulates water (and sodium) reabsorption. This patient lacks other signs of low cardiac output, including pitting edema, pulmonary edema, and/or elevated JVP, making this etiology unlikely.

Hyperglycemia (e.g., from type 1 diabetes mellitus) can cause both hypovolemic and/or dilutional hyponatremia. Hypovolemic hyponatremia is a characteristic feature of diabetic ketoacidosis and occurs due to the osmotic diuresis from hyperglycemia and glucosuria. In dilutional hyponatremia, increased serum osmolality from hyperglycemia causes water to shift from the intracellular to the extracellular space, resulting in a decreased serum sodium concentration. This patient's normal metabolic panel and euvolemia on exam make hyponatremia due to hyperglycemia very unlikely.

Aldosterone deficiency (e.g., due to adrenal insufficiency, type 4 RTA, or congenital hypoaldosteronism) can also manifest with hyponatremia and elevated ADH due to decreased sodium resorption in the collecting ducts. This patient does not have characteristic signs or symptoms of aldosterone deficiency, such as hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, or hypotension.

SIADH is an adverse effect of several medications, including carbamazepine, SSRIs, and cyclophosphamide and is characterized by an inappropriately elevated serum ADH despite low plasma osmolality (e.g., the patient is not hypovolemic). Risk factors for developing medication-induced SIADH include older age (> 65 years old), concomitant use of other antiseizure drugs and diuretics, and a history of hyponatremia. Other causes of SIADH include CNS disorders, pulmonary disease, and ectopic production of ADH (e.g., small cell lung cancer).

Increased levels of cortisol (e.g., Cushing syndrome) classically manifest with hypernatremia, not hyponatremia. Other characteristic laboratory findings include hypocalcemia, hyperglycemia, and hypokalemia.

question_text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being stabbed in the left thigh. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm wound overlying a pulsatile mass on the left anterior thigh, 4 cm below the inguinal crease. A thrill is palpated, and a bruit is heard over this area. Peripheral pulses are normal bilaterally. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being stabbed in the left thigh. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm wound overlying a pulsatile mass on the left anterior thigh, 4 cm below the inguinal crease. A thrill is palpated, and a bruit is heard over this area. Peripheral pulses are normal bilaterally. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
hint: This patient has a traumatic arteriovenous fistula, which typically manifests as a pulsatile mass with a palpable thrill and audible bruit.
learning_objective: Recognize traumatic arteriovenous fistula, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: The aneurysmal dilation of an arteriovenous fistula in the anterior thigh 4 cm below the inguinal crease can result in compression of surrounding structures. However, pudendal nerve compression is unlikely given the location of this patient's injury.

High-output cardiac failure can occur following the formation of a traumatic arteriovenous fistula due to the shunting of blood from the arterial high-pressure system to the venous low-pressure system. As a result of this shunt, systemic vascular resistance decreases, which, in turn, results in an increased heart rate, stroke volume, and cardiac output. However, despite increased cardiac output, low systemic vascular resistance results in arterial underfilling, decreased renal perfusion, and retention of water and salt, which leads to volume overload and heart failure.

Although this patient has an increased risk of thrombus development at the site of an arteriovenous fistula, a pulmonary embolism would be an unlikely complication because a dislodged thrombus would travel distally into the affected vein as a result of the reverse blood flow caused by the pressure differential from the arterial to venous systems.

Risk factors for the development of an iliac artery aneurysm include connective tissue disorders, older age, history of smoking, hypertension, and atherosclerosis. The mechanism of this patient's injury could compromise the vascular integrity at the level of the injury but is unlikely to affect the iliac artery given how distal the wound is.

Osteonecrosis of the femoral head can result from trauma to the medial circumflex femoral artery (e.g., from femoral head fracture or lateral or medial femoral neck fracture, especially with dislocation). However, a stab wound in the anterior thigh is unlikely to affect the medial circumflex femoral artery.

question_text: A previously healthy 37-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 29 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of colicky postprandial abdominal pain. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 29-week gestation. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows multiple 5-mm hyperechoic masses within the gallbladder lumen. Which of the following processes is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A previously healthy 37-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 29 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of colicky postprandial abdominal pain. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 29-week gestation. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows multiple 5-mm hyperechoic masses within the gallbladder lumen. Which of the following processes is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
hint: The patient's colicky abdominal pain and multiple small intraluminal gallbladder masses on ultrasound indicate biliary colic due to cholelithiasis. Pregnancy, with its hormonal changes, is a known risk factor for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize cholelithiasis in pregnancy, and recall its pathogenesis related to cholesterol metabolism.

answers.explanation_why: Accelerated gallbladder emptying is not responsible for gallstone formation; conversely, decreased gallbladder motility causes bile stasis and gallstone formation. Gallbladder stasis is seen in pregnancy due to elevated progesterone levels, which can lead to smooth muscle relaxation and bile stasis. Gallbladder stasis can also occur in patients on prolonged total parenteral nutrition.

Production of CCK is increased rather than decreased in pregnancy. CCK promotes secretion of bile acids and stimulates gallbladder contraction after a meal, thereby reducing the likeliness of gallstone formation. However, the overall effect of pregnancy is one of bile stasis. This effect is due to higher progesterone levels, which result in smooth muscle relaxation, impaired gallbladder contraction, and subsequent bile stasis, predisposing to cholelithiasis.

The caliber of bile ducts does not alter significantly during pregnancy when compared to the nonpregnant population. Therefore, it is unlikely involved in the pathogenesis of gallstones in this patient.

images.title: Cholelithiasis, cholangitis, and biliary pancreatitis
images.description:
Cholelithiasis: the presence of gallstones within the gall bladder
Cholangitis: ascending biliary tract infection (orange shading) secondary to choledocholithiasis
Biliary pancreatitis: Pancreatic outflow obstruction secondary to choledocholithiasis allows for activation of pancreatic zymogens, resulting in pancreatic inflammation (orange shading).

answers.explanation_why: An increase in progesterone levels during pregnancy results in decreased, not increased, bile acid secretion. Bile acids are important surfactants that help dissolve cholesterol in bile. Reduced bile acid levels (e.g., in pregnancy, cystic fibrosis, or due to malabsorption in inflammatory bowel disease) can predispose to gallstone formation.

Overproduction of bilirubin is not responsible for the increased risk of cholelithiasis in pregnancy. Increased bilirubin production contributes to black pigment stones in patients with chronic hemolytic anemias, such as hereditary spherocytosis. Hemolysis results in the increased breakdown of hemoglobin to heme and subsequently to bilirubin. Bile supersaturated with bilirubin can precipitate and form gallstones. Gallstones in pregnancy are usually due to a different cause.

images.title: Gallbladder with stones
images.description: The two larger gallstones in the neck of the gallbladder have an irregular consistency and yellowish-white to dark pigmentation, which indicates a high level of cholesterol. The stones located in the body and fundus are significantly smaller, darkly pigmented, and of different shapes, which is more suggestive of pigment stones due to bilirubin precipitation.

answers.explanation_why: Beginning in the third trimester of pregnancy, increased circulating estrogen levels result in an increased hepatic cholesterol synthesis and the formation of cholesterol-supersaturated bile. Moreover, higher progesterone levels cause smooth muscle relaxation, decreased and incomplete emptying of the gallbladder, and subsequent bile stasis. Together, cholesterol-rich lithogenic bile and gallbladder stasis predispose to gallstone formation. Similarly, hormone replacement therapy and oral contraceptive use also predispose to cholelithiasis.

images.title: Bilirubin metabolism
images.description:
(1) Hemoglobin is broken down into heme and globin in the spleen and, to a lesser extent, in the bone marrow.
(2) Macrophages break heme down into unconjugated bilirubin. Bound to albumin, unconjugated bilirubin is transported in the bloodstream and taken up by the liver.
(3) Bilirubin is conjugated in the liver and secreted in bile.
(4) In order to be secreted, conjugated bilirubin enters the blood to reach the hepatocytes with a direct connection to the bile canaliculi. At this stage, conjugated bilirubin is detectable in the blood.
(5) Bilirubin reaches the intestine via the bile. Intestinal bacteria convert bilirubin to urobilinogen.
(6) Most of the urobilinogen is converted into stercobilinogen and then stercobilin. Stercobilin is excreted via the stool, giving it its characteristic brown color.
(7) A smaller portion of urobilinogen is reabsorbed and follows two different paths:
→ (8) Most of it undergoes hepatobiliary recirculation, while the rest is filtrated in the kidney.
→ Or: (9) The remainder gets filtrated in the kidneys. in the urine, urobilinogen is oxidized to urobilin, which is responsible for the characteristic yellow color.

question_text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue, increased urinary frequency, and low back pain. She reports frequent passing of hard stools, despite using stool softeners. During this time, she has not been as involved with her weekly book club. Her family is concerned that she is depressed. She has no history of serious illness. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Her pulse is 71/min and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. The patient's symptoms are most likely caused by hyperplasia of which of the following?
content_preview: A 51-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue, increased urinary frequency, and low back pain. She reports frequent passing of hard stools, despite using stool softeners. During this time, she has not been as involved with her weekly book club. Her family is concerned that she is depressed. She has no history of serious illness. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Her pulse is 71/min and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. The patient's symptoms are most likely caused by hyperplasia of which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with classic features of hypercalcemia such as fatigue, hypertension, polyuria (“thrones”), abdominal and lower back pain (“groans, bones”), costovertebral angle tenderness (renal “stones”), constipation, and depression (“psychiatric overtones”).
learning_objective: Recognize the symptoms of hypercalcemia, and recall the role of parathyroid chief cells in calcium homeostasis.

answers.content: Chief cells in the parathyroid gland
answers.explanation_why: Parathyroid chief cells are the site of parathyroid hormone (PTH) production and secretion. Under physiological conditions, parathyroid chief cells maintain calcium homeostasis through PTH-mediated increases in bone resorption, renal calcium absorption, and phosphate excretion. This patient's hypercalcemia is most likely caused by excessive production and secretion of parathyroid hormone (primary hyperparathyroidism). The most common causes of primary hyperparathyroidism include parathyroid adenoma (approx. 80% of cases) and hyperplasia (approx. 15% of cases).

images.title: Parathyroid chief cells
images.description: Microscopic image of the parathyroid gland (H&E stain, 100x magnification)The parathyroid gland is composed primarily of parathyroid hormone-producing chief cells, whose cytoplasm stains white as a result of their glycogen and lipid stores.Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

answers.content: Chromaffin cells in the adrenal gland
answers.explanation_why: Chromaffin cells in the adrenal gland are the site of catecholamine release (e.g., epinephrine and norepinephrine). Hyperplasia of chromaffin cells is associated with pheochromocytoma, which commonly manifests as hypertension, which is seen here. This patient, however, lacks other classic features of pheochromocytoma, such as paroxysmal headaches, diaphoresis, and palpitations.

answers.content: Chromophobic cells in the pituitary gland
answers.explanation_why: Chromophobic cell hyperplasia in the pituitary gland is typically seen with non-secretory pituitary adenomas. Destruction of normal pituitary tissue by a large pituitary adenoma can lead to reduced production of FSH/LH, GH, ACTH, TSH, and ADH (panhypopituitarism). Hypothyroidism caused by TSH deficiency could result in fatigue, constipation, depression, and musculoskeletal pain. Diabetes inspidius caused by ADH deficiency would result in increased frequency of micturition due to polyuria. However, this patient's hypertension and abdominal pain are not explained by hypopituitarism, and clinical features of a large pituitary tumor (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia, headache) are not present.

answers.content: Parafollicular cells in the thyroid gland
answers.explanation_why: Parafollicular cell hyperplasia is associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, an aggressive thyroid malignancy. Parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland are the site of calcitonin production and secretion. Calcitonin excess, however, is typically asymptomatic. Also, this patient does not have symptoms suggestive of a thyroid malignancy (e.g., thyroid swelling, cervical lymphadenopathy, vocal cord palsy).
answers.explanation_but: Although calcitonin reduces osteoclastic activity and prevents hypercalcemia, an excess of calcitonin is not known to cause hypocalcemia because of the compensatory increase in PTH secretion, which has a greater effect on calcium homeostasis. Rarely, excess calcitonin can result in cutaneous flushing and diarrhea.

answers.explanation_why: Sheets of spindle cells in the kidney can be seen in patients with angiomyolipoma. However, angiomyolipoma is not associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia. Renal cell carcinoma, which can cause paraneoplastic hypercalcemia, is typically characterized by polygonal clear cells on biopsy.

Kulchitsky cells (K cells) are neuroendocrine bronchial cells that can undergo malignant transformation to become small cell lung cancer (SCLC). SCLC is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes, which could explain some of the features seen in this patient (e.g., fatigue due to paraneoplastic SIADH-induced hyponatremia). However, unlike squamous cell lung carcinoma, SCLC is not associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia.

question_text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of successful conception. She and her husband are trying to conceive, and they have had frequent sexual intercourse over the past month. Her menstrual cycles occur at regular 28-day intervals, and her last menstrual period began 25 days ago. Which of the following is the most sensitive test for diagnosing pregnancy at this time?
content_preview: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of successful conception. She and her husband are trying to conceive, and they have had frequent sexual intercourse over the past month. Her menstrual cycles occur at regular 28-day intervals, and her last menstrual period began 25 days ago. Which of the following is the most sensitive test for diagnosing pregnancy at this time?
hint: Ovulation occurs at about day 14 of a regular 28-day cycle, so this patient is approximately 11 days post ovulation.
learning_objective: Recognize the timeline of early pregnancy detection, and choose the most sensitive test for diagnosing pregnancy.

answers.explanation_why:
Serum β-hCG testing is the most sensitive test for detecting early pregnancy. β-hCG is produced by the syncytiotrophoblast to preserve the corpus luteum and can be detected in serum as early as 6–9 days after fertilization. Qualitative serum pregnancy tests can detect β-hCG levels of 5–10 mIU/mL; a quantitative assay can measure values as low as 1–2 mIU/mL.

Serum β-hCG testing is the preferred method to confirm early pregnancy in cases when exclusion of pregnancy is an important factor, such as before administering a drug that can cause teratogenic birth defects.

A diagnosis of pregnancy is possible at this time, as this patient is approximately 11 days post ovulation based on the length of her menstrual cycle. Pregnancy can be detected as early as 6–9 days after fertilization.

Transvaginal ultrasound can detect a gestational sac or intrauterine fluid collection around 3–4 weeks after fertilization (5–6 weeks of gestational age). This patient is approximately 11 days post ovulation based on the length of her menstrual cycle, and transvaginal ultrasound at this time would not be able to detect a pregnancy.

Transabdominal Doppler ultrasound can detect fetal cardiac activity as early as 8–10 weeks after fertilization (10–12 weeks of gestational age). This patient is approximately 11 days post ovulation based on the length of her menstrual cycle. A transabdominal Doppler ultrasound at this time would not be able to detect a pregnancy.

Urine testing can detect β-hCG in the urine around 14 days after fertilization. This patient is approximately 11 days post ovulation based on the length of her menstrual cycle, and a urine pregnancy test could still be negative at this time even if she were pregnant.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 30 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for evaluation of increased urinary frequency. She has no history of major medical illness. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show an increased serum C-peptide concentration. Ultrasonography shows polyhydramnios and a fetus that is large for gestational age. Which of the following hormones is predominantly responsible for the observed laboratory changes in this patient?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 30 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for evaluation of increased urinary frequency. She has no history of major medical illness. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show an increased serum C-peptide concentration. Ultrasonography shows polyhydramnios and a fetus that is large for gestational age. Which of the following hormones is predominantly responsible for the observed laboratory changes in this patient?
hint: An increased serum C-peptide concentration and ultrasound findings of polyhydramnios and macrosomia suggest a diagnosis of gestational diabetes. Hyperglycemia causes osmotic diuresis, which leads to increased urinary frequency.
learning_objective: Recognize gestational diabetes, and recall the role of human placental lactogen.

answers.explanation_why: Estrogen may play a role in the development of gestational diabetes in pregnancy via increased insulin resistance, but it is not predominantly responsible for the increased serum C-peptide concentration in this patient. The main functions of estrogen during pregnancy are to promote uterine growth and proliferation and differentiation of mammary glands.

Human placental lactogen causes pancreatic beta-cell hyperplasia and leads to an increase in insulin (and C-peptide) secretion as well as maternal insulin resistance. This ensures adequate glucose availability for the fetus. If maternal pancreatic function does not overcome insulin resistance, patients can develop gestational diabetes. In response to increased serum glucose concentrations, fetal production of insulin increases, which leads to increased fetal growth (macrosomia) as seen in this case.

Screening for gestational diabetes is recommended for all pregnant women because this condition increases the risk of maternal and fetal complications such as preeclampsia and birth trauma. Most patients are usually asymptomatic. Diagnosis and appropriate therapy of gestational diabetes mellitus can decrease fetal and maternal morbidity.

Thyroxine is not responsible for the increased serum C-peptide concentration in this patient and does not play a role in the development of gestational diabetes mellitus. Thyroxine, produced by the maternal thyroid gland and the fetal thyroid gland after 12 weeks of gestation, is vital for fetal neurologic development and CNS myelination.

Human chorionic gonadotropin is not responsible for the increased serum C-peptide concentration in this patient and does not play a role in the development of gestational diabetes mellitus. The main function of hCG in early pregnancy is to maintain the corpus luteum, which secretes progesterone. Around 7 to 9 weeks of gestation, the placenta becomes the primary producer of progesterone.

Adrenocorticotropic hormone is not responsible for the increased serum C-peptide concentration in this patient and does not play a role in the development of gestational diabetes mellitus. During pregnancy, ACTH stimulates the secretion of glucocorticoids in the maternal adrenal cortex, which promotes surfactant production and the development of striae gravidarum.

Progesterone may play a role in the development of gestational diabetes in pregnancy via increased insulin resistance, but it is not predominantly responsible for the increased serum C-peptide concentration in this patient. The main functions of progesterone during gestation are to maintain pregnancy, prevent menstruation, induces closure of the cervix, inhibit uterine contractions, and stimulate the expression of uterine oxytocin receptors prior to delivery.

question_text: Twenty minutes after delivery of a newborn infant, a 22-year-old woman starts breastfeeding. Initially, the expressed milk is thick and yellowish. Three days later, the mother's breasts swell and the expressed milk becomes thinner and whiter. A decrease in maternal serum concentration of which of the following is most likely responsible for the observed changes in milk production?
content_preview: Twenty minutes after delivery of a newborn infant, a 22-year-old woman starts breastfeeding. Initially, the expressed milk is thick and yellowish. Three days later, the mother's breasts swell and the expressed milk becomes thinner and whiter. A decrease in maternal serum concentration of which of the following is most likely responsible for the observed changes in milk production?
hint: This hormone physiologically stimulates the endometrium to develop a secretory lining during the menstrual cycle.
learning_objective: Recall the hormonal regulation of lactogenesis postpartum.

answers.explanation_why: Levels of estrogen rise gradually during pregnancy and are required for differentiation and growth of the uterus, breast tissue, and the mammary glands. High circulating levels of estrogen contribute to the suppression of milk production during late pregnancy. Although levels of estrogen decline in the postpartum period, this is not the primary mechanism responsible for the observed changes in milk production.

Oxytocin stimulates the myoepithelial cells in the breast parenchyma to contract and aids in milk secretion. Oxytocin levels increase during and after delivery and also facilitate uterine contractions. Increased, rather than decreased, levels of this hormone facilitate the milk-let-down reflex.

Following implantation, the cells of the syncytiotrophoblasts produce hCG, which is one of the earliest signs that implantation has occurred. This hormone plays a crucial role during early pregnancy, as it triggers the corpus luteum to continue secretion of progesterone until the placenta takes over at around 8–12 weeks' gestation. The level of hCG rises rapidly during the first trimester and gradually declines after that. It has no functional role in lactogenesis.

Prolactin is responsible for milk production in the mammary glands. Prolactin levels increase steadily during pregnancy and reach their peak by the time of delivery. Elevated, rather than decreased, levels of this hormone correlate with milk production.

Thyroxine contributes to growth and hypertrophy of the breast tissue during pregnancy. Additionally, thyroxine indirectly inhibits prolactin secretion through a negative feedback mechanism on the secretion of thyroid releasing hormone. However, thyroxine is not directly involved in lactation and levels do not vary significantly during and/or after pregnancy.

Lactogenesis is the process of milk production during pregnancy and is comprised of two stages: secretory initiation (stage I) and secretory activation (stage II). Secretory initiation occurs during the second half of pregnancy, when high levels of circulating progesterone directly inhibit prolactin-induced milk production. Delivery of the placenta causes a rapid decline in progesterone. This decline triggers secretion of high levels of prolactin, cortisol, and insulin, which propel the second stage of lactogenesis. Secretory activation usually occurs on the second or third day post-partum and is marked by breast swelling and copious milk production.

Occasionally, retained pieces of placenta may result in difficulty with lactation due to the ongoing production of progesterone.

question_text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of urinary hesitancy and poor urinary stream. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, nontender prostate. Serum studies show a prostate-specific antigen concentration of 2 ng/mL (N < 4). Pharmacotherapy with finasteride is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug?
content_preview: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of urinary hesitancy and poor urinary stream. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, nontender prostate. Serum studies show a prostate-specific antigen concentration of 2 ng/mL (N < 4). Pharmacotherapy with finasteride is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug?
hint: Finasteride is a 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), the most likely diagnosis in this patient with obstructive lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and a symmetrically enlarged, nontender prostate.
learning_objective: Recognize the therapeutic use of finasteride, and recall its mechanism of action.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased bladder neck and internal urethral sphincter tone is an effect of tamsulosin and other alpha-1 antagonists, which are also used as first-line agents in the treatment of BPH. Decreased tone results in decreased resistance to urinary outflow, which in turn improves LUTS. However, finasteride treats the symptoms of BPH by another mechanism.

Increased prostatic apoptosis is an effect of finasteride and other 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors (e.g., dutasteride), which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). DHT is the main androgen of prostate growth and the pathogenesis of BPH. Treatment with finasteride results in lower intraprostatic DHT, inhibited prostatic growth, apoptosis, and involution, which can reduce prostate volume by up to 30% in men with BPH and relieve LUTS. 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors also reduce PSA levels by approx. 50%, which must be considered when screening for prostate cancer. They are especially beneficial in men with large prostate volumes but may take > 6 months to become effective. For this reason, alpha-1 antagonists are usually preferred for rapid improvement of symptoms.

Decreased production of urine is not an effect of 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors such as finasteride. It is, however, part of the behavioral treatment of BPH in that patients are advised through lifestyle modifications to decrease their urinary volume (e.g., restricting fluid intake before bed and before going out, reducing alcohol and caffeine consumption).

PDE inhibitors (e.g., tadalafil, sildenafil) act in ED to increase blood flow by inhibiting the degradation of cGMP, leading to smooth muscle relaxation, increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum, and increased penis size during erection. Tadalafil is currently approved for use in the treatment of BPH with comorbid erectile dysfunction (ED), which this patient does not have. The precise mechanism by which tadalafil reduces LUTS in BPH remains unknown, but increased cGMP concentrations in the bladder and prostate smooth muscle are likely to play a role. Finasteride treats the symptoms of BPH by another mechanism.

images.title: Mechanism of action: nitrates and phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors
images.description: Exogenous nitrous oxide (NO) activates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in activation of protein kinase G. There is a reduction in intracellular calcium as a result of increased sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and an increase in myosin-light-chain-phosphatase (MLCP) activity, resulting in smooth muscle relaxation. The net result of both pathways is vasodilation.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased bladder contractions and reduced muscle spasms of the bladder and urinary tract are effects of anticholinergics such as oxybutynin or tolterodine. These agents work in BPH by antagonizing muscarinic receptors in the smooth muscle of the detrusor. They are used to treat patients with primarily irritative LUTS (e.g., polyuria, nocturia, urgency, and dysuria) and would not be used in this patient with obstructive LUTS because the decreased detrusor tone could exacerbate urinary retention. Finasteride treats the symptoms of BPH by another mechanism.

question_text: A 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department with acute-onset, sharp, left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has no history of recent trauma. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 3 years. He is 196 cm (6 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows reduced breath sounds over the left lung field. There is hyperresonance on percussion of the left upper thorax. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following changes is most likely to immediately result from this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department with acute-onset, sharp, left-sided chest pain and shortness of breath. He has no history of recent trauma. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 3 years. He is 196 cm (6 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination shows reduced breath sounds over the left lung field. There is hyperresonance on percussion of the left upper thorax. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following changes is most likely to immediately result from this patient's current condition?
hint: A tall, slender young man with nontraumatic, sudden, unilateral chest pain and dyspnea most likely has a primary spontaneous pneumothorax. Imaging confirms pneumothorax and the absence of any rib fractures.
learning_objective: Recognize primary spontaneous pneumothorax, and recall its immediate physiological consequence.

answers.explanation_why: Transpulmonary pressure is the difference between intra-alveolar pressure and intrapleural pressure. In pneumothorax, the pressure in the pleural space increases due to the presence of air, leading to diminished, not increased, transpulmonary pressure.

images.title: Intrapulmonary and intrapleural pressure during respiration
images.description: Static compliance is a measure of elastic airway resistance without changes in airflow, while dynamic compliance is a measure of airway resistance during times of airflow. Inspiration requires a negative intrapulmonary pressure, which is achieved through expansion of the lungs via contraction of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles. During exhalation, the intrapulmonary pressure becomes positive as the elastic recoil of the thoracic wall compresses the lungs and expels the inhaled air.

answers.explanation_why: Intra-alveolar pressure would be unchanged or even decreased in pneumothorax. Conditions involving increased intra-alveolar pressure include obstructive lung diseases (e.g., COPD, asthma) and mechanical ventilation with increased positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).

images.title: Intrapulmonary and intrapleural pressure during respiration
images.description: Static compliance is a measure of elastic airway resistance without changes in airflow, while dynamic compliance is a measure of airway resistance during times of airflow. Inspiration requires a negative intrapulmonary pressure, which is achieved through expansion of the lungs via contraction of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles. During exhalation, the intrapulmonary pressure becomes positive as the elastic recoil of the thoracic wall compresses the lungs and expels the inhaled air.

answers.explanation_why: Dead space increases in conditions in which alveoli are ventilated but not perfused (e.g., pulmonary embolism). Normal or decreased physiological dead space would be expected in pneumothorax.

images.title: Anatomical vs. alveolar dead space (minute ventilation)
images.description: The physiologic dead space (V_D) consists of the volume of air in the conducting airways (i.e., anatomic dead space) and the sum of alveolar volumes that do not participate in gas exchange (i.e., alveolar dead space). In a healthy lung, anatomical dead space is almost equal to V_D because alveolar dead space is negligible. In diseases that result in a mismatch in lung ventilation/perfusion ratio (e.g., pulmonary embolism), alveolar dead space is increased, resulting in reduced alveolar ventilation (the volume of gas that reaches the alveoli each minute).

answers.explanation_why:
Increased right-to-left pulmonary shunting is likely to be an immediate result of primary spontaneous pneumothorax. In this functional right-to-left shunt, alveoli in collapsed lung areas are not ventilated but are still perfused with deoxygenated blood from the right heart. Perfusion of the nonventilated alveoli results in decreased oxygenation of blood flowing to the left heart (right-to-left pulmonary shunting) and hypoxia.

As a physiological response to hypoxia, reflex vasoconstriction occurs in the pulmonary arterial branches supplying poorly ventilated regions. This hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction minimizes ventilation-perfusion mismatch and reduces pulmonary shunting in small ventilation defects, but is unable to prevent hypoxemia in pneumothorax.

images.title: Ventilation/perfusion mismatch (V/Q mismatch)
images.description: Pathologic lung conditions can alter V/Q ratios.Decreased ventilation leads to shunt perfusion (wasted perfusion) and a low V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no ventilation left (V = 0), V/Q ratio equals zero.Decreased perfusion leads to dead space ventilation (wasted ventilation) and a high V/Q ratio. In lung areas with no perfusion left (Q = 0), V/Q ratio equals infinity.

answers.explanation_why: Increased lung compliance would be expected in a patient with emphysema. Though rupture of emphysematous bullae could result in a secondary pneumothorax, this patient most likely has a primary spontaneous pneumothorax because he is tall, slim, and does not have evidence of emphysematous changes (e.g., hyperinflation, bullae) in the right lung field. Lung compliance is not affected in a patient with primary spontaneous pneumothorax, which is not associated with underlying lung disease.

images.title: Static pressure-volume curve
images.description:
The combination of the static pressure-volume curve of the lung (blue line) and the thorax (orange line) form the static pressure-volume curve of the entire respiratory tract (purple line). The pressure-volume relationship applies to passive changes in the lung volume with relaxed respiratory muscles.All of the curves run in an S-like shape. However, in normal respiration, the shape is only noticeable in the curve of the entire respiratory tract (purple). In each of the curves, the compliance is highest at the steepest part of the curve (advantageous for resting breathing).
At the upper white dot, where the static pressure-volume curve of the thorax passes by 0 in pressure, the thorax is in resting position. At the lower white dot, where the static pressure-volume curve of the respiratory tract passes by 0 in pressure, the elastic forces of the thorax and of the lung are balanced (respiratory rest position).With maximum expiration, the static pressure-volume curve of the lung reaches 0 in pressure. Negative qualities would only occur with a collapse of the alveoli.TV=tidal volume; FRC=functional residual capacity; VC=vital capacity; RV=residual volume

images.title: Pneumothorax without tension
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)A thin white line represents the visceral pleura of the left lung (dotted line). No lung markings are seen peripheral to the visceral pleura (green overlay).The appearance is consistent with a left pneumothorax. There is no evidence of contralateral mediastinal shift, diaphragmatic depression, or ipsilateral intercostal space widening to suggest tension pneumothorax.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for the evaluation of progressive breathlessness. She has no history of major medical illness. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 22/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Cardiac examination shows a loud S_1 and S_2. There is a grade 2/6 early systolic murmur best heard in the 2^nd right intercostal space. Cardiac catheterization shows a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 55% (N = 65–70). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's breathlessness?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for the evaluation of progressive breathlessness. She has no history of major medical illness. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 22/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. Cardiac examination shows a loud S1 and S2. There is a grade 2/6 early systolic murmur best heard in the 2nd right intercostal space. Cardiac catheterization shows a mixed venous oxygen saturation of 55% (N = 65–70). Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's breathlessness?
hint: Mixed oxygen venous saturation (SvO_2) is the oxygen saturation in the pulmonary artery. This is a measure of the oxygen content in the venous system compared to pulse oximetry, which is often used as a surrogate for arterial hemoglobin saturation (S_aO_2)
learning_objective: Recognize severe anemia as a cause of dyspnea.

answers.explanation_why: Carbon dioxide retention is increased in hypoventilation or lung disease and can cause dyspnea, tachycardia, and occasionally, evidence of hyperdynamic circulation (e.g., loud S_1/S_2, ejection systolic murmur). A low mixed venous oxygen saturation can be seen during an exacerbation of lung disease or extreme hypoventilation. However, oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry would also be low.

Severe aortic stenosis, which causes a decreased left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), can present with dyspnea, a soft S_2, a systolic murmur in the 2^nd right intercostal space (aortic area), and a decreased mixed venous oxygen saturation due to decreased cardiac output and increased tissue O_2 extraction. However, aortic stenosis produces a mid-to-late systolic murmur instead of the early murmur in this patient and it does not explain this patient's loud S_1. In this patient with evidence of hyperdynamic circulation, the LVEF would most likely be increased.

Increased peripheral shunting due to AV fistulas can present with tachycardia and evidence of hyperdynamic circulation (e.g., loud S_1/S_2, ejection systolic murmur). However, shunting would cause the oxygenated blood to bypass the tissues and enter the veins, leading to an increase in mixed venous oxygen saturation, not a decrease.

Increased pulmonary vascular resistance is seen in pulmonary hypertension, which can cause a loud S_2 in the second intercostal space as well as a decreased mixed venous oxygen saturation (S_vO_2). However, the loud S_2 would be due to a loud P_2 and would, therefore, be heard best at the left 2^nd intercostal space (pulmonary area). Moreover, if S_vO_2 was decreased in a patient with pulmonary hypertension, the oxygen saturation would also be decreased. Also, pulmonary hypertension alone does not explain the loud S_1 and the murmur in this patient.

Dyspnea, tachycardia, and evidence of hyperdynamic circulation (e.g., loud S_1/S_2, systolic ejection murmur due to increased blood flow) are features of severe anemia. In patients with anemia, the arterial partial pressure of oxygen (P_aO_2), which reflects dissolved oxygen content, and the arterial hemoglobin oxygen saturation (S_aO_2) remain normal. However, the total arterial oxygen content (C_aO_2), which is given by the formula [1.34 x S_aO_2 x hemoglobin concentration] + [0.003 x P_aO_2]), would be decreased because the total hemoglobin concentration is decreased. Therefore, the amount of oxygen delivered to tissues (DO_2) is decreased and tissues extract more oxygen per gram of hemoglobin in order to meet the metabolic demands (VO_2). This results in a decreased hemoglobin oxygen saturation in venous blood, which is measured by S_vO_2.
answers.explanation_but: Other causes of decreased S_vO_2 include decreased DO_2 due to hypoxemia caused by a lung disease, increased tissue O_2 extraction due to decreased cardiac output (e.g., heart failure, hypovolemic shock), increased VO_2 (e.g., exercise, high fever, seizures), and an inability of hemoglobin to bind to O_2 (e.g., carbon monoxide poisoning). If S_vO_2 is decreased as a result of decreased cardiac output or increased VO_2, S_aO_2 would usually be normal. However, pulse oximetry may erroneously show a decreased oxygen saturation in the case of decreased cardiac output because of poor peripheral circulation. If S_vO_2 is decreased as a result of lung disease or carbon monoxide poisoning, S_aO_2 would also be decreased. However, pulse oximetry may erroneously show a normal oxygen saturation in the case of carbon monoxide poisoning because carboxyhemoglobin has a cherry red color. Estimation of true S_aO_2 requires arterial blood gas analysis.

question_text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. She reports increased urinary frequency but otherwise feels well. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 16-week gestation. Urinalysis shows mild glucosuria. Laboratory studies show a non-fasting serum glucose concentration of 100 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's glucosuria?
content_preview: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. She reports increased urinary frequency but otherwise feels well. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 16-week gestation. Urinalysis shows mild glucosuria. Laboratory studies show a non-fasting serum glucose concentration of 100 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's glucosuria?
hint: The change responsible for this woman's glucosuria is physiological during pregnancy.
learning_objective: Recall the physiological changes in pregnancy affecting renal function, and recall the cause of glucosuria in this context.

answers.explanation_why: Insulin production increases during pregnancy to compensate for the action of human placental lactogen, which causes maternal insulin resistance to ensure that glucose is directed to the fetus. Patients who produce insufficient insulin can develop gestational diabetes; however, patients with this condition typically have higher serum blood glucose concentrations.
A mutation or decreased expression of SGLT2 could prevent renal tubular glucose reabsorption, resulting in glucosuria. However, pregnancy does not alter the expression of SGLT2.

Increased glomerular filtration barrier permeability is seen in glomerular diseases (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, nephritic syndrome, diabetic nephropathy) and can cause glucosuria. However, glomerular diseases typically also cause microalbuminuria, proteinuria, hematuria, dysmorphic red blood cells, and/or tubular casts that can be seen on urinalysis, which this patient does not have.

Insulin sensitivity decreases due to the action of human placental lactogen, which causes maternal insulin resistance to ensure that glucose is directed to the fetus. Although decreased insulin sensitivity can result in glucosuria in patients who develop gestational diabetes, these patients typically have abnormal serum blood glucose concentrations.

Increased glomerular filtration rate is normal during pregnancy and leads to mild glucosuria even in patients with normal serum blood glucose concentrations. This change is caused by secretion of relaxin and progesterone during pregnancy, which causes significant vasodilation, decreasing systemic vascular resistance, increasing cardiac output, and increasing renal blood flow. Increased amounts of solutes enter the renal tubules and overload sodium/glucose cotransporters (SGLT2), which results in glucosuria.

question_text:
A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of high fever and confusion for the past 10 hours. His wife reports that 1 week ago during a trip to Guatemala he underwent an emergency appendectomy. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 132/min, and blood pressure is 74/46 mm Hg. He is oriented only to person. Physical examination shows a surgical wound in the right lower quadrant with purulent discharge. The skin is warm and dry. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 138 mEq/L, potassium concentration of 3.7 mEq/L, and lactate concentration of 3.5 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.21

PCO_2
36 mm Hg

HCO_3^-
14 mEq/L

O_2 saturation
87%

Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory changes?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of high fever and confusion for the past 10 hours. His wife reports that 1 week ago during a trip to Guatemala he underwent an emergency appendectomy. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F), pulse is 132/min, and blood pressure is 74/46 mm Hg. He is oriented only to person. Physical examination shows a surgical wound in the right lower quadrant with purulent discharge. The skin is warm and dry. Serum studies show a sodium concentration of 138 mEq/L, potassium concentration of 3.7 mEq/L, and lactate concentration of 3.5 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2). Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.21 PCO2 36 mm Hg HCO3- 14 mEq/L O2 saturation 87% Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these laboratory changes?
hint: This patient has clinical features of septic shock (e.g., fever, tachycardia, hypotension, warm and dry skin) due to infection of his appendectomy surgical site. His metabolic acidosis is likely due to the accumulation of lactic acid from septic shock. Assess for appropriate compensation using the Winter formula: expected pCO_2  = (1.5 x HCO_3^-) + 8 (± 2).
learning_objective: Recognize respiratory fatigue in septic shock.

answers.explanation_why: Hyperventilation results in respiratory alkalosis, which manifests with a lower-than-expected pCO_2. This patient's pCO_2 is higher than predicted by the Winter formula.

Patients with primary adrenal insufficiency who experience an acute stressor, such as a serious infection, have an increased risk of developing shock as a result of adrenal crisis. However, primary adrenal insufficiency typically causes hyponatremia and hyperkalemia (due to hypoaldosteronism), which are not seen here. Additionally, this patient's pCO_2 is higher than predicted by the Winter formula, which indicates a secondary acid-base disturbance. Primary adrenal insufficiency would not cause this secondary disturbance.

Salicylate toxicity typically presents with hyperthermia, altered mental status, and metabolic acidosis. However, salicylates also cause respiratory alkalosis (due to increased respiratory rate resulting from activation of the respiratory center of the medulla), which manifests with a lower-than-expected pCO_2 value. This patient's pCO_2, however, is higher than predicted by the Winter formula.

Per the Winter formula, a pCO_2  of 27–31 mm Hg would reflect an appropriate respiratory compensation for this patient's metabolic acidosis. Instead, this patient's pCO_2 is 36 mm Hg, which indicates the presence of a respiratory acidosis in addition to the metabolic acidosis. Respiratory acidosis is caused by hypoventilation (e.g., from respiratory fatigue in critically ill patients), which leads to CO_2 retention.

Diabetic ketoacidosis can cause hypotension and altered mental status, as seen in this patient, and is often precipitated by an infection. DKA is the initial manifestation of type 1 diabetes mellitus in approximately 30% of cases. However, hallmark symptoms of DKA (e.g., polyuria, polydipsia, nausea, and vomiting) are not seen here. Also, this patient's pCO_2 is higher than the Winter formula would predict. DKA often manifests with hyperventilation, which leads to a lower-than-expected pCO_2.

question_text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment. Three weeks ago he underwent emergency cardiac catheterization because of myocardial infarction. He was hospitalized longer than expected because of decreased kidney function. The patient says his symptoms have since improved greatly. He is now urinating significantly more than before the procedure. His serum creatinine concentration is 1.6 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen concentration is 20 mg/dL. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up appointment. Three weeks ago he underwent emergency cardiac catheterization because of myocardial infarction. He was hospitalized longer than expected because of decreased kidney function. The patient says his symptoms have since improved greatly. He is now urinating significantly more than before the procedure. His serum creatinine concentration is 1.6 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen concentration is 20 mg/dL. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
hint: This patient has most likely developed acute kidney injury (AKI) as a result of contrast-induced nephropathy (due to cardiac catheterization) and possibly renal ischemia due to myocardial infarction. The onset of polyuria three weeks after the development of AKI is consistent with the polyuric phase of AKI.
learning_objective: Recognize the polyuric phase of acute kidney injury, and recall its associated electrolyte abnormalities.

answers.explanation_why: Three weeks after exposure to contrast, this patient is in the polyuric phase of AKI and is actually at risk for hypomagnesemia, rather than hypermagnesemia. During this period, patients lose several electrolytes that are normally reabsorbed by the tubules, including magnesium, into the urine.

Three weeks after exposure to contrast, this patient is in the polyuric phase of AKI. During this period, patients have difficulty excreting H^+ ions and regenerating bicarbonate (a function of the tubular system), putting them at risk for metabolic acidosis, rather than alkalosis.

Three weeks after exposure to contrast, this patient is in the polyuric phase of AKI and is actually at risk for hyponatremia, rather than hypernatremia. During this period, patients lose several electrolytes that are normally reabsorbed by the tubules, including sodium, into the urine.

Patients with AKI usually regain full glomerular filtration function approx. 2 weeks after the inciting event, while tubular reabsorption remains impaired, which results in increased urine production and consequent polyuria. The polyuric phase of AKI is characterized by the loss of several electrolytes that are normally reabsorbed by the tubules, including potassium, sodium, and magnesium.

Patients in the polyuric phase of AKI are at risk for volume depletion, a state in which GFR and sodium delivery to the distal nephrons decreases, causing the release of renin. Therefore, this patient would actually have an increase in renin release.

question_text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath with exertion and intermittent palpitations over the last 2 months. She has had neither chest pain nor a cough. Her pulse is 124/min and irregular. Physical examination shows a grade 4/6 high-pitched holosystolic murmur that is best heard at the apex and radiates to the back. The murmur increases in intensity when she clenches her hands into fists. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath with exertion and intermittent palpitations over the last 2 months. She has had neither chest pain nor a cough. Her pulse is 124/min and irregular. Physical examination shows a grade 4/6 high-pitched holosystolic murmur that is best heard at the apex and radiates to the back. The murmur increases in intensity when she clenches her hands into fists. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: A high-pitched, holosystolic murmur at the apex with radiation to the back and higher intensity with increased systemic vascular resistance (hand grip, squatting) in a patient with exertional dyspnea is characteristic of mitral regurgitation.
learning_objective: Recognize mitral regurgitation, and recall its echocardiographic findings.

answers.content: Pulmonary artery thrombus on computed tomography scan
answers.explanation_why: A pulmonary artery thrombus on CT is seen in pulmonary embolism (PE). While this condition can cause dyspnea, it typically manifests with an acute onset of cough, chest pain, hypotension, and jugular venous distention. This patient's 2-month history of progressive shortness of breath and absence of chest pain and cough make this diagnosis unlikely.

Diffuse ST elevations on ECG suggest acute pericarditis, which can cause dyspnea, as seen in this patient. However, this condition manifests with an acute onset of severe chest pain that is relieved by sitting up and leaning forward, and a pericardial friction rub on cardiac auscultation, neither of which are present.

answers.content: Obstruction of the right marginal artery on coronary angiogram
answers.explanation_why: Obstruction of the right marginal artery on a coronary angiogram is consistent with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), which typically presents with acute retrosternal chest pain/pressure, radiation to the jaw and/or left arm, shortness of breath, and nausea/vomiting. It also produces symptoms of right-sided heart failure due to reduced blood supply of the right ventricle, such as jugular venous distention. However, these symptoms are not present here, and this patient's progressive 2-month history of increasing dyspnea makes this diagnosis unlikely. Also, a significant systolic murmur characteristic of mitral regurgitation requires a different diagnostic method than an angiogram.

answers.content: Reversible area of myocardial ischemia on nuclear stress test
answers.explanation_why: Reversible myocardial ischemia due to CAD can be diagnosed by a nuclear stress test that includes myocardial perfusion imaging (MIBI). While this condition also causes shortness of breath, it typically presents with an acute onset of retrosternal pain/pressure that may radiate to the jaw and/or left arm, and autonomic symptoms such as sweating, pallor, and nausea/vomiting, which are not present here.

answers.content: Dilation of left atrium on echocardiogram
answers.explanation_why: Dilatation of the left atrium (LA) results from volume and pressure overload due to chronic mitral regurgitation (MR) in this patient. LA enlargement can cause atrial fibrillation, which explains the tachycardia and irregular heartbeat seen here. Echocardiography would be the best diagnostic method for visualizing the suspected structural and flow abnormalities of MR.

images.title: Heart murmur in ventricular septal defect, mitral regurgitation, and tricuspid regurgitation
images.description: Holosystolic murmur (often referred to as “pansystolic murmur” in the case of a ventricular septal defect)

question_text: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sharp pain in his left flank that began suddenly 30 minutes ago. Physical examination shows costovertebral angle tenderness on the left side. A photomicrograph of the urine is shown. The patient is most likely to benefit from an increase of which of the following components in the urine?
content_preview: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sharp pain in his left flank that began suddenly 30 minutes ago. Physical examination shows costovertebral angle tenderness on the left side. A photomicrograph of the urine is shown. The patient is most likely to benefit from an increase of which of the following components in the urine?
hint: This patient presents with flank pain radiating to the groin and costovertebral angle tenderness, indicating nephrolithiasis. Urinalysis shows “envelope-shaped” crystals, which are associated with calcium oxalate stones.
learning_objective: Recognize nephrolithiasis, and recall the role of citrate in stone prevention.

answers.explanation_why: An elevated urine sodium increases the risk of stone formation. Calcium is passively reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule with sodium and water. Therefore, a high serum sodium concentration will lead to decreased sodium reabsorption in the tubules, and both a parallel reduction in calcium transport and an increase of calcium excretion. In fact, patients with recurrent calcium stones are often recommended low-sodium diets to enhance sodium (and calcium) reabsorption.

Hypocitraturia is a risk factor for the development of calcium oxalate stones. Calcium and citrate combine in the tubular lumen to form a soluble complex, which results in less free calcium available to combine with oxalate. An increase in urinary citrate through drug therapy or dietary modifications would be beneficial in this patient to reduce the risk of further stone formation.

See “Overview of kidney stones” table.

An increase in H+ ions would not be beneficial in this patient because acidic urine promotes the formation of calcium oxalate stones. In fact, urinary alkalinization (through dietary modification or medications) can be used as a treatment in patients with recurrent calcium oxalate stones.
An increase in urine oxalate excretion would further exacerbate this patient's calcium oxalate stones.
An increase in urinary phosphate would likely increase the risk of further stone formation since the majority of calcium oxalate stones are composed of some combination of phosphate.

images.title: Calcium oxalate crystals in urine
images.description: Photomicrograph of a urine sample (urine sediment wet mount, intermediate magnification)Multiple envelope-shaped crystals can be seen (cf. illustration; examples indicated by yellow overlay) throughout the sample. These are composed of calcium oxalate dihydrate and have an octahedral structure.

question_text: One month after undergoing surgical spinal fusion because of a traumatic spinal cord injury, a 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of lower abdominal pain. He last voided yesterday. Physical examination shows a suprapubic mass and decreased sensation below the umbilicus. Urodynamic studies show simultaneous contractions of the detrusor muscle and the internal urethral sphincter. Urinary catheterization drains 900 mL of urine from the bladder. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient’s urinary symptoms?
content_preview: One month after undergoing surgical spinal fusion because of a traumatic spinal cord injury, a 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of lower abdominal pain. He last voided yesterday. Physical examination shows a suprapubic mass and decreased sensation below the umbilicus. Urodynamic studies show simultaneous contractions of the detrusor muscle and the internal urethral sphincter. Urinary catheterization drains 900 mL of urine from the bladder. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient’s urinary symptoms?
hint: This patient has signs and symptoms of spastic neurogenic bladder (detrusor sphincter dyssynergia) with urinary retention following spinal cord injury. Appropriate pharmacotherapy would involve inhibition of the detrusor and sphincter muscle.
learning_objective: Recognize spastic neurogenic bladder, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Neostigmine can be used to treat the detrusor muscle hypomotility seen in flaccid neurogenic bladder or postoperative urinary retention. In these cases, the addition of an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor will allow more endogenous acetylcholine to stimulate the M3 receptors in the bladder and cause detrusor contraction. Neostigmine would exacerbate this patient's spastic detrusor muscle activity.

Finasteride is used to treat bladder outlet obstruction due to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), as it decreases the size of the prostate. This man is at risk of having BPH, which is common in men > 50 years of age and can cause urinary retention. However, BPH typically has a gradual onset and rarely manifests with acute urinary retention as severe as seen in this patient. Finasteride has no effects on detrusor muscle activity or urinary sphincter contraction and would not be effective for the spastic neurogenic bladder seen in this patient.

Phenylephrine is a sympathomimetic alpha-1 agonist, which would increase the smooth muscle tone at the neck of the bladder and the internal urethral sphincter, thereby inducing urinary retention. Phenylephrine would be contraindicated in this patient with an already overactive sphincter muscle and spastic neurogenic bladder.

Bethanechol can be used to treat bladder hypomotility seen in flaccid neurogenic bladder or postoperative urinary retention. In these cases, the detrusor muscle is not contracting properly, and the addition of a muscarinic agonist will stimulate M3 receptors in the bladder, causing detrusor contraction and improved urinary outflow. This patient's urinary retention is due to a spastic neurogenic bladder, which would be exacerbated with muscarinic agonists; a muscarinic antagonist could be used instead.

Alpha blockers such as prazosin are the most appropriate pharmacotherapy in patients with spastic neurogenic bladder because of their effects on smooth muscle relaxation of the neck of the bladder and the internal urethral sphincter, which can improve urine outflow. This patient likely had a spinal cord lesion near the level of T10 (decreased sensation below the umbilicus), which is now causing sympathetic stimulation of the urethral sphincter, as evidenced by the urodynamic studies. Alpha blockers are also a first-line therapy in urinary retention due to outflow tract obstruction caused by benign prostatic hyperplasia. The most common side effects of alpha blockers are postural hypotension and headaches.

A lower, sacral lesion would affect the parasympathetic bladder input and lead to a flaccid neurogenic bladder that is unable to contract.
