question_text: A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of severe epigastric pain and nausea. She has a 20-year history of alcohol use disorder. Nine hours after admission, she becomes increasingly dyspneic and tachypneic. Pulse oximetry on supplemental oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. Physical examination shows diffuse lung crackles, marked epigastric tenderness, and a periumbilical hematoma. Laboratory studies show normal brain natriuretic peptide. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral opacities in the lower lung fields. Which of the following pathomechanisms best explains this patient's pulmonary findings?
content_preview: A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of severe epigastric pain and nausea. She has a 20-year history of alcohol use disorder. Nine hours after admission, she becomes increasingly dyspneic and tachypneic. Pulse oximetry on supplemental oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. Physical examination shows diffuse lung crackles, marked epigastric tenderness, and a periumbilical hematoma. Laboratory studies show normal brain natriuretic peptide. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral opacities in the lower lung fields. Which of the following pathomechanisms best explains this patient's pulmonary findings?
hint: This patient's abdominal pain, history of alcohol use disorder, and Cullen sign (periumbilical hematoma) suggest acute pancreatitis. Patients with acute pancreatitis are at increased risk of developing severe complications such as acute respiratory distress syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize acute pancreatitis complications, and recall the pathophysiology of acute respiratory distress syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Acute pancreatitis produces a substantial systemic inflammatory response, resulting in increased membrane permeability and edema. Within the lungs, this permeability results in an exudative pleural effusion, leading to acute respiratory distress syndrome. This pathophysiology is further supported by this patient's x-ray findings, hypoxia, and dyspnea. Oxygen supplementation and treatment of this patient's pancreatitis will ultimately resolve her lung issues.

images.title: Pathophysiology of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

answers.explanation_why: A left-to-right shunt is characterized by blood flowing from the systemic to the pulmonary circulation (e.g., due to a ventricular septal defect). In contrast, increased lung pressure during a pulmonary inflammatory event, such as the acute respiratory distress syndrome seen in this patient, would prevent deoxygenated blood from circulating through the lung vasculature. Thus, a right-to-left pulmonary shunt would occur.

Surfactant improves lung compliance and thereby optimizes oxygen exchange. Its production is often reduced, not increased, in acute inflammatory states, such as the acute respiratory distress syndrome that this patient has following her underlying acute pancreatitis.

A pulmonary embolism (PE) prevents oxygen from entering the bloodstream through the lungs. An acute embolic event leads to dyspnea and reduced oxygen saturation, as noted in this patient. However, acute pancreatitis, epigastric markings, and tenderness are not consistent with PE. Furthermore, bilateral opacities on x-ray would not be expected in patients with PE.

Inflammation of the bronchial mucosa is one of the mechanisms involved in asthma. Asthma can be exacerbated by stressful events such as acute alcohol intoxication. However, this patient's symptoms are more likely related to acute respiratory distress syndrome, which is a known risk in the systemic inflammatory state accompanying acute pancreatitis.

Increased pulmonary capillary pressure is associated with cardiogenic pulmonary edema. It is often difficult to differentiate cardiogenic edema from acute respiratory distress syndrome, as x-ray findings and clinical examination between these patients would be similar. However, in cardiogenic pulmonary edema, the brain natriuretic peptide level would be expected to be at least 100, not within normal limits, as seen in this patient. Furthermore, acute pancreatitis is not known to cause cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

question_text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of intermittent chest tightness that worsens with exercise. He has chronic atrial fibrillation treated with a drug that prolongs the QT interval. During cardiac stress testing, an ECG shows progressive shortening of the QT interval as the heart rate increases. Which of the following drugs is this patient most likely taking?
content_preview: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of intermittent chest tightness that worsens with exercise. He has chronic atrial fibrillation treated with a drug that prolongs the QT interval. During cardiac stress testing, an ECG shows progressive shortening of the QT interval as the heart rate increases. Which of the following drugs is this patient most likely taking?
hint: This patient is taking a drug that exhibits reverse use-dependence, a phenomenon in which the effects of an antiarrhythmic (e.g., QT interval prolongation for this drug) decrease as the heart rate increases.
learning_objective: Recall the characteristics of class III antiarrhythmics and their effects on the QT interval.

answers.explanation_why: Diltiazem is a class IV antiarrhythmic that is used for rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation. Class IV antiarrhythmic drugs inhibit slow calcium channels which mediate cardiac pacemaker depolarization. This inhibition decreases the ability of cardiac pacemaker cells to reach the threshold potential and decreases conduction velocity. As a result, the duration of the effective refractory period increases, which results in PR interval prolongation on ECG. Class IV antiarrhythmics do not affect the QT interval.

Lidocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic used to treat ventricular arrhythmias; it is not used to treat atrial fibrillation. Class IB antiarrhythmics block sodium channels in cardiac myocytes and shorten the duration of the action potential. They do not prolong the QT interval and may slightly shorten it. Moreover, while class IB antiarrhythmics exhibit some use-dependence, they do not exhibit reverse use-dependence.

Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic that is used to convert atrial fibrillation to sinus rhythm. Class IC antiarrhythmics block sodium channels in cardiac myocytes and prolong the duration of the effective refractory period in the atrioventricular node. Although this class of antiarrhythmics has little effect on ventricular repolarization, the QT interval is minimally prolonged due to the increase in the QRS duration. Moreover, flecainide exhibits use-dependence; in rare cases, there is a progressive prolonging of the QT interval on cardiac stress testing (i.e., as the heart rate increases) rather than the shortening of the QT interval seen in this patient.

Dofetilide is a class III antiarrhythmic that is used to maintain normal sinus rhythm in patients with chronic atrial fibrillation. Class III antiarrhythmics inhibit potassium channels which are responsible for repolarization of the cardiac membrane. Delayed repolarization prolongs the duration of the cardiac action potential and the effective refractory period, which results in QT interval prolongation on ECG. All class III antiarrhythmics, with the exception of amiodarone, exhibit reverse use-dependence, as seen during this patient's cardiac stress testing. Accordingly, these drugs have decreased antiarrhythmic effects at faster heart rates and are associated with the development of torsades de pointes at slower heart rates.

Quinidine is a class IA antiarrhythmic that is used to maintain sinus rhythm in patients with atrial fibrillation. Class IA antiarrhythmics decrease sodium influx during depolarization and potassium efflux during repolarization. This activity prolongs the duration of the cardiac action potential and the effective refractory period, which results in QT interval prolongation on ECG. However, class IA antiarrhythmics exhibit use-dependence and thus cause progressive prolongation, not shortening, of the QT interval as the heart rate increases.

Carvedilol is a β-blocker and class II antiarrhythmic that is used for rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation. In the cardiac myocyte, β-adrenergic activation of adenylate cyclase results in the production of cAMP. This second messenger facilitates the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which leads to cardiac pacemaker depolarization. Class II antiarrhythmics decrease the conduction velocity of cardiac pacemaker cells, which results in PR interval prolongation on ECG. They do not affect the QT interval.

question_text: A 70-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital 8 hours after the onset of impaired speech and right-sided weakness. Two days after admission, he becomes confused and is difficult to arouse. His pulse is 64/min and blood pressure is 166/96 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A CT scan of the brain shows hypoattenuation in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery with surrounding edema and a 1-cm midline shift to the right. Which of the following interventions is most likely to result in a decrease in this patient's intracranial pressure?
content_preview: A 70-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital 8 hours after the onset of impaired speech and right-sided weakness. Two days after admission, he becomes confused and is difficult to arouse. His pulse is 64/min and blood pressure is 166/96 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A CT scan of the brain shows hypoattenuation in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery with surrounding edema and a 1-cm midline shift to the right. Which of the following interventions is most likely to result in a decrease in this patient's intracranial pressure?
hint: Patients with large strokes are at increased risk of developing cerebral edema in the early post-stroke period. An increase in intracranial pressure (ICP) due to cerebral edema can cause impaired consciousness, papilledema, and an increase in blood pressure with a reduction in heart rate (Cushing reflex).
learning_objective: Choose the intervention to decrease intracranial pressure in a patient with cerebral edema post-stroke.

answers.explanation_why: The cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP), depends on the ICP and the mean arterial pressure (CPP = MAP – ICP). In acute strokes, vasoregulation is often lost and adequate cerebral oxygenation depends directly on the mean arterial pressure. Aggressive blood pressure reduction in this patient should be avoided as it may result in reduced perfusion and increased secondary neurologic injury.

Cerebral perfusion is regulated by pCO_2  and patients with raised intracranial pressure who are mechanically ventilated can be managed with therapeutic hyperventilation. Hyperventilation leads to a reduction in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO_2) which leads to vasoconstriction with subsequent reduction in cerebral blood flow and fall in intracranial pressure. Current guidelines recommend titrating the respiratory rate to achieve a target pCO_2 of between 28–32 mm Hg.

answers.content: Increase the fraction of inhaled oxygen
answers.explanation_why: A pO_2 < 55 mmHg would increase the cerebral perfusion pressure and subsequently aggravate the existing cerebral edema in this patient. However, the pO_2 only plays an important role in cerebral perfusion regulation in cases of severe hypoxia, which this patient does not have evidence of (normal pulse oximetry findings). Increasing the inhaled oxygen concentration (e.g., FiO_2) would be unlikely to affect his ICP.

Increasing positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is a strategy used with mechanically ventilated patients to prevent end-expiratory alveolar collapse and improve oxygenation. However, increasing PEEP reduces venous return, including the venous return from the brain, and may be detrimental to this patient with cerebral edema. Increasing PEEP is commonly used to manage acute respiratory distress syndrome but is not recommended for cerebral edema.

Decreasing the heart rate is a management strategy that may be employed in certain clinical scenarios such as acute myocardial infarction or decompensated heart failure. However, the cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) depends primarily on the ICP and the mean arterial pressure (CPP = MAP – ICP); the heart rate does not play an important role unless it is affecting the mean arterial pressure. Furthermore, this patient already has a borderline low heart rate due to the Cushing reflex.

question_text:
A 32-year-old professional runner is preparing for an upcoming competition in a high-altitude training camp in Ethiopia. He usually trains near sea level. The campsite is at 2800 m (9,200 ft) above sea level, and his training includes several runs to an altitude of 4000 m (13,000 ft). On the morning of the fourth day of the trip, his blood is drawn by a supervising physician. Which of the following sets of arterial blood gas findings is most likely?

pH
P_aO_2 (mm Hg)
P_aCO_2 (mm Hg)
HCO_3^- (mEq/L)

A
7.32
80
30
15

B
7.50
55
25
35

C
7.45
55
27
19

D
7.21
50
60
25

E
7.54
65
40
40

F
7.41
80
40
25
content_preview: A 32-year-old professional runner is preparing for an upcoming competition in a high-altitude training camp in Ethiopia. He usually trains near sea level. The campsite is at 2800 m (9,200 ft) above sea level, and his training includes several runs to an altitude of 4000 m (13,000 ft). On the morning of the fourth day of the trip, his blood is drawn by a supervising physician. Which of the following sets of arterial blood gas findings is most likely? pH PaO2 (mm Hg) PaCO2 (mm Hg) HCO3- (mEq/L) A 7.32 80 30 15 B 7.50 55 25 35 C 7.45 55 27 19 D 7.21 50 60 25 E 7.54 65 40 40 F 7.41 80 40 25
hint: In response to training at high altitude, where the partial pressure of oxygen is decreased, the body responds with compensatory hyperventilation to achieve an adequate supply of oxygen to the tissues.
learning_objective: Recall arterial blood gas findings caused by physiological adaptations to high altitude.

answers.explanation_why: These values (↓ pH, P_aCO_2, and HCO_3^-) indicate a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. Causes of metabolic acidosis include lactic acidosis, ketoacidosis, renal insufficiency, and gastrointestinal loss of HCO_3^-. The compensation mechanism for metabolic acidosis is hyperventilation, which lowers PaCO_2 to help normalize pH. However, this patient is hyperventilating in response to hypoxia at high altitude rather than to compensate for a primary metabolic acidosis.

These values (↑ pH, ↓ P_aCO_2, and ↑ HCO_3^-) indicate a combination of respiratory alkalosis and metabolic alkalosis. This patient's findings should indicate compensatory hyperventilation in response to tissue hypoxia at high altitude, which would not cause a metabolic alkalosis.

These values (upper limit of normal pH, ↓ PaCO_2, and ↓ HCO_3^-) indicate compensated respiratory alkalosis. Training at high altitudes leads to decreased P_aO_2 and consequent tissue hypoxia, triggering compensatory hyperventilation, which increases exhalation of CO_2, causing respiratory alkalosis. Renal reabsorption of HCO_3^- decreases in response to respiratory alkalosis, and the secretion of H^+ into the renal tubules is reduced. These mechanisms help lower plasma bicarbonate levels and bring the pH closer to normal. The expected HCO_3^- concentration in mEq/L can be estimated using the formula: 24 - [0.4 x (40 - PaCO_2 in mm Hg)], or by applying the clinical rule that HCO_3^- decreases by 4–5 mEq/L for every 10 mm Hg decrease in PaCO_2 below 40 mm Hg. Metabolic compensation for respiratory alkalosis in high altitudes typically occurs within 2–5 days.

These values (↓ pH, ↑ P_aCO_2, and normal HCO_3^-) indicate a noncompensated respiratory acidosis, which can be caused by airway obstruction, respiratory muscle weakness, and CNS depression, all of which cause hypoventilation. Retention of CO_2 decreases pH. The metabolic response to decreased pH is increased reabsorption of HCO_3^- and increased renal excretion of H^+.

These values (↑ pH, normal PaCO2, and ↑ HCO3^-) indicate primary metabolic alkalosis. Common causes include gastrointestinal acid loss (e.g., vomiting) and renal acid loss (e.g., loop or thiazide diuretics). However, this patient has been training at high altitude, and his findings most likely show hyperventilation due to hypoxia.

These values are normal ABG findings that would be expected at typical conditions (e.g., a healthy patient near sea level). However, this man has been training at high altitude, so his findings should indicate compensatory hyperventilation.

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of episodic retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 6 months. His symptoms occur when he takes long walks or climbs stairs but resolve promptly with rest. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, for which he takes ipratropium bromide. His pulse is 81/min and blood pressure is 153/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild expiratory wheezing over both lungs. Additional treatment with a beta blocker is considered. Which of the following agents should be avoided in this patient?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of episodic retrosternal chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 6 months. His symptoms occur when he takes long walks or climbs stairs but resolve promptly with rest. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, for which he takes ipratropium bromide. His pulse is 81/min and blood pressure is 153/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild expiratory wheezing over both lungs. Additional treatment with a beta blocker is considered. Which of the following agents should be avoided in this patient?
hint: This patient presents with symptoms of chronic stable angina and a history of COPD. Treatment with nonselective beta blockers should be avoided.
learning_objective: Choose beta blockers selectively for patients with COPD and angina.

answers.explanation_why: Atenolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.
Esmolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

Labetalol is a nonselective beta blocker that inhibits both beta-1 receptors and beta-2 receptors. The negative inotropic and chronotropic effects of beta-1 receptor antagonism would decrease myocardial oxygen demand. This is beneficial in patients with angina. However, inhibition of beta-2 receptors would lead to bronchoconstriction, which would decrease FEV_1 and worsen air trapping in patients with obstructive lung diseases such as COPD and asthma. Therefore, nonselective beta blockers (e.g., labetalol, propranolol, nadolol, pindolol, timolol, carvedilol) should be avoided in this group of patients.
Metoprolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.
Betaxolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.
Bisoprolol is a beta blocker with selectivity for beta-1 receptors. It would not be contraindicated in this patient with COPD.

question_text: An 11-year-old boy who recently emigrated from Ukraine is brought to the physician for the evaluation of failure to thrive. Genetic analysis shows the deletion of the 508^th codon in a gene on chromosome 7. The deletion results in defective post-translational folding of a protein and retention of the misfolded protein in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. The activity of which of the following channels is most likely to be increased as a result of the defect?
content_preview: An 11-year-old boy who recently emigrated from Ukraine is brought to the physician for the evaluation of failure to thrive. Genetic analysis shows the deletion of the 508th codon in a gene on chromosome 7. The deletion results in defective post-translational folding of a protein and retention of the misfolded protein in the rough endoplasmic reticulum. The activity of which of the following channels is most likely to be increased as a result of the defect?
hint: Deletion of the 508^th codon, which encodes phenylalanine on the CFTR gene, is the most common mutation associated with cystic fibrosis.
learning_objective: Recognize cystic fibrosis due to a CFTR gene mutation, and recall its effect on sodium channel activity.

answers.content: Calcium release channels of the sarcoplasmic reticulum
answers.explanation_why: Calcium release channels of the sarcoplasmic reticulum are known as ryanodine receptors. Mutations of the genes encoding these channels are associated with increased activity of the ryanodine receptors, which predisposes individuals to malignant hyperthermia. The ryanodine receptor gene variants are located on chromosomes 1, 15, and 19, not on chromosome 7.

answers.content: Bicarbonate channels of pancreatic ductal cells
answers.explanation_why: Bicarbonate channels of pancreatic ductal cells serve as Cl^-/HCO_3^- exchangers, in which extracellular Cl^- are exchanged for intracellular HCO_3^-. CFTR Cl^- channels establish a high extracellular Cl^- concentration, which allows for the exchange of HCO_3^- into the pancreatic juice. In cystic fibrosis, the defective Cl^- channels lead to diminished activity of the HCO_3^- channels that rely on the Cl^- gradient.

answers.content: Sodium channels of respiratory epithelial cells
answers.explanation_why:
Sodium channels of respiratory epithelial cells reabsorb Na^+ from lung secretions to maintain an electrochemical equilibrium across cell membranes. The failure of ATP-gated Cl^- channels (encoded by CFTR) to function leads to a decrease in Cl^- in lung secretions. This, in turn, results in an increase in the activity of Na^+ channels, which reabsorb Na^+ ions into cells until an extremely positive gradient is created. These ion changes stimulate passive reabsorption of water from bronchial mucous into the cells and interstitium, resulting in abnormally thick bronchial secretions.

Reabsorption of Na^+ results in a nasal transepithelial potential difference that is more negative than normal. This increased difference in electrical potential is helpful in diagnosing cystic fibrosis.

images.title: Cystic fibrosis pathophysiology
images.description: A mutation in the CFTR gene results in defective protein synthesis and the absence of the ATP-gated chloride channel in the cell surface of epithelial cells throughout the body (intestinal and respiratory epithelia, sweat glands, exocrine pancreas, exocrine glands, and reproductive organs). Chloride and sodium are normally in equilibrium, but the accumulation of intracellular chloride due to the absence of a transporter results in the retention of intracellular sodium and water (due to osmosis). This ultimately results in hyperviscous mucus, which causes blockages of small organs and airways, inflammation, and end-organ damage.

answers.content: Chloride channels of epithelial cells in sweat glands
answers.explanation_why: Cl^- channels of epithelial cells in sweat glands first reabsorb Cl^- from sweat, a process that is followed by Na^+ and water reabsorption. Cl^- channels are encoded by the CFTR gene, and defects lead to a decrease in activity of these channels. As a result, NaCl concentrations in sweat increase.

answers.content: ATP-sensitive potassium channels of pancreatic beta cells
answers.explanation_why: ATP-sensitive K^+ channels of pancreatic beta cells are open when intracellular ATP concentrations are below a certain threshold, allowing K^+ to flow into the cell. Glucose entry into the cells increases the intracellular ATP concentration, which arrests the flow of K^+ and depolarizes the membrane, initiating insulin release. Defects of the gene encoding ATP-sensitive K^+ channels result in hypoinsulinemia, which results in neonatal diabetes mellitus and failure to thrive. However, the gene is located on chromosome 11, not 7.

question_text:
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. During this time, he has noticed blood in his stool on 5 separate occasions. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. His hemoglobin concentration is 8.9 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 65 μm^3. Further analysis of this patient's arterial blood is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings?

%O_2 saturation
O_2 partial pressure
O_2 content
O_2-Hb dissociation curve

A
Normal
normal
normal
normal

B
Decreased
normal
decreased
left-shift

C
Normal
normal
increased
normal

D
Normal
normal
decreased
normal

E
Decreased
decreased
decreased
right-shift
content_preview: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion. During this time, he has noticed blood in his stool on 5 separate occasions. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. His hemoglobin concentration is 8.9 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 65 μm3. Further analysis of this patient's arterial blood is most likely to show which of the following sets of findings? %O2 saturation O2 partial pressure O2 content O2-Hb dissociation curve A Normal normal normal normal B Decreased normal decreased left-shift C Normal normal increased normal D Normal normal decreased normal E Decreased decreased decreased right-shift
hint: This patient has chronic blood loss that has resulted in iron deficiency anemia, which can manifest with fatigue, pale conjunctivae, and microcytic anemia (decreased hemoglobin concentration and mean corpuscular volume).
learning_objective: Recall the impact of anemia on oxygen transport and delivery.

answers.explanation_why: Fatigue and shortness of breath in a patient with these normal arterial blood findings could be caused by acute cyanide poisoning, which impairs the mitochondrial enzyme cytochrome c oxidase and causes histotoxic hypoxia. Cyanide poisoning has no effect on O_2 content or PaO_2. Because the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen also remains unchanged, SaO_2 and the O_2-Hb dissociation curve are unaffected. However, this patient's symptoms have been present for 8 months and are unlikely to be caused by cyanide poisoning. In addition, he lacks classical manifestations of this condition such as almond-scented breath and bright red skin tone. Moreover, this set of findings is not consistent with this patient's anemia.

images.title: Mechanism of action: respiratory chain inhibitors
images.description: Uncoupling agents (e.g., salicylic acid, 2,4-dinitrophenol, and thermogenin) act by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial inner membrane, resulting in the dissociation of the electron transport chain and the ATP synthase complex.Respiratory chain inhibitors target specific protein complexes of the electron transport chain. Electron transport chain inhibitors (e.g., rotenone, malonate, antimycin A, and certain toxic substances such as cyanide and aspirin in toxic doses) block ATP synthesis by inhibiting the proton gradient. ATP synthase inhibitors (e.g., oligomycin) block ATP synthesis by inhibiting ATP synthase, the protein complex that catalyzes the synthesis of ATP from ADP and phosphate (Pi).

answers.explanation_why: These findings could be caused by acute carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning or methemoglobinemia, both of which cause fatigue and shortness of breath. Both carboxyhemoglobin and methemoglobin cause a left shift of the O_2-Hb dissociation curve because they increase the affinity of the remaining oxyhemoglobin for oxygen. As a result, the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood is reduced, which decreases both O_2 saturation and O_2 content. PaO_2, which reflects the concentration of dissolved oxygen in arterial blood, remains normal. However, this patient has no history of exposure to carbon monoxide (e.g., domestic fire) or substances that could induce methemoglobinemia (e.g., nitrates). Moreover, this set of findings is not consistent with this patient's anemia.

These findings could be caused by polycythemia vera (PV). PV causes an overall increase in erythrocyte count and hemoglobin concentration, which results in an increase in O_2 content. PaO_2, which reflects the concentration of dissolved oxygen in arterial blood, remains normal. In addition, because the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen remains unchanged, O_2 saturation and the O_2-Hb dissociation curve are unaffected. Although PV is associated with fatigue, this patient lacks classical manifestations of this condition such as facial flushing and pruritus. Moreover, this set of findings is not consistent with this patient's anemia.

Chronic blood loss (e.g., from gastrointestinal bleeding) reduces serum concentrations of hemoglobin, as seen in this patient's arterial blood findings. PaO_2 and SaO_2 depend on the inhaled oxygen concentration, atmospheric pressure, and gas exchange in the lungs, none of which are affected by anemia. O_2 content is affected by PaO_2 (normal), SaO_2  (normal), and hemoglobin concentration (decreased), and is therefore decreased in this patient. In addition, the O_2-Hb dissociation curve depends on the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, which is affected by multiple factors, including body temperature, PaCO_2, serum pH, and 2,3-BPG concentration. In patients with anemia due to chronic blood loss, the O_2-Hb dissociation curve is normal or shifted to the right (due to a compensatory increase in 2,3-BPG concentration).

images.title: Oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve
images.description:
The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shows the partial pressure of oxygen (pO_2) in blood in relation to the percentage O_2 saturation of hemoglobin (HbO_2), i.e., the binding affinity of Hb for O_2. The curve is sigmoidal (S-shaped), starting with a gradual increase, then rising steeply before plateauing (blue curve).Factors that decrease the affinity of Hb for O_2 (e.g., ↑ pCO_2) shift the curve to the right (green curve). This increases P_50 (the partial pressure of oxygen needed to maintain 50% of Hb saturated). These factors facilitate the release of O_2 to the tissues.Factors that increase the affinity of Hb for O_2 (e.g., ↓ pCO_2) shift the curve to the left (purple curve), with a concomitant decrease in P_50.The variation in the binding affinity of Hb for O_2 represented by the sigmoidal shape of the curve is clinically significant, since it means that a decrease in pO_2 does not lead to a corresponding linear decrease in % HbO_2. Instead, HbO_2 initially drops very slowly, but with further decrease in pO_2 then drops precipitously:

(A) A pO_2 of 90 mmHg corresponds to an HbO_2 saturation of ∼ 97%.
(B) A decrease of pO_2 to ∼75 mmHg corresponds to a decrease in % HbO_2 of only ∼3% (to 94%).
(C) A further decrease of pO_2 to 50 mmHg corresponds to a further decrease in % HbO_2 of ∼ 10% (to 84%).

answers.explanation_why: These findings could be caused by exposure to a high-altitude environment. At high altitude, the atmospheric partial pressure of oxygen decreases, which results in decreased PaO_2 and O_2 content. As a physiologic response to tissue hypoxia, serum 2,3-BPG concentration increases, which decreases the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen and shifts the O_2-Hb dissociation curve to the right. This effect promotes the unloading of oxygen in peripheral tissues, which results in decreased SaO_2. However, this patient has no history of exposure to a high-altitude environment. Moreover, this set of findings is not consistent with this patient's anemia.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of delayed onset of speech. Over the past year, he has also had recurrent dizziness and three episodes of syncope. Examination of the ears shows clear auditory canals and intact tympanic membranes with normal light reflexes. Visual reinforcement audiometry shows bilateral sensorineural deafness. Genetic analysis reveals a mutation in the KCNQ1 gene causing a defect in slow voltage-gated potassium channels. An electrocardiogram of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician for evaluation of delayed onset of speech. Over the past year, he has also had recurrent dizziness and three episodes of syncope. Examination of the ears shows clear auditory canals and intact tympanic membranes with normal light reflexes. Visual reinforcement audiometry shows bilateral sensorineural deafness. Genetic analysis reveals a mutation in the KCNQ1 gene causing a defect in slow voltage-gated potassium channels. An electrocardiogram of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: A mutation in the KCNQ1 gene is the most common cause of Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome, a condition associated with arrhythmias and sensorineural deafness.
learning_objective: Recognize Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome, and recall its electrocardiogram findings.

answers.explanation_why: Pseudo-right bundle branch block and ST elevations in leads V_1 and V_2 are characteristic ECG findings of Brugada syndrome, which can manifest with dizziness and syncope. However, Brugada syndrome is caused by defective cardiac voltage-gated sodium channels (not potassium channels) and is most commonly seen in adults males of southeast Asian descent. Moreover, Brugada syndrome would not explain this patient's sensorineural deafness.

images.title: Brugada pattern
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 50 mm/s)– Regular sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼83/min
– Right axis deviation: R < S in I, R > S in aVF
– ST elevation ≥ 2 mm and a negative T wave in V_1 and V_2 (red overlay). The shape of ST elevation seen in V_1 is described as “coved.”
– Pseudo-RBBB: The ST changes create a pattern resembling RBBB in V_1.Pseudo-RBBB with ST elevation in V_1–V_3 is characteristic of Brugada pattern. To diagnose Brugada syndrome, the corresponding clinical criteria must also be met, e.g., VF, syncope, or pertinent family history.

answers.content: Slurred upstroke of the QRS complex
answers.explanation_why: A slurred upstroke of the QRS complex (i.e., delta wave) is a characteristic ECG finding of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, which may manifest with dizziness and syncope. However, WPW is caused by an accessory pathway between the atria and ventricles and is not due to defective voltage-gated potassium channels. While familial forms of WPW exist, they are uncommon and are associated with mutations in the PRKAG2 gene. Moreover, WPW would not explain this patient's sensorineural deafness.

images.title: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Regular sinus rhythm
– Rate 68/min
– Normal axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Short PR interval (112 ms)
– Wide QRS complexes (126 ms) with delta waves (the slurred initial portion of the QRS complex; zoom box)A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. If seen in asymptomatic patients with no evidence of arrhythmia, this constellation of findings is referred to as the "WPW pattern”.

answers.content: Epsilon wave following the QRS complex
answers.explanation_why: An epsilon wave following the QRS complex is a highly specific ECG finding for arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC), which may cause dizziness and syncope. However, while this condition can exhibit either autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive inheritance and is associated with various genetic mutations, it is not caused by a defect in voltage-gated potassium channels. Moreover, ARVC would not explain this patient's sensorineural hearing loss.

images.title: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy/dysplasia
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed 25 mm/s) of a patient recovering from sudden cardiac arrest- Heart rate approx. 60/min
- Regular sinus rhythm
- Left axis deviation (R > S in I, R < S aVF)
- First-degree AV block (PR interval approx. 240 ms)
- Prolonged QT interval (QTc approx. 480 ms)
- Widened QRS complexes (> 120 ms) with RBBB morphology
- Low-voltage QRS complexes in limb leads II, III, aVR, aVL, aVF (QRS amplitude < 5 mm)
- Epsilon waves in leads V_1–V_4 (best seen in V_2/V_3, examples marked in red)
- T wave inversion in leads V_1–V_4
- Slight ST depression in leads V_2–V_4Epsilon waves and T wave inversion in V_1–V_4 are highly suggestive of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (the Epsilon wave is the most specific finding in this condition).

answers.content: Progressive lengthening of the PR interval
answers.explanation_why: Progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a beat is dropped is the characteristic ECG finding of Mobitz type I, which may manifest with dizziness and syncope. However, while heart block has many etiologies (e.g., increased vagal tone in athletes, ischemic heart disease, medications), Mobitz I is not caused by defective voltage-gated potassium channels. Moreover, Mobitz I would not explain this patient's sensorineural deafness.

images.title: Second-degree atrioventricular block: Mobitz I/Wenckebach
images.description:
ECG strip (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Regular P waves at a rate of ∼80/min (green overlay)
– There is progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a P wave is not conducted (in this example, the fourth, which is not followed by a QRS complex) and the progression restarts.

answers.explanation_why: Absence of P waves and an irregularly irregular rhythm are the characteristic ECG findings of atrial fibrillation, which may cause dizziness and syncope. However, while there are many risk factors for atrial fibrillation (e.g., valvular heart disease, smoking, hyperthyroidism), it occurs almost exclusively in adults and is not caused by a defect in voltage-gated potassium channels. Moreover, atrial fibrillation would not explain this patient's sensorineural deafness.

images.title: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)– Irregularly irregular rhythm– Average ventricular rate is ∼ 144/min (24 QRS complexes can be seen on the 10-second rhythm strip)– No discernable P waves– Narrow QRS complexes– Normal cardiac axis

These findings are characteristic of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

answers.explanation_why:
Prolongation of the QT interval (typically with a QTc > 500 ms) is seen on ECG in patients with Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome, an autosomal recessive form of congenital long QT syndrome that is caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the potassium channel genes KCNQ1 (90% of cases) or KCNE1. In cardiomyocytes, the defective potassium channels cause prolongation of the ventricular action potential, which can lead to dizziness, syncope, torsades de pointes, and sudden cardiac death. In the inner ear, the defect disrupts the production of endolymph, resulting in congenital sensorineural deafness.

Another congenital LQTS with a pure cardiac phenotype is Romano-Ward syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition.

images.title: Long QT syndrome
images.description:
12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)- Regular sinus rhythm with a heart rate of approx. 107/min (tachycardia)
- Normal cardiac axis (zoom-box)
- Normal PR interval (approx.160 ms)
- Negative T-wave in III (green circles), T-wave not clearly discernible in V3
- Prolonged (corrected) QT interval with approx. 494 msThese findings suggest a long QT syndrome.

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 5-hour history of right lower quadrant pain, vomiting, and abdominal distention. Examination shows a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a dilated ascending colon with an air-fluid level in the small intestine. A test is performed in which electrodes are placed on the nasal epithelium and the nose is perfused with several different solutions. When a chloride-free solution is administered, hyperpolarization across the nasal epithelium is absent. Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in patients with the condition described here?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 5-hour history of right lower quadrant pain, vomiting, and abdominal distention. Examination shows a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a dilated ascending colon with an air-fluid level in the small intestine. A test is performed in which electrodes are placed on the nasal epithelium and the nose is perfused with several different solutions. When a chloride-free solution is administered, hyperpolarization across the nasal epithelium is absent. Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in patients with the condition described here?
hint: This patient has clinical findings consistent with distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (abdominal distention, RLQ pain, and a RLQ mass), most likely due to abnormal chloride transmembrane transport.
learning_objective: Recognize distal intestinal obstruction syndrome as a complication of cystic fibrosis, and recall the most common cause of mortality in cystic fibrosis.

answers.explanation_why: The liver is often affected in cystic fibrosis, with manifestations including cholestasis, hepatic steatosis, portal hypertension, and liver cirrhosis. However, liver cirrhosis is not a common cause of death in this patient group.
Patients with cystic fibrosis are at a higher risk of developing pulmonary embolism compared to the general population, but it is not a common cause of death in this patient group.

Pancreatic tissue involvement is common in cystic fibrosis. Progressive destruction of pancreatic beta cells can result in a significant proportion of adult patients manifesting with diabetes mellitus. However, diabetes mellitus is not a common cause of death in patients with cystic fibrosis.

The nasal potential difference test conducted here confirms the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis in this patient. Patients with cystic fibrosis have hyperviscous exocrine gland secretions, which can thicken stool and cause distal intestinal obstruction, as seen here. Hyperviscous respiratory secretions and deficient mucociliary clearance lead to recurrent pulmonary infections. This, combined with multiple episodes of antibiotic therapy, leads to the development of more severe, resistant infections (e.g., Pseudomonas aeruginosa) and structural lung changes (e.g., bronchiectasis, emphysema), with eventual progression to respiratory failure.

Nephrolithiasis is more common in patients with cystic fibrosis than in the general population, and chronic nephrolithiasis can lead to renal failure and/or urosepsis. However, it is not a common cause of death in this patient group.

question_text: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling of his legs for 2 months. Three months ago, he was diagnosed with hypertension and started on a new medication. His blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ edema in both lower extremities. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. This patient was most likely treated with which of the following drugs?
content_preview: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling of his legs for 2 months. Three months ago, he was diagnosed with hypertension and started on a new medication. His blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows 2+ edema in both lower extremities. Laboratory studies are within the reference ranges. This patient was most likely treated with which of the following drugs?
hint: The patient was started on an antihypertensive medication and now presents with peripheral edema. This side effect is due to vasodilation, which increases the hydrostatic pressure within the blood vessels, causing an efflux of plasma into the interstitial space.
learning_objective: Recognize the side effects of antihypertensive medications.

answers.explanation_why: Angiotensin II receptor blockers (e.g., losartan) cause decreased activity of angiotensin II on the AT_1 receptor, which leads to decreased systemic vasoconstriction as well as decreased renal reabsorption of water, sodium, and bicarbonate. While ARBs are used in the treatment of hypertension, the most common adverse effects are angioedema and hyperkalemia, not peripheral edema.

ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II by ACE, thereby decreasing systemic vasoconstriction and renal reabsorption of water and sodium. While ACE inhibitors are used in the treatment of hypertension, common adverse effects include cough, angioedema, and hyperkalemia, but not peripheral edema.

Aldosterone receptor antagonists (e.g., spironolactone) block aldosterone-mediated sodium and water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. While aldosterone receptor antagonists are used in the treatment of hypertension, common adverse effects include hyperkalemia and antiandrogen effects (e.g., gynecomastia), but not peripheral edema.

Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) inhibit the reabsorption of sodium in the distal convoluted tubule (which increases the excretion of sodium, water, potassium, and hydrogen ions). While thiazide diuretics are used in the treatment of hypertension, common adverse effects include hypokalemia, hyponatremia, hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, hyperuricemia, and hypercalcemia, but not peripheral edema.

Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers such as amlodipine inhibit voltage-dependent slow calcium channels. Blockage of these channels results in a decrease in the intracellular calcium that is needed for electromechanical coupling and muscle contraction. This causes vascular smooth muscle relaxation, which leads to systemic vasodilation and a decrease in blood pressure. Other common side effects of CCBs include headaches, dizziness, facial flushing, and reflex tachycardia.

Nonselective beta blockers (e.g., propranolol) inhibit both beta-1 receptors and beta-2 receptors. While beta blockers are frequently used in the treatment of hypertension, common adverse effects of nonselective beta blockers include bradycardia, orthostatic hypotension, bronchoconstriction, and erectile dysfunction. Propranolol would be unlikely to cause peripheral edema because it decreases the vasodilatory effect of peripheral beta-2 receptors.

question_text: A 53-year-old woman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex that radiates to the axilla and an extra heart sound during early diastole. Assuming all other parameters remain constant, which of the following is most likely to decrease the volume of retrograde blood flow in this patient?
content_preview: A 53-year-old woman with hypertension and hyperlipidemia comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex that radiates to the axilla and an extra heart sound during early diastole. Assuming all other parameters remain constant, which of the following is most likely to decrease the volume of retrograde blood flow in this patient?
hint: A holosystolic murmur that is best heard at the cardiac apex and radiates to the axilla is characteristic of mitral regurgitation (MR). The extra heart sound during diastole is most likely an S_3 gallop, which is often heard in patients with moderate to severe MR.
learning_objective: Recognize mitral regurgitation, and recall the effect of systemic vascular resistance on regurgitant flow.

answers.explanation_why: The left atrioventricular orifice is formed by the mitral valve annulus. In the case of mitral regurgitation, an increase in the size of this annulus would increase rather than decrease retrograde blood flow (regurgitation).

answers.content: Decrease in left atrial systolic pressure
answers.explanation_why: The left atrial systolic pressure acts as a resistance to retrograde blood flow across the mitral valve. Therefore, a decrease in left atrial systolic pressure would increase rather than decrease the volume of regurgitated blood.

Increased left ventricular inotropy would increase the ejection fraction and thereby decrease the left ventricular end diastolic volume. In a patient with mitral valve incompetence, as seen here, this phenomenon would be expected to decrease the regurgitant fraction (retrograde blood flow) across the mitral valve in the next cardiac cycle. However, this effect of increased LV inotropy is counteracted by the increase in left ventricular systolic pressure, which tends to increase regurgitant blood flow. Overall, increased LV inotropy does not result in a specific or predictable change in the regurgitant volume, as has been shown empirically in studies with dobutamine (an inotropic drug).
answers.explanation_but: Inotropic drugs are used in patients with cardiogenic shock due to acute mitral regurgitation but this is done in order to improve the cardiac output, not to decrease retrograde blood flow.

answers.explanation_why: A decrease in systemic vascular resistance (SVR) would reduce the volume of retrograde blood flow through the mitral valve. In mitral regurgitation (MR), the left ventricular ejection fraction is divided between the output through the aortic valve and through the abnormal regurgitant mitral valve. When SVR (left ventricular afterload) is decreased, a greater volume of blood is ejected through the aortic valve and less blood flows in a retrograde direction across the mitral valve (lower regurgitant fraction). This is the rationale for using systemic vasodilators (e.g., sodium nitroprusside) to treat dyspnea in patients with severe acute MR. Conversely, maneuvers such as isometric contraction and a hand grip, which increase SVR, reduce ejection fraction through the aortic valve and increase the retrograde flow.

answers.content: Increase in left ventricular end-diastolic pressure
answers.explanation_why: As retrograde flow is dependent on the pressure gradient between the LV and left atrium, an increase in left ventricular end-diastolic pressure (LVEDP) would increase the driving pressure and increase retrograde blood flow.

question_text: A 54-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by a nurse 30 minutes after receiving scheduled radiation therapy for papillary thyroid cancer. After the radioisotope was ingested, the physician realized that a much larger fixed dose was given instead of the appropriate dose based on radiation dosimetry. Administration of which of the following is most likely to prevent complications from this exposure?
content_preview: A 54-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by a nurse 30 minutes after receiving scheduled radiation therapy for papillary thyroid cancer. After the radioisotope was ingested, the physician realized that a much larger fixed dose was given instead of the appropriate dose based on radiation dosimetry. Administration of which of the following is most likely to prevent complications from this exposure?
hint: High-dose radioiodine (I^131) is used as adjunct therapy in the case of differentiated thyroid cancer (e.g., papillary thyroid cancer, follicular thyroid cancer). The drug that is used to treat an acute overdose of radioiodine is also used to treat thyroid storm because it temporarily decreases the activity of thyroid peroxidase (Wolff-Chaikoff effect).
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate treatment to prevent complications from radioiodine exposure.

answers.explanation_why: Amifostine acts as an oxygen-free radical scavenger and is used to prevent nephrotoxic side effects in patients receiving chemotherapy with platinum-based, alkylating agents (e.g., cisplatin, carboplatin, and oxaliplatin). Amifostine can prevent salivary gland damage in the case of head and neck radiation or radioiodine therapy. However, it cannot protect the thyroid gland against radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

Propylthiouracil, an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid peroxidase and the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3, is indicated in the treatment of hyperthyroidism and is the drug of choice in thyroid storm. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

Mercaptoethanesulfonate (MESNA) potentially inactivates the toxic metabolite acrolein and is therefore used to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis in patients undergoing chemotherapy with cyclophosphamide or ifosfamide. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

Potassium iodide should be administered immediately to prevent complications of high-dose radioiodine therapy (I^131). In the case of excess exposure to radioactive iodine (e.g., in patients undergoing radioactive iodine ablation or after a nuclear accident), potassium iodide is used to decrease radioactive iodine uptake by the thyroid gland, which decreases the risk of radiation thyroiditis and radiation-induced thyroid cancer. When administered immediately after radioactive iodine overdose, nonradioactive iodine in potassium iodide competes with radioactive I^131 and prevents uptake into the thyroid gland. Potassium iodide also inhibits the release of thyroid hormone by preventing the proteolytic cleavage of T3 and T4 from thyroglobulin. Therefore, it can be used as an adjunct therapy in hyperthyroidism and thyroid storm, as well as a pretreatment before thyroid surgery.

images.title: Mechanisms of action: antithyroid drugs
images.description:
Left side: effect of drugs on the thyroid gland.
- Thionamides inhibit thyroid peroxidase (TPO), which blocks thyroid hormone synthesis.
- Lithium inhibits the release of thyroid hormones and may be used off-label in a thyroid storm.
- Perchlorate inhibits the sodium-iodine cotransporter in the membrane, which blocks iodide uptake in the thyroid gland.Right side: drug effects in the periphery. A number of drugs inhibit the enzyme deiodinase, which blocks the peripheral conversion of T4 to the active form T3.

answers.explanation_why: Methimazole, an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid peroxidase and decreases thyroid hormone synthesis, is indicated in the treatment of hyperthyroidism and thyroid storm. Methimazole can be used prior to the administration of radioactive iodine therapy in patients with Graves disease to control the initial hyperthyroid phase. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

Dexrazoxane, an iron-chelating agent, is used to prevent cardiotoxicity associated with anthracycline-based chemotherapeutic agents such as doxorubicin and daunorubicin. It would not be used to treat potential radioactive iodine toxicity because it does not prevent the uptake of radioactive iodine in the thyroid gland.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus and mild asthma comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has had several episodes of sweating, dizziness, and nausea in the past 2 months that occur during the day and always resolve after she drinks orange juice. She is adherent to her diet and insulin regimen. The physician recommends lowering her insulin dose in certain situations. This recommendation is most important in which of the following situations?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus and mild asthma comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has had several episodes of sweating, dizziness, and nausea in the past 2 months that occur during the day and always resolve after she drinks orange juice. She is adherent to her diet and insulin regimen. The physician recommends lowering her insulin dose in certain situations. This recommendation is most important in which of the following situations?
hint: This patient presents with symptoms of episodic hypoglycemia (sweating, dizziness, and nausea that subsides after the intake of a sugary beverage). Severe hypoglycemia can lead to confusion, convulsions, coma, and death.
learning_objective: Recall situations associated with decreased insulin demand.

answers.explanation_why: Insulin dosing does not need to be lowered during a viral infection. Acute illness and infection are associated with hyperglycemia and worsening glycemic control (due to the release of catecholamines), which often requires increased insulin dosing. Lowering this patient's insulin dosing during a viral infection would be inappropriate because it would place her at risk of uncontrolled hyperglycemia.

Patients with type 1 diabetes require insulin to cover their carbohydrate intake during meals. Mealtime insulin is usually dosed just prior to food intake and is proportional to the expected carbohydrate intake. In cases of especially large meals or greater than expected carbohydrate intake, additional dosing of nutritional insulin may be needed. Decreasing insulin after a large meal would place this patient at high risk for developing hyperglycemia and would not be appropriate.

This patient should be advised to lower her insulin dose before exercise because exertion can cause hypoglycemia by increasing insulin sensitivity (resulting in a reduced need for exogenous insulin) and by increasing insulin-independent glucose uptake. Higher sensitivity to insulin increases glycolysis and reduces gluconeogenesis. The patient should also be advised to closely monitor her blood glucose before, during, and after exercise to watch out for symptoms of hypoglycemia.

Stress is often associated with hyperglycemia due to an increase in counterregulatory hormones that have a diabetogenic effect (glucagon, cortisol, epinephrine, and growth hormone). Lowering insulin dosing during periods of stress may worsen glycemic control and therefore would not be recommended for this patient.

This is a tricky one. Albuterol is a β2 adrenergic agonist. Although β2 agonism stimulates insulin secretion by the pancreatic β cells, activation of β2 receptors in the liver and skeletal muscle increases glycogenolysis and decreases insulin sensitivity. Overall, these mechanisms result in increased serum glucose. For this reason, hyperglycemia is a common adverse effect of β2 agonists. This patient would need to increase her insulin dose prior to using her albuterol inhaler; lowering the dose would further predispose her to hyperglycemia.

Pregnancy is often associated with increased insulin resistance and, consequently, hyperglycemia. Diabetic patients usually require higher doses of insulin coverage to maintain euglycemia. Lowering insulin dosing during pregnancy would worsen glycemic control and therefore would not be recommended for this patient.

question_text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of infertility. She has a history of anorexia nervosa and has received dietary and behavioral therapy over the past 6 months with minimal improvement in her symptoms. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 49 kg (104 lb); her BMI is 17 kg/m^2. Physical examination shows pallor and thin, soft, depigmented hair on the arms and back. After an extensive workup, the physician recommends pulsatile GnRH therapy for infertility treatment. At a follow-up examination one week after initiating therapy, a pelvic ultrasound shows a 24-mm hypoechogenic cavity in the right ovary. The patient subsequently receives a drug that results in the resumption of meiosis and the loss of gap junctions between the cumulus granulosa cells and the oocyte. This patient most likely received which of the following drugs at the follow-up examination?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of infertility. She has a history of anorexia nervosa and has received dietary and behavioral therapy over the past 6 months with minimal improvement in her symptoms. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 49 kg (104 lb); her BMI is 17 kg/m2. Physical examination shows pallor and thin, soft, depigmented hair on the arms and back. After an extensive workup, the physician recommends pulsatile GnRH therapy for infertility treatment. At a follow-up examination one week after initiating therapy, a pelvic ultrasound shows a 24-mm hypoechogenic cavity in the right ovary. The patient subsequently receives a drug that results in the resumption of meiosis and the loss of gap junctions between the cumulus granulosa cells and the oocyte. This patient most likely received which of the following drugs at the follow-up examination?
hint: Anorexia nervosa can cause infertility as a result of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Pulsatile GnRH therapy stimulates endogenous FSH secretion and ovarian follicle maturation. Resumption of meiosis and the loss of gap junctions between the oocyte in the follicle and the cumulus granulosa cells are changes that occur during ovulation.
learning_objective: Recall the pharmacotherapy used to induce ovulation in infertility treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Leuprolide is a GnRH analog that can be used in infertility treatment to stimulate ovarian follicle maturation. This patient, however, has already received pulsatile GnRH to stimulate follicular maturation. Leuprolide does not induce ovulation.

Mifepristone is a competitive progesterone antagonist most commonly used in conjunction with a prostaglandin analog for medical termination of pregnancy. At low doses, mifepristone leads to endometrial contraction, which promotes premature detachment of the ovum and results in abortion. It would not be indicated in the treatment of infertility to induce ovulation.

Recombinant human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is structurally similar to LH, is commonly used to induce ovulation. After ovarian follicle maturation is achieved with pulsatile GnRH therapy, as seen on this patient's pelvic ultrasound, recombinant hCG can then be administered to induce ovulation as part of assisted reproductive therapy. Recombinant hCG stimulates LH receptors, mimicking the mid-cycle LH surge to stimulate final oocyte maturation and ovulation.

Endogenous hCG, which is normally produced by the placenta after implantation, is used to detect pregnancy and plays no role in ovulation.
Ethinyl estradiol inhibits follicular maturation and ovulation by decreasing FSH secretion through negative feedback on the pituitary gland. It would not be used for ovulation induction.

Synthetic medroxyprogesterone can be used in the treatment of infertility to stimulate endometrial changes necessary for successful implantation. Synthetic progesterone, however, has no effect on follicle maturation or ovulation.

question_text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent chest pain and dizziness on exertion. Her pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 125/82 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6, late-peaking, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best over the right upper sternal border. An echocardiogram confirms the diagnosis. Three months later, the patient returns to the physician with palpitations and worsening shortness of breath for 2 weeks. An ECG obtained at the second visit is shown. Based on the abnormality seen on ECG, what is the most likely cause of the acute exacerbation of dyspnea in this patient?
content_preview: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent chest pain and dizziness on exertion. Her pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 125/82 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6, late-peaking, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur heard best over the right upper sternal border. An echocardiogram confirms the diagnosis. Three months later, the patient returns to the physician with palpitations and worsening shortness of breath for 2 weeks. An ECG obtained at the second visit is shown. Based on the abnormality seen on ECG, what is the most likely cause of the acute exacerbation of dyspnea in this patient?
hint: This patient presents with a crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur that is best heard over the right upper sternal border, suggesting aortic stenosis (AS). Her ECG shows features of atrial fibrillation (AF), such as irregularly irregular RR intervals, indiscernible P waves, and narrow QRS complexes.
learning_objective: Recognize aortic stenosis, and recall the effects of atrial fibrillation on ventricular preload.

answers.content: Impaired contractility of the right ventricle
answers.explanation_why: Severe AS can lead to impaired right ventricular contractility via backward failure. Backward failure can cause dyspnea due to the backup of blood into the lungs. The backup of blood in this patient is caused by impaired contractility of the left rather than the right ventricle. Also, this patient has no features of right ventricular dysfunction, such as pitting edema or jugular venous distention. In patients with AS, exacerbation of dyspnea due to AF is caused by a different mechanism.

Coronary artery blood flow predominantly occurs during diastole and is driven by the myocardial perfusion pressure gradient. AF causes a decreased, not increased, myocardial perfusion pressure gradient as a result of uncoordinated atrial contraction (which impairs diastolic filling of the left ventricle) and tachycardia (which shortens the duration of diastole). In addition, this patient has AS, which often causes left ventricular hypertrophy. Left ventricular hypertrophy further compromises the myocardial perfusion pressure gradient by impeding diastolic filling.

AS causes increased left ventricular afterload and end-systolic volume, which results in an increase in filling pressures and concentric left ventricular hypertrophy. Because left ventricular hypertrophy commonly results in diastolic dysfunction, individuals with AS rely on the contraction of the left atrium for ventricular filling. The increase in diastolic filling pressure can, in turn, cause left atrial dilatation, which increases the risk of AF. AF decreases left ventricular preload as a result of uncoordinated atrial contraction (which impairs diastolic filling of the left ventricle) and tachycardia (which shortens the duration of diastole and reduces ventricular filling time). If AF develops in individuals with severe AS, it can exacerbate symptoms of angina and dyspnea due to pulmonary edema, which is likely responsible for this patient's worsening shortness of breath.

answers.content: Decreased impulse conduction across the AV node
answers.explanation_why: Decreased impulse conduction across the AV node occurs in patients with nodal conduction abnormalities, which can cause angina, dizziness, and/or an irregular pulse, depending on the degree of AV block. However, these conditions typically cause bradycardia, and are associated with discernable P waves on ECG. Moreover, none of these conditions is associated with a crescendo-decrescendo murmur.

Increased systemic vascular resistance (SVR) occurs as part of the compensatory response to maintain tissue perfusion in patients with AS. A stenotic aortic valve reduces cardiac output and leads to hypoperfusion, which results in angina and dizziness. An increase in SVR is not, however, responsible for the acute exacerbation of symptoms, which is most likely related to AF.

images.title: Atrial fibrillation
images.description:
Lead I from a 12 lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)- Irregularly irregular rhythm (irregularly irregular R-R intervals; examples indicated by red overlay) with a ventricular rate of approx. 60/min
- No visible P waves
- Narrow QRS complexes (< 120 ms)
- Coarse fibrillatory waves (f waves; examples indicated by green overlay) can be seen between the QRS complexes. These are characterized by low amplitude, high frequency, and irregular morphology and should not be confused with P waves or flutter waves.This appearance is typical of atrial fibrillation.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father for a well-child examination. He recently emigrated from Mexico with his family and has not seen a physician since birth. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination shows a harsh, grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. During deep inspiration, the second heart sound is split. If left untreated, irreversible changes would most likely be seen in which of the following structures?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his father for a well-child examination. He recently emigrated from Mexico with his family and has not seen a physician since birth. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination shows a harsh, grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. During deep inspiration, the second heart sound is split. If left untreated, irreversible changes would most likely be seen in which of the following structures?
hint: A harsh holosystolic murmur heard along the left lower sternal border with normal splitting is suggestive of a ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common congenital heart defect.
learning_objective: Recognize a ventricular septal defect (VSD), and recall its effects on the pulmonary vasculature.

answers.explanation_why: Irreversible enlargement of the right atrium can be caused by an untreated tricuspid regurgitation (e.g., due to Ebstein anomaly), tricuspid stenosis/atresia, or atrial septal defect (ASD). Tricuspid regurgitation would cause a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (LLSB), as seen here, but the patient would also have features of right heart failure (e.g., increased JVP, hepatomegaly, ascites), unlike this asymptomatic patient. The murmur due to tricuspid stenosis would also be heard at the LLSB but the murmur would be a diastolic, not systolic. The murmur due to an ASD would be a systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the upper (not lower!) left sternal border and it would be associated with a fixed split in S_2, unlike this patient with a normal inspiratory split of S_2. This patient most likely has an isolated VSD, which is associated with irreversible changes in a different structure.

Irreversible coarctation or atresia of the ascending aorta is associated with certain congenital disorders such as bicuspid aortic valve and hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS). A bicuspid aortic valve can cause an asymptomatic systolic murmur due to aortic stenosis but such a murmur would be a mid-to-late systolic murmur and it would be best heard at the right upper sternal border (aortic area). Patients with HLHS can have a systolic murmur due to the atrial septal defect associated with HLHS but such a murmur would be a systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the upper (not lower!) left sternal border and it would be associated with a fixed split in S_2, unlike this patient with a normal inspiratory split of S_2. Moreover, patients with HLHS would present with cyanosis and features of heart failure shortly after birth, unlike this asymptomatic patient. This patient most likely has an isolated VSD, which does not cause irreversible changes in the ascending aorta.

Irreversible stenosis of the superior vena cava (SVC) is a rare congenital condition that manifests with features of superior vena cava syndrome (e.g., facial plethora, edema of the face and upper extremities) at birth, not an asymptomatic murmur, as seen here. This patient most likely has a VSD, which does not cause irreversible changes in the SVC.

A VSD is characterized by a left-to-right shunt, leading to reduced cardiac output despite increased left ventricular load and pulmonary blood flow. Oxygenated blood from the left ventricle re-enters the pulmonary system, increasing pulmonary artery and right ventricular pressure, which leads to hypertrophy in those two areas. The irreversible thickening and narrowing of the pulmonic vasculature cause pulmonary hypertension. In the late stage of the disease, due to irreversible pulmonary hypertension, the right ventricle pressure increases until it exceeds the left ventricular pressure, causing a shunt reversal (Eisenmenger reaction).

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Irreversible fibrosis and stenosis of the mitral valve are seen in rheumatic heart disease, which is a chronic complication of rheumatic fever. Mitral regurgitation, which manifests with a holosystolic murmur, is the most common valve defect associated with rheumatic fever and this patient's migrant background is a risk factor for rheumatic fever. However, murmurs due to mitral valve disease are best heard at the cardiac apex, not at the left lower sternal border, and this child has no features to suggest rheumatic fever (e.g., fever, history of recent pharyngitis). Moreover, rheumatic fever is uncommon in children below the age of 5 years. This patient most likely has a VSD, which is not associated with irreversible changes in the mitral valve.
